events.text: [Iodized salt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iodised_salt), now used in [table salt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/table_salt) worldwide, was introduced in the United States after Canadian-born pediatrician [David Murray Cowie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Murray_Cowie) became aware that the [Swiss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Switzerland) addition of [sodium iodide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/sodium_iodide) or [potassium iodide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/potassium_iodide) to salt could safely remedy the problem of iodine deficiency that was a leading cause of thyroid problems. With problems including related [goiters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/goiter) prevalent in Michigan, Dr. Cowie was able to persuade several saltmakers (Diamond Crystal Salt, Mulkey Salt, Inland Delray Salt, Michigan Salt Works, and Ruggles and Rademaker) to use the [Swiss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Switzerland) process and distribute the product, starting in Michigan grocery stores.

Two German automobile manufacturers, [Benz und Companie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Benz) (founded by [Carl Benz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Benz)) and [Daimler Motoren Gesellschaft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daimler_Motoren_Gesellschaft) (founded by [Gottlieb Daimler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottlieb_Daimler) and [Wilhelm Maybach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_Maybach)) signed an Agreement of Mutual Interest to combine operations, which would result in the merger on June 28, 1926, of the eventually merge into the [Daimler-Benz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Mercedes-Benz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz)_Group), manufacturers of the [Mercedes-Benz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz) automobile.
The German military suppressed attempts to hold [May Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Workers'_Day) demonstrations all over the country. Eight people died and hundreds were wounded.

The [Whampoa Military Academy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whampoa_Military_Academy), which would later become the military academy for the Republic of China in Taiwan, officially opened at [Guangzhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou) in China. Chinese Premier [Sun Yat-sen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen) delivered the opening address at ceremonies at [Changzhou Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Changzhou_Island). The Academy, renamed the [Republic of China Military Academy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_China_Military_Academy), would move to [Taipei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taipei) after the Communist Revolution in 1949.

[Big Maybelle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Maybelle) (stage name for Mabel Smith), American rhythm and blues singer, posthumous inductee into the [Grammy Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammy_Hall_of_Fame); in [Jackson, Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson,_Tennessee) (d. 1972)

events.text: The [Craters of the Moon National Monument](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craters_of_the_Moon_National_Monument_and_Preserve), located in the U.S. state of [Idaho](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho) near the town of [Arco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arco,_Idaho), was designated for federal protection.
U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) issued an [arms embargo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/arms_embargo) on Cuba at the request of its government.

births.text: [Jamal Abro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamal_Abro), Pakistani writer; in [Mehar Tehsil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mehar_Tehsil), [Bombay Province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombay_Presidency), [British India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_India) (now Pakistan) (d. 2004)

events.text: The [B'nai B'rith Youth Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B'nai_B'rith_Youth_Organization) (BBYO) was founded in [Omaha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omaha), [Nebraska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebraska) as a fraternal organization for Jewish teenagers, by college students who had created the Jewish fraternity [Aleph Zadik Aleph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleph_Zadik_Aleph) a year earlier, and would have 75,000 members and 250,000 alumni worldwide half a century later.

The steamship SS *Catalina*, known as "The Great White Steamer", and for making thousands of trips between [Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles) and Santa *Catalina* Island in the U.S. state of California, was launched for the first time. Over the next 51 years, it would transport as many as 2,000 passengers at a time on the 2½ hour and 26 mi trip to and from Santa *Catalina*, carrying 25 million people over the years, passengers than any other vessel anywhere in the world, according to the [Steamship Historical Society of America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steamship_Historical_Society_of_America).

In [Argentina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentina), 150,000 workers participated in a [general strike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/general_strike) protesting the mandatory deduction of 5% of their wages for a fund for old-age pensions.
The "Bozenhardt incident" occurred in Berlin when German police raided the Soviet Trade Delegation.
[Zinaida Kokorina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zinaida_Kokorina), the first female military pilot in history, made her first solo flight.

births.text: [Isadore Singer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isadore_Singer), American mathematician known for [index theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/index_theory) and the [Atiyah–Singer index theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atiyah–Singer_index_theorem) which paved the way for new interactions between pure mathematics and theoretical physics, as well as the [Kadison–Singer problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kadison–Singer_problem), the [Ambrose–Singer holonomy theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambrose–Singer_holonomy_theorem) and the McKean–Singer theorem; in [Detroit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit) (d. 2021)

[Jane Morgan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jane_Morgan) (stage name for Florence Currier), American singer and actress; in [Newton, Massachusetts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton,_Massachusetts) (alive in 2024)

events.text: [At least 50 Muslims were killed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Kirkuk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirkuk)_Massacre_of_1924) in the Iraqi city of [Kirkuk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirkuk) by the British-sponsored [Assyrian Levies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iraq_Levies) paramilitary force.

[Elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/May_1924_German_federal_election) were held in Germany for all 472 seats of the [[Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic))](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic))_(Weimar_Republic)). The [Social Democratic Party of Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany) narrowly maintained its small plurality of 100 seats, and the [German National People's Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_National_People's_Party) finished second with 95. Among the new [[Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic))](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic))_(Weimar_Republic)) electees was [Erich Ludendorff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erich_Ludendorff), who ran under the banner of the [National Socialist Freedom Movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Socialist_Freedom_Movement), a stand-in for the [Nazi Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazi_Party) which was banned at the time.
The [Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics) preliminary competitions began in Paris, France, although the official opening ceremony would not be held until July 5.
Soviet officials said the Bozenhardt incident would have serious consequences unless Germany apologized and paid reparations.

[Symphony No. 6 in E-flat minor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symphony_No._6_(Myaskovsky)), written by Russian composer [Nikolai Myaskovsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolai_Myaskovsky), premiered at the [Bolshoi Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre) in [Moscow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moscow).
The film *[Men](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men_(1924_film))*, starring [Pola Negri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pola_Negri), was released.

[Real Unión](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_Unión) defeated [Real Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_Madrid), 1 to 0, to win the 24th [Copa del Rey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Copa_del_Rey) football championship.

births.text: [Tatiana Nikolayeva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tatiana_Nikolayeva), Soviet Russian pianist and composer; in [Bezhitsa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryansk), [Russian SFSR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_SFSR) (d. 1993)

[Lynn Evans Mand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lynn_Evans_Mand) (stage name for Carolyn Hartgate), American pop music singer for [The Chordettes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Chordettes), known for "[Mr. Sandman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mr._Sandman)" and "[Lollipop](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lollipop_(1958_song))"; in [Youngstown, Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youngstown,_Ohio) (d. 2020)

events.text: The [Pusan Public Industrial Continuation School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pukyong_National_University), later the Busan National University of Technology, was established in [Japanese-ruled Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule) near Busan (at the time, Fuzan, Chōsen) in [Bosu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jung_District,_Busan). It is now part of [Pukyong National University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pukyong_National_University).
The Cuban rebellion spread to [Oriente Province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oriente_Province).

[Chattampi Swamikal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chattampi_Swamikal), 70, Indian Hindu social reformer

events.text: The Soviet Union suspended trade with Germany as it had not received satisfaction over the Bozenhardt incident.

Near [Iași](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iași), [Corneliu Zelea Codreanu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corneliu_Zelea_Codreanu) opened the founding meeting of the new anti-Semitic [Romanian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romania) organization, *Frăția de Cruce* ("Brotherhood of the Cross"). The meeting was invaded by Romania's national police, the *[Poliția Română](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanian_Police)*, on orders of the local police chief, Constantin Manciu. Codreanu and his associates were severely beaten and tortured before they were released, and he made plans to take revenge on Manciu, whom he would assassinate on October 24, 1924.
Macedonian separatists presented the [May Manifesto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/May_Manifesto).

The [Batley Bulldogs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batley_Bulldogs) defeated the [Wigan Warriors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wigan_Warriors) 13–7 to win the [championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1923–24_Northern_Rugby_Football_League_season) of the [Northern [Rugby Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugby_Football_League)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Rugby_Football_League) a predecessor to England's [Rugby Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugby_Football_League).
The strike in [Argentina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentina) ended in victory for the workers.

sources: Russia Stops German Trade; Shuts Offices - May 7, 1924, p. 16
[Wigan RL History – 1923-24 Season](http://wigan.rlfans.com/fusion_pages/index.php?page_id=343)

events.text: The first issue of *[Liberty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberty_(general_interest_magazine))* magazine, with a [cover date](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/cover_date) of May 10, appeared on newsstands. The weekly general-interest magazine would decline in popularity, becoming a monthly magazine and ceasing publication until July 1950.

The [American Popular Revolutionary Alliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Popular_Revolutionary_Alliance) (Alianza Popular Revolucionaria Americana) was founded in Mexico City by Peruvian politician [Víctor Raúl Haya de la Torre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Víctor_Raúl_Haya_de_la_Torre).
In the [Ruhr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruhr) region of Germany, 300,000 miners went on strike over working hours.
The Turkish daily newspaper *[Cumhuriyet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cumhuriyet)*, founded by [Yunus Nadi Abalıoğlu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yunus_Nadi_Abalıoğlu), published its first issue.

deaths.text: [Dimitar Blagoev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dimitar_Blagoev), 67, Bulgarian political leader

[Alluri Sitarama Raju](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alluri_Sitarama_Raju), 26, Indian independence activist, was executed by firing squad in the village of Koyyuru (now in the state of [Andhra Pradesh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh) by orders of the British Indian government.

events.text: In a lawsuit between inventors [Edwin Howard Armstrong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edwin_Howard_Armstrong) and [Lee de Forest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_de_Forest) on the question of who was entitled to the patent for the [regenerative circuit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/regenerative_circuit), the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia reversed a finding by the interference board of the U.S. Patent Office, and held that de Forest had invented [regeneration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/positive_feedback). The decision would be upheld by the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals and by the U.S. Supreme Court.
[Federico Laredo Brú](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federico_Laredo_Brú), leader of the short-lived Cuban rebellion, negotiated the terms of his surrender.

The revised version of the [Sergei Prokofiev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergei_Prokofiev)'s [Piano Concerto No. 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piano_Concerto_No._2_(Prokofiev)) was premiered more than 10 years after the September 5, 1913, premiere of the original version. Prokofiev had reconstructed the music after the only manuscript had been destroyed by a fire in 1917.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Sophie Lyons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophie_Lyons), 75, American philanthropist and reformed swindler, was fatally injured in a home invasion by three men.

sources: Lack of Leader Dooms Revolt of Cuban Army - May 9, 1924, p. 4, Author: Larry Rue

events.text: U.S. President [Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge)'s attempt to delay the controversial anti-Japanese immigration bill, until March 1, 1925, was defeated in the [House of Representatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives) by a vote of 191 to 171.

The [Richard Strauss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Strauss) [ballet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ballet) *[Schlagobers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schlagobers)* (German for "Whipped Cream") was given its first performance, in a premiere at the [Vienna State Opera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vienna_State_Opera).

A [home rule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/home_rule) bill for [Scotland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotland) was introduced by [George Buchanan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Buchanan_(politician)) into the [British House of Commons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom), but the debate degenerated into a shouting match that the [Speaker of the House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaker_of_the_House_of_Commons_(United_Kingdom)) adjourned the session for the day.

The futuristic [Westland Dreadnought](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westland_Dreadnought), designed for Britain's [Westland Aircraft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westland_Aircraft) company by Russian-born inventor Nicolas Woyevodsky, crashed on its first, and only, flight. Test pilot Stuart Keep, who had taken the Dreadnought on short takeoff and landing hops, lost control of the aircraft at an altitude of 100 ft and plummeted to the ground. Keep survived, but was seriously injured.

events.text: [J. Edgar Hoover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Edgar_Hoover), a 29-year-old lawyer, became the U.S. Justice Department's Acting Director of the Bureau of Investigation, the predecessor to the [Federal Bureau of Investigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation) (FBI). Hoover, the Associate Director for William J. Burns, took office on a temporary basis after Burns resigned. U.S. Attorney General [Harlan Fiske Stone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harlan_Fiske_Stone) was reportedly expected to appoint former Bureau Director William J. Burns to the position, but would eventually choose the young prosecutor to the job. Hoover would direct the FBI for the next 48 years use the bureau to gather information on his political enemies.
The German drama film *[Mountain of Destiny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mountain_of_Destiny)* was released.
A cave-in trapped five miners in the Black Iron Mine near [Gilman, Colorado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilman,_Colorado). All five were rescued 80 hours later, on May 13.

events.text: The first round of [voting for the 581-seat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_French_legislative_election) French Chamber of Deputies was held. Runoff elections were held on May 25 for those seats where no candidate had won a majority.

The dedication of a restored monument to [Helmuth von Moltke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmuth_von_Moltke_the_Elder) in [Halle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halle_(Saale)), [Saxony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saxony-Anhalt), Germany turned into a violent confrontation in which eight people died.

[Nellie Morse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nellie_Morse) became the fourth and last [filly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/filly) to win the [Preakness Stakes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preakness_Stakes).
The Soviet Union began a boycott of Germany over the Bozenhardt incident.

Two government-owned liquor stores opened in the Canadian province of [Alberta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alberta), ending [Prohibition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prohibition_in_Canada) in that province after eight years.

[A Short History of Liquor Regulations in Alberta](http://aglc.ca/liquor/historyofliquorregulations.asp)
Moscow Hangs Stresemann and Poincaré in Effigy - May 14, 1924, p. 1

events.text: In Canada, [Peter Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Smith_(Canadian_politician)), the former treasurer of the province of [Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontario), was arrested along with financier [Aemilius Jarvis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aemilius_Jarvis), on charges of theft and conspiracy to defraud the provincial government, in what became known as the [Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontario) Bond Scandal. While Smith and Jarvis would be acquitted of theft and fraud, they would both be found guilty of conspiracy on October 24, with Smith being given a three year sentence and spending six months in jail.

Crowds in Moscow hanged effigies of [Gustav Stresemann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustav_Stresemann) and [Raymond Poincaré](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Poincaré) during a protest against the Bozenhardt incident.

[Bohemian F.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bohemian_F.C.) of [Dublin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dublin), commonly called "Bohemians", won their first championship, finishing in first place in the 10-team [League of Ireland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1923–24_League_of_Ireland), the highest level of soccer football competition in the Irish Free State. Bohemians finished with 16 wins, no draws and two losses for 32 points, ahead of runner up [Shelbourne F.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shelbourne_F.C.) (13-2-3), whom they had defeated 2—0 and 5—2 during the season.

births.text: [Gerald Westheimer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerald_Westheimer), German-born Australian professor of [ophthalmology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ophthalmology) and researcher into visual optics; in [Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin) (alive in 2024)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Louis Hirsch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Hirsch), 36, American songwriter, died of pneumonia

sources: The Ontario Bond Scandal of 1924 Re-Examined - p. 293, Publisher: Irwin Law, Author: C Ian Kyer
PETER SMITH AND AEMILIUS JARVIS SR. CONVICTED: ERSTWHILE MINISTER OF THE CROWN AND HEAD OF BIG FINANCIAL HOUSE ARE SENTENCED AND FINED $600,000 - October 25, 1924, p. 1

events.text: The new multiracial [Legislative Council of Kenya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legislative_Council_of_Kenya), with 11 white members, 5 Asians and one Arab (but no black Africans) convened for the first time after [elections held on April 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Kenyan_general_election).

In [Springfield, Massachusetts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Springfield,_Massachusetts), the [Methodist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Methodism) general conference committee voted 76 to 37 to recommend to the conference that the [Methodist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Methodism) church never again as an organization participate in any kind of warfare under any circumstances, not even self-defense. An amendment to make an exception for wars to save the country and help humanity was tabled.

The last college championship in the U.S. for [cricket](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/cricket) was played before the Intercollegiate Cricket Association disbanded, as Haverford College defeated the University of Pennsylvania, 94 to 34.

births.text: [Eduard Petiška](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eduard_Petiška), popular Czech novelist; in [Prague](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prague), [Czechoslovakia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czechoslovakia) (d. 1987)

deaths.text: **Died:** General [Fortunato Maycotte](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortunato_Maycotte), 32, former rebel military officer and supporter of [Francisco I. Madero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_I._Madero), was executed by firing squad.

sources: No More War! Is Methodist Committee Cry - May 15, 1924, p. 1, Author: W.B. Norton

events.text: [Eugene O'Neill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eugene_O'Neill)'s play *[All God's Chillun Got Wings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_God's_Chillun_Got_Wings_(play))*, based on a Negro spiritual of the same name, premiered in New York with [Paul Robeson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Robeson) as the star. The controversial play, addressing the subject of interracial relations, caused an uproar in the United States because of its scene of Robeson, an African-American actor, having his hand kissed by white actress Mary Blair, who played the role of his character's wife. One critic would write "“The scene where Miss Blair is called upon to kiss and fondle a Negro’s hand is going too far, even for the stage."

An assassination attempt against China's Foreign Minister [Wellington Koo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wellington_Koo) failed after a bomb was delivered to his home in a gift package. One of Dr. Koo's servants opened the package and was killed, while two others were seriously injured.

births.text: [Maria Koepcke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maria_Koepcke), German ornithologist who discovered 14 species of birds in Peru; in [Leipzig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leipzig) (killed in the crash of [LANSA Flight 508](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LANSA_Flight_508) in 1971) Among the birds named for her are [Koepcke's screech owl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koepcke's_screech_owl) (*Megascops koepckeae*), [Koepcke's hermit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koepcke's_hermit) (*Phaethornis koepckeae*) and [Koepcke's hairy-nosed bat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koepcke's_hairy-nosed_bat) (*Mimon koepckeae*).

[Ernest C. Wilson Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernest_C._Wilson_Jr.), American architect known for designing the Nixon Presidential Library and Museum; in [Burbank, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burbank,_California) (d. 1992).

[Don Kenyon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don_Kenyon), English cricketer who played in international Test Cricket during the 1950s; in [Wordsley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wordsley), [Staffordshire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Staffordshire) (d. 1996)

deaths.text: [Paul Henri Balluet d'Estournelles de Constant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Henri_Balluet_d'Estournelles_de_Constant), 71, French diplomat and recipient of the 1909 [Nobel Prize for Peace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_Prize_for_Peace) for organizing the Hauge Conferences and co-creating the Permanent Court of Arbitration of the League of Nations

Major General [Pedro Díaz Molina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Díaz_Molina), 74, former Cuban slave who rose through the ranks to become a general in the [Cuban Revolutionary Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuban_Revolutionary_Army)

[Ed Swartwood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Swartwood), 65, American baseball player who was the major league [American Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Association_(1882–1891)) batting champion in 1883

images.caption: Robeson and Blair's scene was controversial in 1924

events.text: The "[control chart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/control_chart)", now commonly used for [quality control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/quality_control) in business, was first proposed by statistician and physicist [Walter A. Shewhart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_A._Shewhart), who diagrammed the chart in a memorandum to George Edwards, his boss at [Bell Laboratories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_Laboratories).

A [Labour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)) government bill to nationalize Britain's coal mining industry was defeated, 264 to 168, when the [Liberals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_Party_(UK)) refused to support it. The nationalization bill was the first attempt by the government of Prime Minister [Ramsay MacDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald) to introduce truly socialist legislation.

The Soviet Russian monthly children's magazine *[Murzilka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murzilka)* published its first issue. Aimed at primary school children aged 6 to 12, *Murzika* would continue to be published almost a century later, and has been recognized as the longest running children's magazine in the world.

births.text: [Dawda Jawara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawda_Jawara), the first Prime Minister of the Gambia (1965-1970) and then the [President of the Gambia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_of_the_Gambia) (1970-1994); in [Barajally](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barajally), [Gambia Colony and Protectorate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gambia_Colony_and_Protectorate) (d. 2019)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Harry Yount](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Yount), 85, American wilderness guide who served as the first [game warden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/game_warden) of the first U.S. National Park, [Yellowstone National Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellowstone_National_Park)

sources: British Scheme to Nationalize Mines Defeated - May 17, 1924, p. 3, Author: Vincent Sheean

[Enigmatic Icon: The Life and Times of Harry Yount](http://npshistory.com/publications/yount/index.htm) - Spring 1998, Author: William R. Supernaugh

events.text: The [United States House of Representatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives) voted, 313–78, to override President Coolidge's veto of the [World War Adjusted Compensation Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_Adjusted_Compensation_Act), far more than the two-thirds required, and sent the resolution to a vote in the [United States Senate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate).
[Black Gold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Gold_(horse)) won the [1924 Kentucky Derby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Kentucky_Derby).
People living near the [Kīlauea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kīlauea) volcano in [Hawaii](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawaii) began to evacuate as a huge eruption appeared imminent.

The [Giant Dipper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giant_Dipper), a wooden [roller coaster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/roller_coaster) that would later be designated a [National Historic Landmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark) and would still be operational almost 100 years later, opened at the [Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Cruz_Beach_Boardwalk) in the U.S. state of California.

The three planes trying to [fly around the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation) completed the longest and most hazardous leg of their journey, flying from [Attu Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attu_Island) in [Alaska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska) to Paramashiru in the [Kurils](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuril_Islands).

births.text: [Guy Pedroncini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guy_Pedroncini), French historian and biographer; in [Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris) (d.2006)

[Gabriel Bacquier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gabriel_Bacquier), French operatic baritone; in [Béziers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Béziers), [Hérault](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hérault) département (d.2020)

deaths.text: [William "Candy" Cummings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candy_Cummings), 75, American major league baseball pitcher and [Baseball Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baseball_Hall_of_Fame) enshrinee, credited by the Hall with inventing the [curve ball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/curve_ball)

[José A. Baca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/José_A._Baca), 47, U.S. politician and [Lieutenant Governor of New Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lieutenant_Governor_of_New_Mexico) since January 1, 1923, died of pneumonia.
[Tankerville Chamberlayne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tankerville_Chamberlayne), 80, British politician kicked out of the House of Commons in 1895 for election irregularities

Yanks Fly Across Pacific - May 17, 1924, p. 1

events.text: The [Kīlauea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kīlauea) volcano [erupted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/explosive_eruption) in Hawaii with a violent explosion at the Halema‘uma‘u crater.

In the last Olympic [rugby union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/rugby_union) game ever played, the United States defeated France, 17 to 3, before 30,000 fans at the [Stade Olympique](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stade_Yves-du-Manoir) in [Colombes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colombes), as part of the 1924 Summer Olympic Games. A variant of the sport, [rugby sevens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/rugby_sevens), would become an Olympic sport beginning in 2016.

births.text: [Wolfgang Rindler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolfgang_Rindler), Austrian astrophysicist and author, known for coining the term "[event horizon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/event_horizon)" in his 1956 paper "Visual Horizons in World Models", as well as for the [Rindler coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rindler_coordinates) and for the [ladder paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ladder_paradox); in [Vienna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vienna) (d.2019)
[Priscilla Pointer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priscilla_Pointer), American stage, film and TV actress; in New York City (alive in 2024)

[Maya Kopitseva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maya_Kopitseva), Soviet Russian painter; in [Gagry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gagry), [Georgian SSR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgian_SSR), [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union) (d. 2005)

events.text: The [United States Senate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate) passed the [World War Adjusted Compensation Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_Adjusted_Compensation_Act) (unofficially, the "Bonus Bill") into law when it voted 59–26 to override U.S. President Coolidge's veto.

The first use of telephone lines to transmit images was made in a demonstration by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company of "a new process of transmitting pictures by electricity". Over a period of two hours, the company transmitted 15 photographs from its office in [Cleveland, Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland,_Ohio) to the AT&T headquarters in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City).

An attempt by Korean nationalists to assassinate [Makoto Saito](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Makoto_Saito), the Japanese [Governor-General of Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor-General_of_Korea), failed after one of the eight-member *[Yukgunjamuibu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Staff_Headquarters)* team fired at Saito's patrol boat from the Chinese side of the [Yalu River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yalu_River). The boat, which was conducting border patrol at Saito's request, was able to retreat before further shots could be fired.

Dr. Roscoe R. Spencer of the [U.S. Public Health Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Public_Health_Service) successfully tested his research team's vaccine against [Rocky Mountain spotted fever](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocky_Mountain_spotted_fever), injecting himself with "a large dose of mashed wood ticks, from lot 2351B, and some weak carbolic acid", after which he and other persons given the vaccine were able to achieve full or partial immunity to the fatal disease.

A conference in [Istanbul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Istanbul) to resolve the [Mosul question](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosul_question), a dispute between the United Kingdom and Turkey over possession of the former [Mosul Vilayet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosul_Vilayet), an oil-abundant province of the Ottoman Empire, broke up with no agreement reached. The Republic of Turkey claimed Mosul, on its south border, while Britain asserted that the territory should be part of the British mandate, the Kingdom of Iraq. On August 6, the matter would be taken by the UK to the [League of Nations Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations_Council) for resolution.

The [Marx Brothers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marx_Brothers) made their [Broadway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadway_theatre) with the presentation of the stage show *[I'll Say She Is](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I'll_Say_She_Is)* at the [Casino Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casino_Theatre_(New_York_City)).

The first aerial circumnavigation of Australia was carried out by an [RAAF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Australian_Air_Force) crew in a [Fairey IIID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairey_III).

births.text: [Alexander "Sandy" Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandy_Wilson), English composer and lyricist known for the successful [musical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/musical_theatre) *[The Boy Friend](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Boy_Friend_(musical))*, in [Sale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sale,_Greater_Manchester), [Cheshire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheshire) (d. 2014)

[Harry Wald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Wald), German-born American casino executive and Holocaust survivor who served as president of the [Caesars Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caesars_Palace) casino in [Las Vegas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Las_Vegas); as Hans Eichenwald in [Rheine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rheine) (d. 1996)

sources: First Bonus Pay Day Jan. 1 - _Chicago Daily Tribune_, May 20, 1924, p. 1, Author: Arthur Sears Henning
[1924 Chronology of Aviation History](http://www.skytamer.com/1924.html)

events.text: Over one million radio listeners in the United Kingdom listened in on an experimental broadcast from a garden in [Surrey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrey) in which a [nightingale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_nightingale)'s song was picked up by a microphone concealed in a bush. Cellist [Beatrice Harrison](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beatrice_Harrison) played a few soft notes in the garden until the [nightingale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_nightingale) joined in. It has since been suggested, however, that the "[nightingale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_nightingale)" was actually the work of a bird impressionist.
Eight sailors were killed and five wounded in the explosion of an artillery shell during gunnery drills on the French battleship *[Patrie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_battleship_Patrie)*.

births.text: [Stan Paterson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Paterson), Scottish [glaciologist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/glaciology) whose research provided data on climate change in the past 100,000 years; in [Edinburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburgh).

deaths.text: **Died:** [Laure Conan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laure_Conan) (pen name for Marie-Louise-Félicité Angers), 79, popular French-Canadian novelist, book author and journalist

events.text: In one of the most famous kidnapping cases in U.S. history, 14-year-old Bobby Franks, son of the millionaire head of a watch manufacturer, [disappeared while walking home from school](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leopold_and_Loeb) in the [Kenwood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenwood,_[Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago)) area of [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago).

Many people were injured in [Gelsenkirchen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gelsenkirchen) during rioting over the Ruhr miners' strike. Belgian troops and German police fought a mob trying to prevent emergency employees from working in the mines.

The [Bulgaria national football team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulgaria_national_football_team), which would compete in seven FIFA World Cups and reach the quarterfinals in [1994](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup) and finish fourth, played its first international game, a 6 to 0 loss to [Austria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austria_national_football_team) in [Vienna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vienna).

births.text: [Tjokropranolo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tjokropranolo), Indonesian politician and Governor of Jakarta, 1977 to 1982 (d.1998)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Lucia Fairchild Fuller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucia_Fairchild_Fuller), 53, American painter, died of [multiple sclerosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/multiple_sclerosis).

events.text: The [Concerto for Piano and Wind Instruments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concerto_for_Piano_and_Wind_Instruments_(Stravinsky)) by [Igor Stravinsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky) premiered at the [Opera of Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palais_Garnier).

Bobby Franks' wealthy parents received a ransom note demanding $10,000, but the boy's body was found near [Wolf Lake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolf_Lake_(Indiana–Illinois)) before any money was paid.

The airmen trying to [fly around the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation) landed at [Kasumigaura](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kasumigaura,_Ibaraki), Japan where they were welcomed by Japanese military commanders and schoolchildren waving American flags.

births.text: [Charles Aznavour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Aznavour) (stage name for Shahnour Vaghinag Aznavouryan), [French singer of Armenian ancestry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armenians_in_France), actor and songwriter; in [Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris) (d. 2018)

[Cuddly Dudley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuddly_Dudley) (stage name for Dudley Heslop), Jamaican born British rock and roll singer, known as ""Britain's first black rock & roller"; in [Kingston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingston,_Jamaica)

Japan Booms Grand Greeting to U.S. Birdmen - May 23, 1924, p. 5, Author: Roderick Matheson

events.text: The [13th Congress of the Soviet Union's Communist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/13th_Congress_of_the_Russian_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)), the first since the death of First Secretary [Vladimir Lenin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin), opened at [Moscow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moscow) with 1,164 delegates, 748 of whom had voting rights. The nine-day conference was a confrontation between [Joseph Stalin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Stalin) and [Leon Trotsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leon_Trotsky) over the future direction of the Communist movement.

French authorities notified owners of mines in the [Ruhr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruhr) that [occupying forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Ruhr) would seize their coal if the coal miners' strike continued.

births.text: [Bette Henritze](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bette_Henritze), American stage actress, winner of the 1967 [Obie Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obie_Award_for_Distinguished_Performance_by_an_Actress) for Best Actress; in [Betsy Layne, Kentucky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betsy_Layne,_Kentucky) (d.2018)

[Arnaud Fraiteur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnaud_Fraiteur), Belgian resistance fighter hanged for assassinating Belgian newspaper editor and collaborator with the Nazis, Paul Colin; in [Ixelles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ixelles) (d. 1943)

[Kenneth Grant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Grant), English ceremonial magician and occultist, known for founding the [Typhonian Order](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Typhonian_Order) in 1973; in [Ilford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ilford), [Essex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Essex) (d. 2011)

sources: France to Seize Coal in Ruhr if Strike Keeps Up - May 24, 1924, p. 5, Author: Henry Wales

events.text: U.S. President Coolidge signed into law the [Rogers Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rogers_Act), officially the Foreign Service Act of 1924, creating the [United States Foreign Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Foreign_Service) to make diplomatic service a career track by rotating employees to posts around the world.
The government of the [Turkish Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey) purchased the [Port of Haydarpaşa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_Haydarpaşa).

In a shift on policy of [World War I reparations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I_reparations) payments, Germany's President [Friedrich Ebert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert) ordered the dissolution of the [Reich Ministry for Reconstruction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reich_Ministry_for_Reconstruction) (*Reichsministerium für Wiederaufbau*).

births.text: [José Manuel Martín](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/José_Manuel_Martín), popular Spanish film and television [character actor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/character_actor), primarily in [Spaghetti Westerns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spaghetti_Westerns) and EuroHorror films, including the first European western, *[Savage Guns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Savage_Guns_(1961_film))* (*Tierra brutal*), and *[I Want Him Dead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_Want_Him_Dead)* (*Lo voglio morto*); in [Casavieja](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casavieja)

events.text: The [Second Hellenic Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Hellenic_Republic) was proclaimed in [Greece](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greece), as [Pavlos Kountouriotis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pavlos_Kountouriotis) was inaugurated as the former monarchy's new President. Kontouriotis had been serving as the Regent of [Greece](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greece) after King George II had gone into exile on December 23.

[Beulah Annan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beulah_Annan), who had shot and killed her lover Harry Kalstedt on April 3, was acquitted of murder in her sensationalized trial in Chicago, based on a finding that she had shot Kalstedt in [self-defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/self-defense).

[Theodore F. Morse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodore_F._Morse), 51, American composer of the melodies of numerous popular songs, died of pneumonia.

events.text: The [Johnson–Reed Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnson–Reed_Act), officially the U.S. Immigration Act of 1924, was signed into law by U.S. President Calvin Coolidge to restrict the entry of non-white foreigners into the United States. The Act included the [Asian Exclusion Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asian_Exclusion_Act) and National Origins Act (Pub.L. 68–139, 43 Stat. 153), which prevented immigration from Asia and set quotas on the number of immigrants from the Eastern Hemisphere. The broad discrimination against Asians would become one of the factors in spurring Japan against its former allies and eventually into [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II).

The [Battle of [Turubah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turubah)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_[Turubah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turubah)), which would determine the fate of the region that would become [Saudi Arabia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saudi_Arabia), was fought between the [Kingdom of Hejaz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz) (ruled by [King Hussein bin Ali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hussein_bin_Ali,_King_of_Hejaz)), and the [Sultanate of Nejd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sultanate_of_Nejd) (ruled by the [Sultan Abdulaziz bin Abdul Rahman Al Saud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibn_Saud), commonly called "Ibn Saud"). At dawn, 1,500 Ikhwan warriors from Nejd made a surprise attack on the Hejazi encampment of 850 troops at [Turubah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turubah), killing almost 700 of them. [Abdullah I bin Al-Hussein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abdullah_I_of_Jordan), who was also the ruler of the [Emirate of Transjordan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emirate_of_Transjordan), narrowly escaped being killed in the attack.
The cabinet of German Chancellor [Wilhelm Marx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_Marx) resigned as he failed to form a new government.

events.text: The English [High Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_Court_of_Justice) granted an [injunction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/injunction) to the investors of [Harry Grindell Matthews](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Grindell_Matthews), forbidding him from selling the rights to his "[death ray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/death_ray)" without their consent.

German President [Friedrich Ebert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert) offered the Chancellorship to [Oskar Hergt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oskar_Hergt), but Hergt voiced too many reservations about the [Dawes Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan) and so Ebert asked [Wilhelm Marx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_Marx) to make another attempt to form a government.

A lively new session of the [Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic)) opened. When [Erich Ludendorff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erich_Ludendorff) was announced, communists heckled him with cries such as "mass murderer". The session was adjourned after communists stood and sang "[The Internationale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Internationale)" and nationalists countered with "[Deutschland über alles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutschlandlied)".

U.S. track athlete [Harold Osborn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Osborn) broke the world record for the [high jump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/high_jump), clearing the bar at 6 feet, 8¼ (=2m 03.83500000000000285 cm) inches at an Amateur Athletic Union (AAU) meet at the University of Illinois in Champaign.

events.text: The [United States Border Patrol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Border_Patrol) was created, as a part of the Labor Appropriation Act of 1924, as a federal agency within the U.S. Department of Labor to enforce the Immigration Act and to prevent illegal entry into the U.S. from Mexico and from Canada.

The government of Japan filed a formal protest to the United States against the [Immigration Act of 1924](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immigration_Act_of_1924), which had been directed at minimizing immigration to the U.S. from Japan and China.

The [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations) demanded the secret of the "[death ray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/death_ray)" which British inventor [Harry Grindell Matthews](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Grindell_Matthews) had claimed to have invented and which he had demonstrated on April 26.

[Max Wallraf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Wallraf) was elected as the [President of Germany's Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidium_of_the_Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic)), succeeding [Paul Löbe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Löbe).

The [Ireland national football team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_national_football_team) played its first match, representing the [Irish Free State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Free_State) defeating [Bulgaria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulgaria_national_football_team), 1 to 0, at the 1924 Summer Olympics in [Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris). [Paddy Duncan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paddy_Duncan) scored the team's first goal, 1 to 0.

events.text: Italian politician [Giacomo Matteotti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti), leader of the [Partito Socialista Unitario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitary_Socialist_Party_(Italy,_1922)) (PSI) and a member of parliament, made an impassioned speech at the Chamber of Deputies, criticizing the way the election of the previous month had been conducted and saying it had no validity due to the Fascist tactics of intimidating voters and candidates. His speech was shouted down by Fascists with cries such as "villain" and "traitor". Eleven days after his speech, Matteotti would be kidnapped and murdered by the Fascist Party's secret police, *[La Ceka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceka)*.

U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) and his family spent their final night in the [White House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House), which was set for six months of repairs on the roof and the upper floor. The following day, the family took up residence at the [Patterson Mansion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patterson_Mansion) on 15 Dupont Circle, owned by Mrs. Ellinor Schlesinger. President Coolidge continued to use the executive offices at the [White House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House).

The discovery, by teenagers Frank Horton Jr. and Leonard Taylor, of high grade gold ore in Nevada, set off a modern-day gold rush that attracted thousands of prospectors to the area. The town of [Weepah, Nevada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esmeralda_County,_Nevada) sprang up near [Tonopah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tonopah,_Nevada).  Within three months, the rush was over, and the Weepah was almost totally deserted by August.

An 8 foot high [storm surge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/storm_surge) washed over the city of [Tamatave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamatave), killing almost 600 people, and numerous ships in the harbor were driven inland.

Archaeologist [George Andrew Reisner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Andrew_Reisner) and a group of explorers opened the tomb of Queen [Hetepheres I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hetepheres_I), the mother of the builder of the Great Pyramid, and found that the sarcophagus was empty.

events.text: At 6:28 pm local time, [an earthquake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1927_Kita_Tango_earthquake) measuring 7.6 on the Richter magnitude scale struck on [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan)'s [Tango Peninsula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyōtango,_Kyoto) in the [Kyoto Prefecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyoto_Prefecture). The tremors and subsequent fires killed 3,020 people, and destroyed the cities of [Toyooka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyooka) and [Kinosaki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinosaki) in the [Hyōgo Prefecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyōgo_Prefecture).

In the case of *[Nixon v. Herndon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nixon_v._Herndon)*, the [United States Supreme Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court) declared unconstitutional a [Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas) law that barred African-American voters from participating in [primary elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/primary_elections), rendering similar laws in other states void. The victory was short-lived, as [Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas) passed a new law that gave political parties the right to set their own rules for participation in a party primary election.  Such laws were not held unconstitutional until the [April 1, 1946](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/April_1946) ruling in *Primus v. King*.

The first [downhill skiing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/downhill_skiing) race in the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States) took place at [Mount Moosilauke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Moosilauke) in [New Hampshire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Hampshire), and was won by Charles N. Proctor of [Dartmouth College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dartmouth_College).
Singer [Jimmie Rodgers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmie_Rodgers_(country_singer)), celebrated later as "The Father of Country Music", recorded his first hit single, *The Soldier's Sweetheart*.

Signed on September 23, 1926, the [1926 Slavery Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1926_Slavery_Convention), officially the Convention to Suppress the Slave Trade and Slavery, entered into force.

A neutrality pact was signed between [Latvia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latvia) and the [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union), but was not ratified. A subsequent, and weaker, non-aggression pact was finally signed on February 5, 1932.  The Republic of [Latvia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latvia) was annexed by the [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union) in 1940.

American balloonist [Hawthorne C. Gray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawthorne_C._Gray) set an unofficial altitude record of 8,230 meters (27,000 feet) over Belleville, Illinois, but passed out in the thin air, regaining consciousness only after the balloon descended on its own. Gray would reach 12,945 meters on May 4, a record that would fail because he parachuted from the craft (at 3,830 m) landing.  On November 4, he reached 12,192 meters but did not survive the trip.
[Adolf Hitler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolf_Hitler) made his first public speech after the Bavarian government lifted a two-year ban against his participation in political events.

sources: [Fundamentals of Aerospace Medicine](https://books.google.com/books?id=_6hymYAgC6MC&pg=PA6) - p. 6, Publisher: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, ISBN: 978-0-7817-7466-6

events.text: [Zenith Radio Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zenith_Electronics) became the first company to obtain a license from [RCA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RCA) to manufacture radios, followed on May 18 by the [Crosley Radio Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crosley_Radio_Corporation).

The [first armored car robbery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/first_armored_car_robbery) was committed by [Paul Jaworski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Jaworski) and the Flatheads Gang near [Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh,_Pennsylvania). The gang set off explosions to disable two cars that were transporting cash for the payroll for the Terminal Coal Company, and escaped with more than $104,000.

In [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City), the *[Roxy Theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roxy_Theatre_(New_York_City))* was opened by [Samuel Roxy Rothafel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Roxy_Rothafel). With 5,920 seats, it was the largest cinema built up to that time.

births.text: [Ron Todd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ron_Todd_(trade_unionist)), British trade union leader; President of TGWU 1985-92; in [Walthamstow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walthamstow), [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London) (d. 2005)

events.text: The [Kreta Ayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kreta_Ayer) Incident in [Singapore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singapore) turned much of the Chinese community in the British colony against the colonial administration. Demonstrators, observing the anniversary of the death of [Sun Yat-sen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen), were fired upon by police after stopping in front of a precinct station at [Kreta Ayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kreta_Ayer), and six people were killed.

Outside the [Bolshoi Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre) in [Moscow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moscow), an assassination attempt was made against Soviet Politburo member [Nikolai Bukharin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolai_Bukharin). The Soviets claimed that the failed crime had been the work of British intelligence agents, and a group of "counterrevolutionaries" were executed on June 9, 1927.  In 1938, Bukharin himself was accused of plotting against the government and was executed.
The adventure film *[The Beloved Rogue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Beloved_Rogue)* starring [John Barrymore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Barrymore) was released.

births.text: [Emmett Leith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmett_Leith), co-inventor of the hologram, in [Ann Arbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ann_Arbor) (d. 2005)

events.text: The leadership of the [Kuomintang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuomintang) voted to fire [Chiang Kai-shek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek) from most of his executive positions, except for commander of expeditionary forces. Generalissimo Chiang ignored the demotion and, after capturing Shanghai two weeks later, took absolute control over the [Kuomintang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuomintang).

births.text: [Raúl Alfonsín](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raúl_Alfonsín), 49th [President of Argentina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_Argentina) (1983–89), in [Chascomús](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chascomús), [Buenos Aires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buenos_Aires) (d. 2009)
[Robert Denning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Denning), American interior designer (d. 2005)

events.text: [Jigme Wangchuck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jigme_Wangchuck) was formally crowned as [King of Bhutan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_of_Bhutan), under the authority of the British protectorate.
[Igor Stravinsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky) finished the score for the opera *Oedipus Rex*.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Jānis Čakste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jānis_Čakste), 67, first [President of Latvia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_Latvia) and in office since 1922; he was succeeded by Gustavs Zemgals

events.text: [Shōwa financial crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shōwa_financial_crisis): In [Tokyo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokyo), the large Watanabe Bank failed a day after Finance Minister Naoharu Kataoka mistakenly said in a speech that the struggling bank had "at last collapsed" and depositors made a [bank run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/bank_run), withdrawing their cash. Two other banks collapsed by the end of the week and by March 24, twelve banks had crashed and more would follow.

births.text: [Carl Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Smith_(country_musician)), American country musician, in [Maynardville, Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maynardville,_Tennessee) (d. 2010)

events.text: *[The Intelligent Woman's Guide to Socialism and Capitalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Intelligent_Woman's_Guide_to_Socialism_and_Capitalism)* was completed by [George Bernard Shaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw).

births.text: [Vladimir Komarov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Komarov), Soviet cosmonaut and first human to die during a space mission, in [Orenburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orenburg) ( killed 1967 in re-entry of [Soyuz 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soyuz_1) )
[Daniel Patrick Moynihan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Patrick_Moynihan), U.S. Senator (D-N.Y.), 1977–2001, in [Tulsa, Oklahoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulsa,_Oklahoma) (d. 2003)
[Georges Séguy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Confederation_of_Labour_(France)), leader of the France's CGT labour union; in [Toulouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toulouse) (d. 2016)

events.text: The Royal Australian Navy cruiser [HMAS Australia (D84)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMAS_Australia_(D84)) was launched at [Clydesbank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clydesbank), [Scotland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotland). It would be commissioned in 1928.

births.text: [Roberto Suazo Córdova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Suazo_Córdova), [President of Honduras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_Honduras) from 1982 to 1986 (d. 2018)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Charles Emmett Mack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Emmett_Mack), 26, American silent film actor, in an auto accident

events.text: In the [Northern Expedition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Expedition): Generalissimo [Chiang Kai-shek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek)'s Nationalist forces arrived at the defensive line protecting the city of [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai). Instead of defending against the enemy, the garrison commander collaborated with the Nationalists, as well as handing over the plans for city's defense.  Though offered a position with Chiang's forces, the officer who betrayed his commander declined to work further with them.  One author wrote later, "Stupidly, he went home to [Shandong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shandong), where he was executed
A tornado leveled the town of [Green Forest, Arkansas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Forest,_Arkansas), killing 16 people and injuring more than 50. In all, 26 people were killed in the storm.

births.text: [George Plimpton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Plimpton), American sportswriter (*Paper Lion*), in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City) (d. 2003)

events.text: [Balto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balto), the Siberian husky who would later become the subject of an animated [1995 film (Amblin Entertainment)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balto_(film)), was given a parade and a hero's welcome in [Cleveland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland), along with six of his canine teammates (Fox, Sye, Billy, Tillie, Moctoc and Alaska Slim). Businessman George Kimble had rescued the animals, two years after the [1925 serum run to Nome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_serum_run_to_Nome), after finding that they were being neglected.

births.text: [Richie Ashburn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richie_Ashburn), American MLB player and Hall of Fame enshrinee, at [Tilden, Nebraska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tilden,_Nebraska) (d. 1997)
[Allen Newell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen_Newell), pioneering computer programmer, in [San Francisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco) (d. 1992)

sources: No More Mushing For Balto - _Oakland Tribune_, March 31, 1927, p. 20
The Cruelest Miles: The Heroic Story of Dogs and Men in a Race Against an Epidemic - p. 253, Publisher: W. W. Norton & Company

events.text: In [Mahad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahad), Dr. [Babasaheb Ambedkar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Babasaheb_Ambedkar) began a crusade for the end of discrimination against the [Dalit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dalit) caste in [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India), known commonly as "Untouchables".

Albert Snyder, a 44-year-old art editor for the magazine *Boating*, was brutally murdered at his home on 222nd Street in [Queens, New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queens,_New_York), and his wife, [Ruth Snyder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruth_Snyder), was discovered bound and gagged. A few days later, police arrested Ruth and her lover, Judd Gray, for Albert's murder.  After their trial and conviction, Mrs. Snyder and Mr. Gray would both be executed on January 12, 1928.

births.text: [John Joubert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Joubert_(composer)), British composer, in [Cape Town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cape_Town), [South Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Africa) (d. 2019)

events.text: [Northern Expedition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Expedition): As the Nationalist Chinese troops of [Chiang Kai-shek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek) approached [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai), Chinese Communist Party leader [Zhou Enlai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhou_Enlai) led the [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai) Uprising to aid Generalissimo Chiang. A strike was called and 600,000 workers left their jobs.  Rebels then seized police stations and armories, cut power and telephone lines, and obeyed Zhou's orders to not  harm foreigners in the city.

births.text: [Hans-Dietrich Genscher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans-Dietrich_Genscher), [Vice-Chancellor of West Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice-Chancellor_of_Germany) and the nation's [Foreign Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_Minister_of_Germany) from 1974 to 1990; following reunification with East Germany, Genscher would serve as *Vizekanzler* and [Foreign Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_Minister_of_Germany) until May 17, 1992; in [Reideburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reideburg) (d. 2016)

events.text: At a meeting at the Biltmore Hotel in New York, Zionist leader [Chaim Weizmann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaim_Weizmann) and a supporter from the Jewish community, attorney [Louis Marshall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Marshall), reached an agreement to fund a survey of [Palestine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestine_(region)) and the "[Holy Land](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Land)". A commission headed by Lee Frankel delivered its report later in the year.
Forty-three Russian peasants, on their way to church in [Orenburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orenburg), drowned when their ferry boat sank.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Charles Sprague Sargent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Sprague_Sargent), 85, creator of the [Arnold Arboretum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnold_Arboretum) in Boston.

events.text: [[Nanking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanking) Incident](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Nanking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanking)_incident_of_1927): After the troops supporting [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai)'s warlords retreated to [Nanking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanking), Nationalist troops pursued, and attacks on foreigners began. Six foreign residents, including Professor John E. Williams of Nanjing University, were killed.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Paul César Helleu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_César_Helleu), 67, French painter

events.text: [Nanking Incident](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanking_incident_of_1927): After six foreigners had been killed in [[Nanjing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanjing)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Nanjing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanjing)) and it appeared that Kuomintang troops would overrun the foreign consulates at [[Nanjing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanjing)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Nanjing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanjing)), the American consul, John K. Davis, asked for military intervention. The American destroyers USS *Noa* and USS *Preston*, and the British cruiser HMS *Emerald*, fired shells into the Chinese city to clear the streets, then dispersed the attackers with gunfire.

births.text: [Martin Walser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Walser), German author, in [Wasserburg am Bodensee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wasserburg_am_Bodensee) (d. 2023)
[Gerald D. Aurbach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerald_D._Aurbach), American biochemist, in [Cleveland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland) (d. 1991)

events.text: The Japanese aircraft carrier **Akagi** was commissioned into the [Imperial Japanese Navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Navy). After taking part in the 1941 [attack on Pearl Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/attack_on_Pearl_Harbor), the **Akagi** was damaged and sunk six months later at the [Battle of Midway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Midway).

[[Nanking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanking) Incident](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Nanking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanking)_incident_of_1927): After a day of shelling [Nanking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanking), the United States and Britain agreed to a one-day ceasefire in return for the Kuomintang allowing the hundreds of foreigners in the city to be safely evacuated.  Six foreigners, three of them British, had been killed by Chinese forces.  Chinese histories estimate that there were more than 2,000 Chinese casualties from the bombardment.  The French Communist newspaper *Communite* reported that 7,000 Chinese had been killed in the bombardment of [Nanjing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanjing), while the U.S. State Department placed the total number of deaths and injuries "at less than 100".

births.text: [Bill Barilko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Barilko), Canadian NHL player for Toronto Maple Leafs, in [Timmins, Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timmins,_Ontario) (killed in plane crash, 1951)
[Leslie Claudius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leslie_Claudius), Indian field hockey star and three time Olympic gold medalist (d. 2012)

events.text: Marshal [Chiang Kai-shek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek), Commander in Chief of the Cantonese armies, captured [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai) "without firing a shot", and arrived at the city on the gunboat *Zhongshan*, after sailing from [Hankou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hankou). At the French Concession, Chiang met with local political and business leaders, who pledged their financial support if he would end his alliance with the Communists who had helped him gain control of the city.

[Anatol Josepho](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anatol_Josepho), a 31-year-old Russian who had arrived in the United States penniless in 1925, became a millionaire with the sale of the rights to his invention, the [photo booth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/photo_booth), to the newly organized Photomaton Corporation.

[Henry Ford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Ford), at the time the world's wealthiest man, was hospitalized after he struck a tree. The auto magnate had been driving his coupe when it was run off the road by a larger Studebaker on Michigan Avenue in [Detroit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit).  Reports of the crash were kept from the press for several days  and the matter was later investigated as "an attempted assassination", but the case was later dropped.  Researcher Jim Morris concluded that the accident was the motivating reason for the inclusion of [safety glass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/safety_glass) in all Ford automobiles thereafter.

births.text: [Mstislav Rostropovich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mstislav_Rostropovich), Russian cellist and conductor, in [Baku](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baku), [Azerbaijan SSR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azerbaijan_SSR), [USSR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USSR) (d. 2007)
[Anthony Lewis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Lewis), Pulitzer Prize–winning journalist, in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City) (d. 2013)

deaths.text: [Joe Start](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Start), 84, American first baseman from 1871 to 1886
[William Healey Dall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Healey_Dall), 81, American naturalist
[Will H. Dilg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Izaak_Walton_League), 56, American conservationist

events.text: The [Majestic Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majestic_Theatre_(Broadway)) opened in New York with the production *Rufus LeMaire's Affairs*. The [Broadway theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadway_theatre) would premiere numerous successful plays and musicals, including *Carousel*, *South Pacific*, *The Music Man*, *Camelot*, *The Wiz*, and Andrew Lloyd Webber's [The Phantom of the Opera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Phantom_of_the_Opera_(1986_musical)), which has played at the Majestic since 1988.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Alfred Klausmeyer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchor_Buggy), 66, co-founder and operator of the Anchor Buggy Company, which had been the world's largest manufacturer of horse-drawn carriages from 1887 until 1915.

events.text: [Henry Segrave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Segrave) became the first person to drive a car at more than 200 mph, reaching 203.79 mph in the 1000 hp Sunbeam *Mystery*. Racing on the sands of [Daytona Beach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daytona_Beach), [Florida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida), Segrave broke [Malcolm Campbell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malcolm_Campbell)'s world record, set in [February 1927](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/February_1927), by almost 30 mph.

[Hubert Wilkins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_Wilkins) and [Ben Eielson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Eielson) became the first people to make an airplane landing on a floating icepack, after having engine trouble. Landing in the [Arctic Ocean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arctic_Ocean), further north than any previous airplane had been, Wilkins and Eielson made their repairs and took off again, flew back south, made another forced descent onto ice, and had to hike ten more days across the ice to return to the shores of [Barrow, Alaska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrow,_Alaska).

births.text: [John McLaughlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McLaughlin_(host)), American political commentator (*The McLaughlin Group*), in [Providence, Rhode Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Providence,_Rhode_Island) (d. 2016)

[John Robert Vane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Robert_Vane), British pharmacologist and 1982 Nobel Prize laureate, in [Tardebigge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tardebigge), [Worcestershire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worcestershire) (d. 2004)

sources: Segrave Smashes World Records; Speedster Sets Mark of 203.841 in Daytona Test - _Miami Daily News_, March 29, 1927, p. 1

Unsolved Mysteries of the Arctic - Publisher: Ayer Publishing, Author: [Vilhjalmur Stefansson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilhjalmur Stefansson)

events.text: [Shōwa financial crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shōwa_financial_crisis): Following the worst financial panic in that nation's history, [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan)'s Diet passed an emergency banking law, the Ginko Ho, immediately increasing the amount of capital that banks were required to keep in reserve. As a result, the number of banks decreased over the next five years from 1,417 to 680  and [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan)'s five largest banks (Mitsui, Mitsubishi, Sumitomo, Yasuda and Dai-Ichi) doubled their share of the nation's deposits, from 17% to 31%.

Coal mine explosions in Pennsylvania and Illinois killed five and eight miners respectively, but hundreds more were rescued the next day after being trapped underground. At [Ehrenfeld, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ehrenfeld,_Pennsylvania), it appeared that nearly 500 miners had been trapped, but all but five came out the next day. An explosion the same day near [Ledford, Illinois](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ledford,_Illinois) trapped 300 men, but all but 8 were saved.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Ladislas Lazaro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ladislas_Lazaro), 54, U.S. Congressman (D-La.) since 1913

events.text: At midnight, members of the [United Mine Workers of America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Mine_Workers_of_America) began a strike of American bituminous coal mines after the expiration of their 1924 contract with union mines, with 200,000 miners across the United States walking off of their jobs. Coal mining continued with strikebreakers, and the strike came to an end on July 18, 1928.

[Vladimir K. Zworykin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_K._Zworykin) received British Patent No. 255,057 for an all cathode ray television system. U.S. Patent No. 1,691,324 was issued on November 13, 1928.

births.text: [César Chávez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/César_Chávez), American labor leader, founder of [United Farm Workers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Farm_Workers); in [Yuma, Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuma,_Arizona) (d. 1993)

[William Daniels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Daniels), American film and television actor (voice of KITT in *Knight Rider*; Dr. Mark Craig in *St. Elsewhere*); in [Brooklyn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn) (alive in 2021)

events.text: The [Locarno Treaties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locarno_Treaties) were formally signed in London, intended to secure the post-war continental European territorial settlement.
European delegates also agreed that troops engaging in the [Occupation of the Rhineland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Rhineland) would be greatly reduced on January 31, 1926.

The [Farmer-Labour Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farmer-Labour_Party_(Japan)) was founded in Japan and dissolved two hours later upon orders from the government which claimed they had a secret [communist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/communism) agenda.

The [Stanley Baldwin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanley_Baldwin) government survived a vote of [censure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/censure) condemning a recent wave of arrests of communists on offences under the [Incitement to Mutiny Act 1797](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incitement_to_Mutiny_Act_1797) as a violation of free speech rights.

France negotiated separate treaties with Poland and [Czechoslovakia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czechoslovakia) pledging mutual assistance in the event of an attack by Germany on any of the signatories.

A new [general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Bolivia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolivia)n_general_election,_December_1925) was held in [Bolivia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolivia) after the [May 2 results](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolivian_general_election,_May_1925) were annulled. [Hernando Siles Reyes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hernando_Siles_Reyes) was elected [President](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_Bolivia).

births.text: [Cal McLish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cal_McLish), baseball player, in [Anadarko, Oklahoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anadarko,_Oklahoma) (d. 2010); [Martin Rodbell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Rodbell), biochemist and [Nobel Prize](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine) recipient, in [Baltimore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore), [Maryland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maryland) (d. 1998)

The Italian [Chamber of Deputies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Italy)) passed a law allowing the government to regulate rates of industrial production based on the needs of the country.
