events.text: A larger, more elaborate housing for [Lenin's Mausoleum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lenin's_Mausoleum), built from wood, was opened to the public in [Moscow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moscow). Previously, a temporary structure had housed Lenin's body. The new structure would serve as Lenin's resting place until the opening of the permanent [mausoleum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/mausoleum) in [October 1930](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_1930).
A boiler fire on the French battleship *Courbet* killed three people and injured 10 others.
[Koshien Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koshien_Stadium) opened near [Kobe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kobe), Japan.

events.text: The first [Women's International and British Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Women's_Olympiad), also called the "Women's Olympiad", was held in [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London) with women from six European nations (Belgium, Czechoslovakia, France, Italy, Switzerland at the UK) competing. [Track and field athletics events at the Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1924_Summer_Olympics) had been limited to men only. The events staged were the [100-yard dash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100-yard_dash), races at 250 metres and [1000 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1000_metres), two [relay races](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/relay_race) (4 x 110 yards and 4 x 220 yards), [hurdling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/hurdling) (120 yards), [racewalking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/racewalking) ([1000 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1000_metres), and competition in the [high jump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/high_jump), [long jump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/long_jump), [discus throw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/discus_throw), [shot put](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/shot_put) and [javelin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/javelin). Exhibition events (which including women from the U.S. and Canada) were held for in [cycling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/cycle_sport) (two-thirds of a mile bicycle sprint) [netball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/netball), and [gymnastics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/gymnastics).
Jamaican-born political leader [Marcus Garvey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcus_Garvey) was indicted by a grand jury for filing an allegedly fraudulent income tax return for 1921.

The British flying team of navigator [Archibald Stuart-MacLaren](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archibald_Stuart-MacLaren), pilot W. N. Plenderleith and flight engineer Sergeant W. H. Andrews ended when their amphibious plane had to make a forced landing in the [Bering Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bering_Sea) and was badly damaged. They were rescued from [Bering Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bering_Island) by the Royal Navy ship HMCS *Thiepval*.

events.text: The American newspaper comic strip *Little Orphan *[Annie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annie_(musical))**, created by [Harold Gray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Gray) and syndicated by New York's *[Daily News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Daily_News)*, made its first appearance. Named for [James Whitcomb Riley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Whitcomb_Riley)'s 1885 poem "Little Orphant *[Annie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annie_(musical))*", but not related to the well-known verse, the popular feature would be adapted to [an NBC Radio show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Orphan_[Annie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annie_(musical))_(radio_series)) on the Blue Network from in 1931 to 1942, to two films (in 1932 and 1938) and to the successful [Broadway musical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadway_theatre) *[Annie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annie_(musical))* in 1977. After Gray's death in 1968, *Little Orphan *[Annie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annie_(musical))** was continued by other artists but would finally cease on June 13, 2010.

The German delegation, including Chancellor [Wilhelm Marx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_Marx) and Foreign Minister [Gustav Stresemann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustav_Stresemann), joined the London reparations conference.

[John Ross Campbell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Ross_Campbell) was charged under the [Incitement to Mutiny Act 1797](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incitement_to_Mutiny_Act_1797) for the July 25 editorial in *[Workers' Weekly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workers'_Weekly_(UK))*. The British public became bitterly split on what was known as the [Campbell Case](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Campbell_Case), as conservatives wanted Campbell locked up while liberals said that rights to [free speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/freedom_of_speech) were being suppressed.
The film *[Janice Meredith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janice_Meredith)* premiered at the [Cosmopolitan Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majestic_Theatre_(Columbus_Circle)) in New York City.

events.text: Con artist [Charles Ponzi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Ponzi), known for the "[Ponzi scheme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ponzi_scheme)", was released from prison in [Plymouth, Massachusetts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plymouth,_Massachusetts) after serving less than four years of a five year federal sentence. He then reported to the District Attorney in [Boston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston), where he faced 10 indictments by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and was arrested again. A benefactor from West Roxbury put up his bond of $14,000 and Ponzi was freed until a trial date could be set.

events.text: The [[Canton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou) Merchants' Corps Uprising](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Canton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou)_Merchants'_Corps_Uprising) began in the Republic of China as the British freighter *Harvard* arrived in [Canton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou) (now Guangzhou) with guns and ammunition that had been purchased by the merchants. Before the cargo could be unloaded, the city's police seized the shipment. The merchant's corps then called a strike across all of the [Guangdong Province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong_Province), and violence over the next two months claimed 2,000 casualties.

events.text: [Lee de Forest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_de_Forest) filmed U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) on the [White House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House) lawn using his experimental [Phonofilm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonofilm) sound-on-film process, resulting in the earliest sound film footage of an American president.

Britain and Turkey agreed to submit their territorial dispute over the [Mosul question](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosul_question), regarding the border between Turkey and the [British mandate for Iraq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandatory_Iraq) and of which side should take possession of the mostly [Kurdish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurdish_people) territory of the Ottoman Empire's former [Mosul Vilayet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosul_Vilayet), to the [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations). An agreement on division would be reached on August 20.

Anti-British riots broke out in [Atbarah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atbarah) in [Sudan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudan). British troops fired on rioting Egyptian railway labourers, killing 10 of them.

In the [Hyderabad State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad_State) of [British India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_India), rioting that would injure 400 people at kill at least 10 in [Gulbarga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulbarga) (now Kalaburagi in [Karnataka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka) state). The date coincided with the [Ashura](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashura) holiday on the Islamic calendar and with a practice by Hindus in Hyderabad to carry a holy idol from the [Sharana Basaveshwara Temple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharana_Basaveshwara_Temple) in a procession through the streets on Mondays. The riots then spread during the week to throughout [British India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_India) and Burma.

Andrew S. Anderson, who had won the Democratic Party nomination for the [South Dakota election for Governor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_South_Dakota_gubernatorial_election), was killed on his farm near [Beresford, South Dakota](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beresford,_South_Dakota), when he was gored by a bull. The [state Democratic Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Dakota_Democratic_Party) selected [William J. Bulow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_J._Bulow) as the new Democratic nominee on August 20. Bulow went on to lose to [Carl Gunderson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Gunderson) on November 4.

The historical drama film *[Monsieur Beaucaire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monsieur_Beaucaire_(1924_film))*, starring [Rudolph Valentino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_Valentino) and [Bebe Daniels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bebe_Daniels), was released.

Retired boxer [Kid McCoy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kid_McCoy), who held the world middleweight title from 1896 to 1899, came home drunk to his Los Angeles apartment and shot his lover, Teresa Mors, after she told him what her friends thought of him. The next day, McCoy went to an antique shop owned by the estranged husband of Mors, looking to kill him as well, and took 11 hostages while waiting for his intended target. After a while, McCoy fled until police apprehended him. Later convicted of manslaughter instead of murder, McCoy would serve eight years in prison until his parole in 1932.

events.text: A mutiny charge against [John Ross Campbell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Ross_Campbell) was dropped when [Travers Humphreys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travers_Humphreys), prosecutor for the Crown, informed the court that "Since process has been issued in this case it has been represented that the object and intention of the article in question was not to endeavour to seduce men in the fighting forces from their duty and allegiance, or to induce them to disobey lawful orders, but that it was comment upon armed military force being used by the State for the suppression of industrial disputes." Humphreys said that he had been instructed not to offer any evidence upon the charge, and so Campbell was freed. [Sir Patrick Hastings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patrick_Hastings), the [Attorney General](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attorney_General_for_England_and_Wales), had stopped the prosecution after learning that Campbell was an injured war veteran, and that prosecution was opposed by [Labour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)) government. He concluded that a trial before a jury was likely to fail; backbenchers.

events.text: The body of Italian opposition leader [Giacomo Matteotti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti), who had been kidnapped on June 10 after making speeches against Fascist Prime Minister [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini), was found in a shallow ditch about 14 mi outside of Rome. Three members of the Fascist Party— [Amerigo Dumini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amerigo_Dumini) of the Fascist secret police, the [Ceka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_fascism); Giuseppe Viola, and Amleto Poveromo would be convicted of Matteotti's murder, and be released from prison 11 months later by a general amnesty proclaimed by King Victor Emmanuel III.

[Boris Savinkov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Savinkov), a Russian terrorist with the paramilitary wing of the outlawed [Socialist Revolutionary Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SR_Combat_Organization), was arrested in [Minsk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minsk) by the Soviet secret police agency [OGPU](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OGPU) after being tricked into returning to the Soviet Union by a police agent.

An agreement to enact the [Dawes Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan) was signed in London by the European powers, pending formal ratification by the respective parliaments of the countries concerned. The French and Belgians agreed to end their [occupation of the Ruhr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/occupation_of_the_Ruhr) in one year's time.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Pavel Urysohn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pavel_Samuilovich_Urysohn), 26, Russian mathematician and [topology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/topology) theorist, drowned while on vacation in Brittany in France, when he went swimming in the ocean while visiting a beach at [Batz-sur-Mer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batz-sur-Mer). During his brief career, Urysohn developed [Urysohn's metrization theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urysohn's_metrization_theorem) and [Urysohn's lemma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urysohn's_lemma). He also postulated [Urysohn universal space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urysohn_universal_space), and was co-developer of [Menger–Urysohn dimension](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menger–Urysohn_dimension) and [Fréchet–Urysohn space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fréchet–Urysohn_space).

events.text: U.S. Senator [Nathaniel B. Dial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathaniel_B._Dial) and his challenger for the Democratic Party's nomination, John J. McMahan, were both arrested for disorderly conduct in [Gaffney, South Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaffney,_South_Carolina) after a campaign meeting broke up amid threats of violence. Dial approached McMahan brandishing a chair after he charged that McMahan had called him a "dirty liar".

The [Victoria-Vélez Treaty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/:es:Tratado_Victoria-Vélez) was signed by the Foreign Ministers of Panama (Nicolás Victoria Jaén) and Colombia (Jorge Vélez) and setting a permanent boundary between the two nations. Panama had formerly been part of Colombia as the [Departamento del Istmo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isthmus_Department) and the border was based on the separation of Istmo from the [Chocó Department](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chocó_Department) of Colombia.

events.text: The [world flyers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation), U.S. Army Lieutenants [Lowell Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lowell_Smith) and Erik Nelson landed in [Greenland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenland) at [Frederiksdal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narsaq_Kujalleq), 12 hours after departing [Reykjavik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reykjavik) in [Iceland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iceland). The only other competitors, a crew of three commanded by [Antonio Locatelli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_Locatelli) of Italy, went down in the sea in [Greenland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenland), where they were rescued later by the USS *Richmond* (CL-9).

[U.S. President Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) made public a letter he wrote to the [National Negro Business League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Negro_Business_League), praising the African-American population for "the assumption of a full and honorable part in the economic life of the nation" and his belief in equal rights for all races, though not with any assistance from the federal government. Coolidge wrote, "it may fairly said that the colored people themselves have already substantially solved these phases of their problem," and added that "If they will but go forward along the lines of their progress in recent decades... their future would be well cared for." Commenting that "Our constitution guarantees equal rights to all our citizens without discrimination on account of race or color. I have taken my oath to support that constitution," he praised the "economic emancipation being splendidly wrought out by the colored people for themselves; so I believe their full political rights will be won through the inevitable logic of their position and rightfulness of their claims."

sources: American Round-the-World Fliers Arrive in Greenland after 825-Mile Arctic Hop - _Philadelphia Inquirer_, August 22, 1924, p. 1
President Praises Progress of Colored Race in America - _Philadelphia Inquirer_, August 22, 1924, p. 10

U.S. presidential candidate [John W. Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Davis) condemned the [Ku Klux Klan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan) by name in a speech in [Sea Girt, New Jersey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_Girt,_New_Jersey), reviving an issue that had badly split the [Democratic Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)) at the [National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Democratic_National_Convention). Davis called on President [Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) to do the same.
The [Agatha Christie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agatha_Christie) novel *[The Man in the Brown Suit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Man_in_the_Brown_Suit)* was published.

Communists in the [Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic)) [filibustered](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/filibuster) Chancellor [Wilhelm Marx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_Marx) by causing a loud disturbance of hoots and jeers when he tried to speak on the London conference ahead of a vote on the matter. The session was suspended and police were called in, but no clause could be found by which to arrest those who were causing the disturbance and the [Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic)) adjourned for the day.

As Mars was making its closest approach to Earth, radio stations heard what were believed to be "signals which apparently were operated by some intelligent force, yet which could be identified with no earthly telegraph code" on their receivers. Engineers pointed out after the reports that the radio receiving technology available on Earth at the time would not be able to pick up a telegraph signal from more than 10000 mi away and that acquiring signals from 34 million miles away would be "highly improbable, if not impossible."

events.text: [Miriam A. "Ma" Ferguson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miriam_A._Ferguson) won the [runoff election for the Democratic Party nomination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Texas_gubernatorial_election) for [Governor of Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_of_Texas), defeating Felix D. Robertson after the two candidates had received the highest plurality of votes in the July 26 primary without either receiving a majority. Ferguson's win in the heavily Democrat U.S. state virtually guaranteed that she would become the first woman to be elected governor of a U.S. state, with the general election set for November 4.

In a speech in [Maine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maine), U.S. vice presidential candidate [Charles G. Dawes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_G._Dawes) responded to [John W. Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Davis)' challenge of the previous day by also denouncing the [Ku Klux Klan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan) by name. events.text: With [hyperinflation in Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperinflation_in_the_Weimar_Republic) out of control in the [Weimar Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weimar_Republic), the almost worthless German [[papiermark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/papiermark)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[papiermark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/papiermark)) was finally taken out of circulation. The Reichsbank replaced the [Rentenmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rentenmark) of 1923 (whose value had fallen by two-thirds in one year) with the new [Reichsmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichsmark) coin, which was exchanged at 1:1 ratio with the [Rentenmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rentenmark) and at a 1,000,000,000,000:1 (one trillion to 1) with the [[papiermark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/papiermark)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[papiermark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/papiermark)).

The [Dawes Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan) was formally put into effect with a signing in [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London) by diplomatic representatives of Germany and the United Kingdom, Belgium, France, Greece, Italy, Japan, Portugal and Yugoslavia.

In accordance with its agreement to the Dawes Plan, Germany created the government-owned Deutsche Reichsbahn-Gesellschaft to operate Germany's railways and to use its profits to contribute to paying off the nation's war reparations.
Six people were killed in clashes with the [Ku Klux Klan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan) in [Herrin, Illinois](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herrin,_Illinois).

The [Prince of Wales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_VIII) met with President [Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) and his family at the [White House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House) in an informal two-hour visit.

Lebanese citizenship was legally created by decree of [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France)'s [High Commissioner of the Levant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_Commissioner_of_the_Levant) for the French Mandate of Lebanon and Syria, [Maxime Weygand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxime_Weygand). Citing Article 30 of the [Treaty of Lausanne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne) clause with respect for former territories of the [Ottoman Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ottoman_Empire), based in Turkey, Weygand declared "any person who was a Turkish subject and who resided in the territories of Lebanon on August 30, 1924, is confirmed as a Lebanese subject and is henceforth considered to have lost Turkish citizenship."

[Pittsburgh Pirates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates) shortstop [Glenn Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glenn_Wright) turned the rare [unassisted triple play](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/unassisted_triple_play) against the [St. Louis Cardinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals).

deaths.text: **Died:** [William Hesketh Lever](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Lever,_1st_Viscount_Leverhulme), 73, English industrialist, philanthropist and politician; [Todor Panitsa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Todor_Panitsa), 48, Bulgarian activist; [Doveton Sturdee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doveton_Sturdee), 65, British admiral

events.text: [Tom Lee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Lee_Park) rescued 32 people from the *[M.E. Norman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M.E._Norman)*, a sinking steamboat that capsized in the [Mississippi River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mississippi_River).
[South Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Africa) passed a bill making [Afrikaans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afrikaans) the official language of the Union.

births.text: [Ali Hassan Mwinyi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ali_Hassan_Mwinyi), politician, in Kivure, [Tanzania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanzania) (d. 2024)

events.text: The [Keats House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keats_House), which once belonged to the Romantic poet [John Keats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Keats), was opened to the public.

births.text: [Roy Pritchard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Pritchard), footballer, in [Dawley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawley), England (d. 1993)

events.text: [FC Barcelona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FC_Barcelona) beat [Arenas Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arenas_Club_de_Getxo), 2 to 0 in the [1925 Copa del Rey Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Copa_del_Rey_Final) in Spain.

New Zealand Prime Minister [William Massey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Massey) died in office. He was succeeded by [Francis Bell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Bell_(New_Zealand_politician)).

births.text: [Sugako Hashida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugako_Hashida), Japanese screenwriter, in [Seoul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seoul) (Keijyo), South Korea (former Japan territory until August 15, 1945) (d. 2021)

deaths.text: **Died:** [William Massey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Massey), 69, 19th [Prime Minister of New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_New_Zealand)

events.text: The romantic comedy film *[Eve's Secret](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eve's_Secret)* was released.

births.text: [Max Morlock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Morlock), footballer, in [Nuremberg, Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuremberg,_Germany) (d. 1994)

events.text: [Paul von Hindenburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_von_Hindenburg) was sworn in as [president of Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/president_of_Germany). His inaugural address emphasised the need to place unity and mutual progress ahead of political partisanship.

[William Jennings Bryan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Jennings_Bryan) agreed to participate in a trial of [John Scopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Scopes) on the side of the prosecution, ensuring great national interest.

births.text: [Yogi Berra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogi_Berra), baseball player, in [St. Louis, Missouri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis,_Missouri) (d. 2015)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Amy Lowell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amy_Lowell), 51, American poet; [Charles Mangin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Mangin), 58, French general

sources: Hindenburg's Inaugural Speech - May 13, 1925, p. 5
[Timeline: Remembering the Scopes Monkey Trial](https://www.npr.org/2005/07/05/4723956/timeline-remembering-the-scopes-monkey-trial) - July 5, 2005, Author: Noah Adams

events.text: [Aloys Van de Vyvere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aloys_Van_de_Vyvere) became [Prime Minister of Belgium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Belgium).
The Gold Standard Act was passed in Britain, officially returning the country to the gold standard.
The French captured Bibane Height in the [Rif War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rif_War).
The novel *[Mrs Dalloway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mrs_Dalloway)* by [Virginia Woolf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_Woolf) was published.

births.text: [Sophie Kurys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophie_Kurys), baseball player, in [Flint, Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flint,_Michigan) (d. 2013); [Les Moss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Les_Moss), baseball player, in [Tulsa, Oklahoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulsa,_Oklahoma) (d. 2012); [Patrice Munsel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patrice_Munsel), soprano singer, in [Spokane, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spokane,_Washington) (d. 2016)

deaths.text: **Died:** [H. Rider Haggard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._Rider_Haggard), 68, English novelist

sources: French Storm Bibane Height - May 15, 1925, p. 1

events.text: U.S. president [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) ruled out prohibitionist [Wayne Wheeler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayne_Wheeler)'s plan to use the American navy to enforce the [Volstead Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volstead_Act), believing the navy's purpose should only be for national defense and not police duty.

Editorials in the Japanese press decried American plans to strengthen the naval base at [Pearl Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearl_Harbor), as such plans either suggested fear of Japanese aggression towards America or American aggression towards Japan.
*[Al-Insaniyyah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Insaniyyah)*, the first Arabic communist newspaper, is founded.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Nelson A. Miles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_A._Miles), 85, American general

sources: Navy a Defense Arm, Not a Rum Fist – Coolidge - May 16, 1925, p. 1
U.S. Superbase Plan for Hawaii Arouses Japan - May 16, 1925, p. 3, Author: Roderick Mathson

events.text: [Flying Ebony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_Ebony) won the [Kentucky Derby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Kentucky_Derby).

The first modern performance of [Claudio Monteverdi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claudio_Monteverdi)'s opera *[Il ritorno d'Ulisse in patria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Il_ritorno_d'Ulisse_in_patria)* occurred in [Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris).

births.text: [Nílton Santos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nílton_Santos), footballer, in [Rio de Janeiro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro), Brazil (d. 2013)

sources: Oxford Dictionary of Music - p. 732, Publisher: Oxford University Press, ISBN: 0-19-861459-4, Author: [Michael Kennedy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael Kennedy (music critic))

events.text: [Thérèse of Lisieux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thérèse_of_Lisieux) was [canonized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/canonization) as a saint.
Some 15,000 people demonstrated in [Bucharest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bucharest) against the [Brătianu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion_I._C._Brătianu) government.

The [Richard Rodgers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Rodgers) and [Lorenz Hart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lorenz_Hart) [revue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/revue) *[The Garrick Gaieties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Garrick_Gaieties)* opened on Broadway.

sources: [Romania (1904–present)](http://uca.edu/politicalscience/dadm-project/europerussiacentral-asia-region/romania-1904–present/)

events.text: [Alfonso XIII of Spain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfonso_XIII_of_Spain) signed a decree ending [martial law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/martial_law) in Spain, which had been imposed in September 1923.

sources: See Dictator's End as Spain Ends Army Rule - May 19, 1925, p. 6
[Immigration and Assimilation](https://archive.org/details/immigrationassim00duncrich) - 1933, p. 156, Publisher: Heath, Author: Hannibal Gerald Duncan

events.text: [Casey Stengel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casey_Stengel) played in his final major league baseball game. The [Boston Braves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Boston_Braves) released him one day later, ending his fourteen-season playing career.

births.text: [Malcolm X](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malcolm_X), minister and activist, in [Omaha, Nebraska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omaha,_Nebraska) (d. 1965); [Pol Pot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pol_Pot), [Khmer Rouge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khmer_Rouge) leader, in [Prek Sbauv](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prek_Sbauv), [Cambodia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambodia) (d. 1998)

events.text: [Gerardo Machado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Machado) became [president of Cuba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/president_of_Cuba).
The [Murrumbidgee River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murrumbidgee_River) flooded in Australia, killing eight.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Elias M. Ammons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elias_M._Ammons), 64, 19th [Governor of Colorado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_of_Colorado); [Joseph Howard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Howard_(Prime_Minister)), 62 or 63, 1st [Prime Minister of Malta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Malta)

events.text: In an expedition directed by explorer [Roald Amundsen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roald_Amundsen), two specially-equipped seaplanes (the N24 and N25) took off from Kings Bay (now [Ny-Ålesund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ny-Ålesund)) in [Svalbard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Svalbard), Norway in an attempt to be the first to fly to the North Pole.
Legal 4.4 beer went on sale in the Canadian province of [Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontario), triggering an influx of visitors from bordering U.S. states.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Hidesaburō Ueno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hidesaburō_Ueno), 53, Japanese agricultural scientist and guardian of Hachiko

sources: Open Ontario Beer Spigots - May 22, 1925, p. 1, Author: Philip Kinsley
[With The N24 and the N25 Towards the North Pole (1925)](http://www.frammuseum.no/Polar-Expedition/The-N24-N25-flight-towards-the-North-Pole-%281925%29.aspx) - Publisher: Fram Museum

events.text: Unsure of their position, experiencing engine trouble and with half their fuel used up, the crew of the N25 touched down on the ice 150 miles short of the North Pole. The N24 spotted their predicament and landed as well. The next twenty-four days would be spent trying to chisel a primitive runway to take off again.

births.text: [James King](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_King_(tenor)), tenor singer, in [Dodge City, Kansas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dodge_City,_Kansas) (d. 2005); [Jean Tinguely](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Tinguely), artist, in [Fribourg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fribourg), Switzerland (d. 1991)

events.text: A powerful earthquake struck [Toyooka, Hyōgo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyooka,_Hyōgo), Japan.

births.text: [Joshua Lederberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joshua_Lederberg), molecular biologist, recipient of the [Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine), in [Montclair, New Jersey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montclair,_New_Jersey) (d. 2008)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Sir Edward Hulton, 1st Baronet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_Edward_Hulton,_1st_Baronet), 56, British newspaper proprietor and thoroughbred racehorse owner

events.text: The Lens war monument by French sculptor [Augustin Lesieux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augustin_Lesieux) was inaugurated in [Lens, Pas-de-Calais](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lens,_Pas-de-Calais).
The Bulgarian football club [FC Vihren Sandanski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FC_Vihren_Sandanski) was founded.

births.text: [Mai Zetterling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mai_Zetterling), actress and film director, in [Västerås](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Västerås), Sweden (d. 1994)

events.text: High school teacher [John Scopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Scopes) was indicted by a grand jury for violating Tennessee's anti-evolution law.

births.text: [Jeanne Crain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeanne_Crain), actress, in [Barstow, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barstow,_California) (d. 2003); [José María Gatica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/José_María_Gatica), boxer, in [Villa Mercedes, San Luis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Villa_Mercedes,_San_Luis), [Argentina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentina) (d. 1963)

events.text: International plans were drawn up for possibly sending a rescue expedition towards the North Pole, as the [Roald Amundsen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roald_Amundsen) plane expedition had not been heard from since its departure five days earlier.

Chicago mobster [Angelo Genna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angelo_Genna) was assassinated by the [North Side Gang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Side_Gang), crashing his car after a high-speed chase in which he was shot numerous times. He died in a hospital shortly afterwards.
The [Mongolian Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongolian_Air_Force) was activated.

births.text: [Alec McCowen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alec_McCowen), actor, in [Tunbridge Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Tunbridge_Wells), England (d. 2017)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Angelo Genna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angelo_Genna), 27, boss of [Genna crime family](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genna_crime_family)

sources: Amundsen Lost 6 Days; U.S. May Send Rescuers - May 27, 1925, p. 1

events.text: The [Coal Glen mine disaster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coal_Glen_mine_disaster) occurred in Coal Glen near [Farmville, North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farmville,_North_Carolina). 53 miners died in the explosion.

sources: Encyclopedia of Terrorist, Natural, and Man-made Disasters - 2006, p. 186, Publisher: Jones and Bartlett Publishers, ISBN: 978-0-7637-3782-5, Author: Michael I. Greenberg

events.text: British [Home Secretary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_Secretary) [William Joynson-Hicks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Joynson-Hicks,_1st_Viscount_Brentford) announced that he had issued instructions that no "aliens known to be engage in subversive activities abroad" would be allowed into the United Kingdom to participate in next week's communist conference in [Glasgow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glasgow).

births.text: [Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietrich_Fischer-Dieskau), baritone singer and conductor, in Berlin (d. 2012); and [Pavel Stepan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pavel_Stepan), pianist, in [Brno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno), [Czecheslovakia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czecheslovakia) (d. 1998)

sources: Britain Opens War in Reds; Bars All Moscow Agitators - May 29, 1925, p. 2, Author: Don Skene

events.text: British aviator [Alan Cobham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Cobham) set a new record for the longest nonstop flight in a light airplane, flying his [de Havilland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/de_Havilland) Moth from [Croydon Aerodrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croydon_Airport) in London to [Zürich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zürich), Switzerland. The flight consumed only twenty-five gallons of gasoline and six pints of oil.

sources: 500 Miles and Back in Day in Air for $10 - May 30, 1925, p. 1, Author: Don Skene

events.text: Protests were staged in [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai) against [unequal treaties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/unequal_treaty). [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai) Municipal Police opened fire and sparked an international outcry; the [May Thirtieth Movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/May_Thirtieth_Movement) drew its name from this incident.

Los Angeles police announced they had foiled a plot to kidnap Hollywood film stars [Mary Pickford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Pickford), [Pola Negri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pola_Negri) and [Buster Keaton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buster_Keaton) for ransom. Three arrests had been made.

[Peter DePaolo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_DePaolo) won the [1925 Indianapolis 500](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Indianapolis_500), the first driver to complete the course in under five hours.
[Gordon Coates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Coates) became the 21st [Prime Minister of New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_New_Zealand).

sources: Plot to Kidnap Mary Pickford - May 31, 1925, p. 1, Author: George Shaffer

events.text: [Rogers Hornsby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rogers_Hornsby) managed his first game for the [St. Louis Cardinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals). They beat the [Cincinnati Reds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Reds) 5 to 2.

deaths.text: **Died:** [John Palm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Palm), 39, [Curaçao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curaçao)-born composer (tuberculosis)

sources: [May 31, 1925 Cincinnati Reds at St. Louis Cardinals](https://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/SLN/SLN192505310.shtml)

events.text: In its third year of conferring B.A. degrees, the "Southern Branch of the University of California" formally changed to its present name to the [University of California at Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_California_at_Los_Angeles), more commonly referred to as [UCLA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UCLA).

The first seaside resort hotel in [Hawaii](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawaii), the Royal [Hawaii](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawaii)an Hotel opened for business. Now called the "Pink Palace", the hotel originally owned 15 acre of land in [Honolulu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honolulu) at [Waikiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waikiki).

On the same day, the first and only luxury hotel in [Death Valley National Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Death_Valley_National_Park)— originally called The Furnace Creek Inn, and later the [Oasis at Death Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oasis_at_Death_Valley)— opened in the California desert.

births.text: [Galway Kinnell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galway_Kinnell), American poet, in [Providence, Rhode Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Providence,_Rhode_Island) (d. 2014)

deaths.text: **Died: ** Sir [George Higginson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Higginson), 100, British general and [Crimean War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_War) hero

sources: [HawaiianHistory.org](http://www.hawaiianhistory.org/moments/roylhawn.html)

events.text: After ax murderer George J. Hassell gave directions, police in [Whittier, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whittier,_California) unearthed the bodies of his wife and three children. Hassell on death row in [Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas) for the murder there of a second wife and eight other children, earned a postponement of his February 27 execution date.
The [Ziegfeld Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ziegfeld_Theatre_(1927)) opened on Broadway with the production *Rio Rita*. The building was razed in 1967

births.text: [Stan Getz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Getz), American jazz saxophonist, in [Philadelphia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia) (d. 1991)

events.text: A [revolt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/February_1927_Revolt) against the government of [Portugal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portugal) broke out at [Oporto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oporto). After six days of fighting, and at least 120 deaths, the rebels surrendered after it appeared that [Oporto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oporto) would be destroyed by heavy artillery.  More than 600 conspirators and participants were exiled to [Portugal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portugal)'s colonies in the Azores and Cape Verde.

The [4th Regiment of the United States Marines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4th_Marine_Regiment_(United_States)), with 1,200 men, was dispatched from [San Diego](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Diego) to protect Americans in [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai).  After arriving on the transport USS *Chaumont* on February 27, the unit continued its presence in [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai) until 1941.
The [Brazilian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazil) airline [VARIG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VARIG) (Viação Aérea Rio-Grandense) began operations.

[William Phillips](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Phillips_(diplomat)) was named as the first [U.S. Minister to [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_[Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada)), and [Frederick A. Sterling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_A._Sterling) was named as the first [United States Ambassador to Ireland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_Ireland). Prior to 1927, diplomatic relations with [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada) and the [Irish Free State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Free_State) had been conducted directly with the United Kingdom.

births.text: [Val Doonican](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Val_Doonican), Irish singer and TV personality, in [Waterford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waterford) (d. 2015)
[Blas Ople](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blas_Ople), Philippine Secretary of Foreign Affairs from 2002 until his death in 2003; in [Hagonoy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hagonoy,_Bulacan) (d. 2003)

sources: [University of San Diego](http://history.sandiego.edu/GEN/projects/moss/chinamarines1.html)
[History of São Paulo Airport](http://www.portalcongonhas.com/history)

events.text: [Malcolm Campbell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malcolm_Campbell) of England broke the world's record for the fastest speed in an automobile, driving at nearly 175 mi per hour on the [Pendine Sands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pendine_Sands) in [Wales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wales). Driving the [Napier-Campbell Blue Bird](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napier-Campbell_Blue_Bird), Campbell averaged 174.883 mph (281.447 km/h).

U.S. Senator [Matthew M. Neely](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_M._Neely) (D-WV) introduced a bill in the Senate to provide a $5,000,000 reward to the discoverer of a cure for [cancer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/cancer). Neely would die of [cancer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/cancer) on January 18, 1958, after his own 15-month battle with the disease.

Flying in an airplane approximately 4000 ft above [Columbus Circle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbus_Circle) in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City), baritone [John Charles Thomas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Charles_Thomas) sang operatic arias to an audience in the first public test of what he called the "Voice of the Sky", a secret sound-reproducing and amplifying device which makes possible direct vocal communication between aircraft and any one on the ground.

images.caption: Malcolm Campbell sets new speed record at 174.883 mph

events.text: The [Royal Australasian College of Surgeons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Australasian_College_of_Surgeons) (RACS), described as "a non-profit organisation training surgeons and maintaining surgical standards in Australia and New Zealand", was founded.

The [United States Tennis Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Tennis_Association) dropped its 1926 national champion, [Vincent Richards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vincent_Richards), from its rankings after Richards became the most famous player to that time to turn professional. [Bill Tilden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Tilden), at that time still an amateur, replaced Richards at #1 in the rankings.

sources: [www.surgeons.org](http://www.surgeons.org/Content/NavigationMenu/CollegeResources/HeritageandArchives/History/Low_History.pdf)

events.text: In [Nicaragua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicaragua), a force of 1,500 rebels captured the city of [Chinandega](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinandega) and burned the city, at one time the national capital. Government troops retook the town after a battle of five days. Reportedly, 300 people were killed and 500 were wounded.  At the request of President [Adolfo Díaz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolfo_Díaz),  the United States sent troops to [Chinandega](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinandega).

The first revision of the *[Book of Common Prayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer)* since [1662](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1662) was introduced at 3:00 pm at [Westminster Abbey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westminster_Abbey). The [Archbishop of Canterbury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randall_Davidson,_1st_Baron_Davidson_of_Lambeth) received the proposed revisions for a new prayer book for the [Church of England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Church_of_England), "the outcome of sixty years of study and effort designed to make the church services richer and more elastic".  The new book quickly became a bestseller for Anglicans and Episcopalians worldwide, but failed to receive the required approval.  The House of Commons twice voted against a bill to accept the new text, a resolution that would still have required the approval of the House of Lords and royal assent by the King in his capacity as Supreme Governor of the [Church of England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Church_of_England).

births.text: [Vladimir Kuts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Kuts), Ukrainian Soviet distance runner, 1956 Olympic gold for 5,000m (world record holder 1957–65) and 10,000 m, (world record holder 1956–60)(committed suicide, 1975)
[Juliette Gréco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juliette_Gréco), French singer, in [Montpellier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montpellier) (d. 2020)

events.text: In what the American press described as "the most pretentious funeral in the history of the Orient", the [Emperor Taishō](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emperor_Taishō), known in the West as [Yoshihito](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emperor_Taishō), was buried after being mourned by his 80,000,000 subjects in [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan), who thought of him as a deity.

By a 59–30 vote, the [United States Senate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate) rejected American participation in the [Permanent Court of International Justice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permanent_Court_of_International_Justice) of the [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations), more popularly known as the "World Court".

The strongest [gun control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/gun_control) legislation in the United States, to that time, was signed by U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge).  Taking effect on May 10, the Miller Act prohibited the sending of revolvers, pistols and other small arms through the mail.  The ban was easily evaded by using private shipping companies.

[President Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) addressed a joint session of the [United States Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress) and announced that he would invite the world's major powers to meet in [Geneva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geneva) to discuss further reductions of their navies. In [1922](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1922), the [Washington Naval Treaty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Naval_Treaty) had been signed by the U.S., the [United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom), [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France), [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italy) and [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan).  As one historian noted, "The hastily conceived meeting, which [Coolidge] expected to parallel the success of the 1921-22 naval conference, turned out to be a fiasco."
The first contingent of American troops in China arrived as 300 U.S. Marines arrived at [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai) to protect U.S. citizens there.

*[Jonny spielt auf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonny_spielt_auf)*, [Ernst Krenek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Krenek)'s opera about an African-American jazz musician, premiered in [Leipzig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leipzig) and became a hit in [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany).

births.text: [Leontyne Price](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leontyne_Price), African-American operatic soprano and prima donna, in [Laurel, Mississippi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurel,_Mississippi) (alive in 2021)

deaths.text: **Died: ** Frank S. Ryan, 46, American who at one time was known as the "prince of clairvoyants" until his nationwide ring was broken in 1914.

images.caption: U.S. President Coolidge announces world peace conference

events.text: [Billy Gaffney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Fish), a 4-year-old boy, was kidnapped while playing near his apartment building at 99 Fifteenth Street in [Brooklyn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn), and was never found. More than eight years later, convicted child murderer [Albert Fish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Fish) confessed to abducting and killing Gaffney.
The city of [Homewood, Alabama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homewood,_Alabama), near Birmingham, was created by the merger of the towns of Rosedale, Edgewood and Grove Park.

The first contingent of British troops landed in [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai) to begin protection of British citizens.  Within a week, 21 warships from the U.S., Britain, Japan, France and Italy had anchored at the [Huangpu River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huangpu_River).

Three months before Charles Lindbergh's nonstop flight across the North Atlantic, two Italian army officers, Lt. Col. Francesco de Pinedo and Lt. Col. Carlo del Prete, began the longest airplane tour to that time. Taking off from [Sesto Calende](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sesto_Calende) in a [Savoia-Marchetti S.55](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Savoia-Marchetti_S.55), de Pinedo and del Prete made fifty stops over four months in Europe, Africa, and North and South America, traveling 30000 mi with 193 hours flying time.

A series of twenty [earthquake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/earthquake) tremors in one hour in [Bosnia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosnia) killed about 100 people in an area along the [Neretva River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neretva_River). While the death toll was initially believed to be 700 or more, the areas hit were sparsely populated and the loss of life was less than expected.

deaths.text: **Died: ** [Brooks Adams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooks_Adams), 78, American economic historian

events.text: In a 24-hour period, a winter storm dumped 11.82 meters (almost 38.78 feet) of snow on [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan)'s [Mount Ibuki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Ibuki) to set a new record for largest snowfall. The event broke the previous record of 8.18 m (26.84 ft) in the [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan)ese town of [Itakura](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Itakura,_Niigata), which had been set one day earlier.

[Conn Smythe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conn_Smythe) purchased the Toronto St. Patricks hockey team, preventing it from being moved to Philadelphia, and renamed it the [Toronto Maple Leafs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto_Maple_Leafs), after the Maple Leaf Regiment which fought for Canada in World War One. As the St. Pats, the team had lost 1 to 0, on the 13th, to the Ottawa Senators, and was in last place in its division at 8-18-4.  With a new name, the Maple Leafs played their first game on the 15th in Windsor, Ontario, and lost to the Detroit Cougars (which would in 1932 be renamed the [Detroit Red Wings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit_Red_Wings)), 5 to 1.

Boxer Jimmy Delaney defeated future light heavyweight boxing champion [Maxie Rosenbloom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxie_Rosenbloom) in a bout in Cincinnati, but splintered a bone in his left elbow in the process. After a loss the next week to Benny Ross, Delaney sought medical treatment, but would die of blood poisoning from an infection on March 4.

births.text: [Lois Maxwell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lois_Maxwell), Canadian film actress who portrayed "[Miss Moneypenny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miss_Moneypenny)" in 14 James Bond films; in [Kitchener, Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kitchener,_Ontario); (d. 2007)

deaths.text: William Gemmell, former horse racer, after jumping from this 5th floor hotel room in Butte, Montana to escape a fire
William Vanderbilt, 70, dynamite expert, by suicide

events.text: [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California) was struck by the worst storm in that state's history, up to that time, as hurricane force winds and torrential rains killed 24 people. Thirteen of the dead had been employees of [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California) Edison Company, killed when an avalanche buried their homes in the Sierra Nevada mountains.

For the first time in half a century, travel across the [English Channel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_Channel) came to a halt, as a dense fog in England continued into its fifth day. "Many veteran channel-commuters simply refused to believe it", noted one account.  "It had never occurred to them that such a time would come to Britain, and they hounded passenger agents with comments and queries."

births.text: [Harvey Korman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvey_Korman), American comedian, in [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago) (d. 2008)

events.text: [Sir Oliver Lodge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_Oliver_Lodge) conducted an experiment in [telepathy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/telepathy) on [BBC Radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Radio), asking listeners to give their impressions as a team of people concentrated on images on a set of cards. Out of 24,659 responses, as many as 190 correctly noted that a two of clubs had been drawn, but, writes [Harry Price](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Price), "it is obvious that there was no evidence of anything but pure chance".

[Mao Zedong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mao_Zedong) delivered his "[Report on an Investigation of the Peasant Movement in Hunan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Report_on_an_Investigation_of_the_Peasant_Movement_in_Hunan)" to the Central Committee of China's fledgling Communist Party. Summing up 32 days of interviews, Mao predicted "Within a short time, hundreds of millions of peasants will rise in Central, South, and North China, with the fury of a hurricane; no power, however strong, can restrain them."

births.text: [June Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/June_Brown), British TV soap opera actress (Dot Cotton on *EastEnders*), in [Needham Market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Needham_Market), [Suffolk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suffolk) (d 2022)

events.text: Turkey and U.S. re-established diplomatic relations, which had been severed April 20, 1917, after the two nations were on opposite sides of World War One.

sources: [U.S. Embassy in Turkey](http://turkey.usembassy.gov/us_diplomatic_interaction_turkey.html)

events.text: By voice vote, the [United States Senate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate) passed the White-Dill bill, the [Radio Act of 1927](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_Act_of_1927). President Coolidge signed the measure into law five days later, creating what is now the [Federal Communications Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission).

Diplomatic relations [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada) and [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States) formally began as U.S. President Coolidge received the credentials of Charles Vincent Massey, first Canadian Minister to the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States), in a half-hour ceremony at the White House. Prior to 1927, American relations concerning [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada) were conducted through the United Kingdom.

births.text: [John Warner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Warner), United States Senator (R-Virginia) from 1979 to 2009, and one-time husband of [Elizabeth Taylor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth_Taylor); in [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C.) (d. 2021)

events.text: "[Dry ice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dry_ice)", it was announced by the [American Chemical Society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Chemical_Society) in a press conference in New York, would become available worldwide as the result of the perfection, by of a process that "converts solid [carbon dioxide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/carbon_dioxide) into a practical portable 'ice'" "Synthetic 'Dry Ice' Is Invented As Shipment Aid".  The mass production of "frozen CO2", which "melted" more slowly than frozen water, was a milestone in transporting perishable foods, because far less of it was required—1,200 pounds of dry ice could replace 17,000 pounds of regular ice and 1,700 pounds of salt, freeing up more space for products.

Radio station [CFRB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CFRB) began broadcasting in [Toronto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto) as the first station in the world to rely on alternating current (AC) rather than direct current (DC).
The romantic comedy film *[It](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/It_(1927_film))* was released, starring [Clara Bow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clara_Bow) in the role that made her a major star.

births.text: [Ernest Trova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernest_Trova), American pop art sculptor, in [Clayton, Missouri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clayton,_Missouri) (d. 2009)

events.text: The [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States) increased the number of troops committed to [Nicaragua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicaragua), as 800 U.S. Marines arrived at [Corinto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corinto,_Nicaragua), half of a group of 1,600 that had been mobilized three days earlier. Within the week, the American grew fivefold, from 400 to 2,000.

births.text: [Sidney Poitier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidney_Poitier), African-American film actor and director; in [Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami) (d. 2022)
[Roy Cohn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Cohn), American prosecutor during McCarthy Era; in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City) (d.1986)
[Ibrahim Ferrer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibrahim_Ferrer), Cuban singer; in [San Luis, Santiago de Cuba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Luis,_Santiago_de_Cuba) (d. 2005)
[Hubert de Givenchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_de_Givenchy), French fashion designer, in [Beauvais](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beauvais) (d. 2018)

events.text: [Nicaragua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicaragua)'s President [Adolfo Díaz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolfo_Díaz) asked that his nation become a [protectorate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/protectorate) of the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States), and proposed to sign a 100-year treaty to allow American troops to occupy the Central American nation.  President Coolidge declined to take the offer seriously, but U.S. troops remained in [Nicaragua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicaragua) until 1933.

In its decision in [Farrington v. Tokushige](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farrington_v._Tokushige), the United States Supreme Court invalidated, as unconstitutional, a law in Hawaii that required schools to receive a license from the state before they could teach any languages other than [English](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language).

The city of West [Vernon, Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vernon,_Texas), was incorporated. It existed until 1944, when it was annexed into [Vernon, Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vernon,_Texas).

births.text: [Erma Bombeck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erma_Bombeck), American humorist and newspaper columnist (*At Wit's End*), in [Bellbrook, Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellbrook,_Ohio) (d. 1996)

events.text: The Italian team of Lt. Col. [Francesco de Pinedo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francesco_de_Pinedo) and Lt. Col. Carlo del Prete, flew their airplane in a successful [transatlantic flight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/transatlantic_flight) across the [South Atlantic Ocean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Atlantic_Ocean), from [Porto Praya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porto_Praya) in the [Cape Verde Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cape_Verde_Islands), to [Port Natal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_Natal), [Brazil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazil), a distance of 1433 mi.  The distance was slightly more than one third of the 3624 mi distance between [New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City) and [Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris), subject of the [Orteig Prize](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orteig_Prize), which would be awarded for the first transatlantic crossing between two continents.

[Werner Heisenberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Werner_Heisenberg) wrote a 14-page letter to fellow physicist [Wolfgang Pauli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolfgang_Pauli), describing for the first time a key concept in [quantum mechanics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/quantum_mechanics) that would become known as the [Heisenberg uncertainty principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heisenberg_uncertainty_principle).
The [Radio Act of 1927](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_Act_of_1927) was signed into law by U.S. President Coolidge.

births.text: [Régine Crespin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Régine_Crespin), French opera soprano, in [Marseille](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marseille) (d. 2007)

events.text: The [Fox Film Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Film_Corporation) gave its first demonstration of the process that it would use for a new feature, [Movietone News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Movietone_News), that would allow filmgoers to see *and* hear scenes from recent events. Fifty reporters were escorted into Fox-Case's New York studios at 10:00 that morning *and* filmed.  Four hours later, the same group saw *and* heard themselves when the film of the press conference was screened.

deaths.text: **Died: ** [William Fuld](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Fuld), 56, inventor of the [Ouija Board](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ouija_Board), after falling from the roof of a three-story building.

events.text: The [McFadden Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McFadden_Act) was signed into law by U.S. President Coolidge, prohibiting commercial banks from establishing branches in more than one state. The act would not be completely repealed until [1994](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1994), when the Riegle-Neal Act was passed.

On the same day, President Coolidge vetoed the [McNary–Haugen Farm Relief Bill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McNary–Haugen_Farm_Relief_Bill), which had passed the Senate 47-39, and the House of Representatives 214-178. Congress failed to override the veto, as well as being unable to overcome a second veto of a new version in 1928.  Domestic farm price supports would become law in 1933.

Instant communication between [San Francisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco) and [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London) (and by extension, the Western United States and Europe), was first achieved at 7:30 am Pacific time and 3:30 pm GMT. H.D. Pillsbury of Pacific Telephone and Telegraph spoke to Col. H.E. Shreeve, an AT&T representative 7287 mi away in Britain.  In 1915, the two men had spoken during the first phone conversation between [San Francisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco) and New York.  "The inauguration of this service", noted one account, "completes the final tie-up in trans-atlantic radio telephone service between the entire United States and England, Scotland and Wales."

births.text: [Mark Lane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Lane_(author)), American lawyer and author who challenged the Warren Commission findings on the Kennedy assassination, in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City) (d. 2016)

[Tom Kennedy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Kennedy_(television_presenter)), American TV game show host (*Name That Tune*); as James Narz in [Louisville, Kentucky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louisville,_Kentucky) (d. 2020)

events.text: In what one author described as "a milestone in the evolution of Afro-Asian solidarity", the first [Congress of Oppressed Nationalists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_against_Imperialism) opened in [Brussels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brussels). Among the delegates who would one day lead their people to independence were [Jawaharlal Nehru](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru) (India), [Ho Chi Minh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh) (Vietnam), [Mohammed Hatta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammed_Hatta) (Indonesia) and [Léopold Sédar Senghor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Léopold_Sédar_Senghor) (Senegal).

[Charles Lindbergh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Lindbergh) arrived at the factory of [Ryan Airlines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Airline_Company) in [San Diego](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Diego), placed the order for the construction of what would become one of the most famous airplanes in history, the *[Spirit of St. Louis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spirit_of_St._Louis)*, then remained in the city during the craft's construction.

Communists staged a [failed coup attempt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_[Estonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estonia)n_coup_d'état_attempt) in [Estonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estonia).

The drama film *[Romola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romola_(film))*, starring [Lillian Gish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lillian_Gish), premiered at [George M. Cohan's Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_M._Cohan's_Theatre) in New York City.

[Boston Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Arena) hosted the first [National Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hockey_League) game ever held on American soil when the [Boston Bruins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Bruins) defeated the visiting [Montreal Maroons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montreal_Maroons), 2 to 1, as both played their first games in franchise history. [Smokey Harris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smokey_Harris) scored the first-ever Bruins goal.

The musical *[Lady, Be Good](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lady,_Be_Good_(musical))*, with music by [George](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Gershwin) and lyrics by [Ira Gershwin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ira_Gershwin), opened at the [Liberty Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberty_Theatre) on Broadway.

events.text: U.S. president [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) delivered his 2nd [State of the Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_the_Union) message to the [United States Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress). Unlike in 1923, Coolidge delivered a written address instead of giving a speech. The message stated that the present state of the Union "may be regarded with encouragement and satisfaction by every American."

events.text: [Ibn Saud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibn_Saud) entered [Mecca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mecca) in [ihram clothing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ihram_clothing) and performed the [umrah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/umrah).
[Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) introduced a bill enforcing widespread press censorship.

A first [Woolworths Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woolworths_Group_(Australia)) [department store](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/department_store) open in downtown [Sydney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney), as predecessor name was Woolworths Stupendous Bargain Basement.

events.text: France rounded up over 300 communists in raids on their headquarters, including some 70 of foreign nationality that were to be deported. "There are too many foreign communists in France who forget their duty to the country that has given them asylum", Prime Minister [Édouard Herriot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Édouard_Herriot) told the [Chamber of Deputies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(France)). "They are indulging in political demonstrations, and we will not tolerate it, we will not let them meddle in our political life. If we meet with resistance we will break it, and we will deport as many as necessary."

events.text: The Supreme Court of Hungary confiscated the property of former president [Mihály Károlyi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mihály_Károlyi) for high treason. Károlyi was convicted of negotiating with Italy in 1915 to keep the Italians out of the war in exchange for Austrian territory, and for allowing a [communist revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_Soviet_Republic) to happen in 1919 by deserting his position.

events.text: Seven of the eight teams in baseball's [American League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_League) presented a resolution to commissioner [Kenesaw Mountain Landis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenesaw_Mountain_Landis) saying that the "misconduct" of League president [Ban Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ban_Johnson) would cease, "or his immediate removal from office will follow." The resolution also declared "that legislation will be adopted that will limit his activities to the internal affairs of the American league." [Phil Ball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phil_Ball_(baseball)) of the [St. Louis Browns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_St._Louis_Browns) was the only team owner who did not sign the resolution.
The football club [Associação Atlética Portuguesa (RJ)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associação_Atlética_Portuguesa_(RJ)) was founded in Brazil.

births.text: [Margaret Wigiser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Wigiser), baseball player, in [Brooklyn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn), [New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_(state)) (d. 2019)

events.text: [Pope Pius XI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI) made his first statement against communism after an abandoned pontifical relief mission returned from Russia. He said the Vatican would continue to make efforts to help needy Russians, but "nobody certainly can have thought by our efforts on behalf of the Russian people we intended in any way to lend our support to a system of government which we are so far from approving."

sources: Pope in Bitter Denouncement of Communism - December 19, 1924, p. 5

He returned to his small [Munich apartment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolf_Hitler's_Munich_apartment) where his friends threw him a party.
[Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) presented legislation repealing the much-criticized [Acerbo Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acerbo_Law).

events.text: An [interallied](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I) military committee headed by [Ferdinand Foch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_Foch) decided that troops would not withdraw from the [Cologne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cologne) area on January 10, 1925, as specified in the [Treaty of Versailles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles), because Germany had not fulfilled its disarmament provisions. Angry articles in the German press accused the Allies of breaking the [Dawes Pact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan).

sources: 'Stay on Rhine,' Foch Order - December 23, 1924, p. 1, Author: Henry Wales

German president [Friedrich Ebert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert) lost a libel trial in [Magdeburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magdeburg). Newspaper editor Erwin Rothart was sentenced to three months in prison for insulting the president, but his accusation that Ebert had betrayed the country for leading a strike in 1918 was ruled as proven.

[Albanian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania) Prime Minister [Fan Noli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fan_S._Noli) and his ministers fled [Tirana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tirana) as rebel forces led by the deposed leader [Ahmet Zogu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zog_I_of_Albania) approached the city.

[Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania) was declared a republic as [Ahmet Zogu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zog_I_of_Albania) entered [Tirana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tirana) without resistance, reclaiming leadership of the country and completing the overthrow of [Fan Noli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fan_S._Noli)'s government.

Eight people died in an [Imperial Airways de Havilland DH.34 crash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Imperial_Airways_de_Havilland_DH.34_crash), seconds after taking off from [Croydon Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croydon_Airport). It was Britain's worst air disaster to date.

The [Babbs Switch fire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Babbs_Switch_fire) killed thirty-six people in a one-room school house at [Babbs Switch, Oklahoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Babbs_Switch,_Oklahoma).

events.text: An editorial written by the estranged Fascist politician [Cesare Rossi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesare_Rossi_(politician)) ran in [Giovanni Amendola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Amendola)'s newspaper *[Il Mondo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Il_Mondo_(newspaper))*, simultaneously published in other opposition papers. In it, Rossi claimed that [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) had directly ordered the Fascists to carry out several crimes.

During a transfer of 10.5 tonnes [dynamite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/dynamite) from a [cargo ship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cargo) to [freight car](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/freight_car), there was an explosion in Temiya railway station, [Otaru](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otaru), [Hokkaido](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hokkaido), Japan, 94 persons were killed and more than 300 persons were hurt, according to a Japanese government official document figured report.

sources: Italian Premier is Accused of Fascist Crimes - December 28, 1924, p. 12, Author: John Storer
My Fault: Mussolini As I Knew Him - 2014, Publisher: Enigma Books, ISBN: 978-1-936274-40-6, Author: Margherita Sarfatti

events.text: A [general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honduran_general_election,_1924) was conducted in [Honduras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honduras). [Miguel Paz Barahona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miguel_Paz_Barahona) of the conservative [National Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Party_of_Honduras) was elected president virtually unopposed, as liberals boycotted the election.

With Franco-German tensions high over the issue of the occupation of [Cologne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cologne), a sensational report was published in Paris claiming that German scientists had secretly developed a new and devastating poison gas that could annihilate a whole city in a matter of hours.

sources: The History of Honduras - 2011, p. 100, Publisher: Greenwood, ISBN: 978-0-313-36304-7, Author: Thomas M. Leonard

[Kid McCoy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kid_McCoy) was found guilty of manslaughter in the August 12 death of his live-in mistress.

events.text: [Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) called an unexpected cabinet meeting and requested a show of support from all present, which he received from a majority. The two Liberal ministers in [Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini)'s cabinet were convinced to withdraw their resignations.

German Foreign Minister [Gustav Stresemann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustav_Stresemann) told international media that peace in Europe and fulfillment of the [Dawes Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan) were in danger unless a compromise was reached on the [Cologne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cologne) evacuation issue.

sources: Mussolini Leaps Fresh Obstacle; Saves Cabinet - December 31, 1924, p. 7

events.text: Thirty-three [Blackshirt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milizia_Volontaria_per_la_Sicurezza_Nazionale) consuls arrived unannounced in Mussolini's office, demanding that Mussolini crush the opposition or they would do so without him.

Italian police were ordered to search the houses of prominent opposition leaders over allegations that enemies of the government had stockpiled vast stores of arms. Issues of opposition newspapers in several Italian cities were seized, with [Florence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence) becoming especially violent as thousands of Blackshirts converged on the city and ransacked several buildings, including the printing plant of an opposition newspaper which was set on fire.

Three of four brothers in the Barmat family of merchants were arrested as the industrial corruption scandal known as the [Barmat scandal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barmat_scandal) broke in Germany. One report claimed that President [Friedrich Ebert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert)'s son ["Fritz"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert,_Jr.) was connected to the scandal.
