events.text: The verdicts in the [Beer Hall Putsch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beer_Hall_Putsch) trial were announced. [Adolf Hitler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolf_Hitler), [Ernst Pöhner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Pöhner), [Hermann Kriebel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermann_Kriebel) and [Friedrich Weber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Weber_(veterinarian)) were all found guilty of treason and sentenced to five years in prison, with a chance of parole in six months. [Erich Ludendorff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erich_Ludendorff) was acquitted. Hitler was taken to [Landsberg Prison](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landsberg_Prison) and given a large and comfortable room with a fine view.

[Northern Rhodesia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Rhodesia) (now [Zambia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zambia)) became a British [protectorate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/protectorate) after having been administered by a private corporation, the [British South Africa Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_South_Africa_Company). British colonial administrator [Herbert Stanley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Stanley) became the [protectorate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/protectorate)'s first Governor and took office in the [Northern Rhodesia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Rhodesia)n capital, [Livingstone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Livingstone,_Zambia).

The [Royal [Canadian Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Air_Force_(1920–1924))](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Air_Force), an all-military force was activated by royal assent from King George V, after having being created as the [Canadian Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Air_Force_(1920–1924)) in 1920 to operate both military and civilian flights.

births.text: [Brendan Byrne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brendan_Byrne), U.S. politician and Governor of New Jersey from 1974 to 1982; in [West Orange, New Jersey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Orange,_New_Jersey) (d. 2018)

deaths.text: [Frank Capone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Capone), 28, U.S. mobster and older brother of [Al Capone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Capone), was shot by police in Chicago police a gun battle.
[Clinton Burns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinton_Sumner_Burns), 52, American engineer and designer of municipal water systems across the United States

events.text: A huge monarchist demonstration was staged in Berlin on the occasion of the funeral for martyred criminal Wilhelm Dreyer, a German who died in a French prison after dynamiting a train in the [Ruhr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruhr). Police struggled to prevent an unauthorized parade from forming in the wake of Dreyer's casket procession.

On the [Red Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Sea), the British cruise ship **Clan McIver** rescued more than 1,200 passengers, almost all of the Muslim pilgrims on their way to [Mecca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mecca), from the British steamship SS *Frangestan*, a freighter which had caught fire after the ignition of its cargo of cotton. **Clan McIver** then delivered the 1,200 pilgrims to [Port Sudan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_Sudan)

U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) nominated [Harlan Fiske Stone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harlan_F._Stone) to be the new Attorney General of the United States, to replace [Harry M. Daugherty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_M._Daugherty), who had been fired by Coolidge on March 28. Stone Was confirmed by voice vote in the U.S. Senate on April 7.
The Italian government announced it was studying measures to take against [Romania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romania) over its failure to pay its debts to Italy.

The outlawing of the [Bulgarian Communist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulgarian_Communist_Party), in the aftermath of the [September Uprising](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_Uprising) that attempted to overthrow the Bulgarian government in 1923, was upheld by the Eastern European nation's [Supreme Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Cassation_of_Bulgaria).

births.text: [Bobby Ávila](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bobby_Ávila), Mexican-born baseball player, 1954 American League batting champion and Player of the Year, later the mayor of [Veracruz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veracruz_(city)) and president of the [Mexican League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexican_League); in [Veracruz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veracruz_(city)) (d. 2004)

events.text: The [Irish Free State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Free_State) issued its own passports for the first time, after being unable to reach a compromise with the British government over whether to refer to an Irish citizen as a "British subject."

In [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italy), the [Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) government demanded 80 million gold lire from [Romania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romania) to square its debts within several days, stationing several Italian warships off the port of [Constanța](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constanța) to back up the ultimatum.

By a vote of 408 to 151, the French Chamber of Deputies voted its confidence in the new government of Prime Minister [Raymond Poincare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Poincare), who had threatened to resign and made the vote a test of whether France should accept a reduction of the German reparation payments.
In [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago), 24-year-old [Beulah Annan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beulah_Annan) shot the man with whom she had been having an affair in her apartment.

African-American and Russian stage actress and opera singer [Coretti Arle-Titz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coretti_Arle-Titz) made her debut at the [Bolshoi Theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolshoi_Theater) in [Moscow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moscow).

[Betsy Plank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betsy_Plank), American [public relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/public_relations) woman; in [Tuscaloosa, Alabama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuscaloosa,_Alabama) (d. 2010)

events.text: Educational broadcast media began with the initial broadcast of the first educational radio program, now called *[BBC School Radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_School_Radio)*, transmitted during school hours in [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London) by station [2LO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2LO) on the 860 kHz AM radio frequency.
An extravagant funeral for slain mobster [Frank Capone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Capone) was held in Chicago.

The [Galeries Lafayette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galeries_Lafayette) department store in [Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris) negotiated with fashion designer [Coco Chanel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coco_Chanel) and bought the exclusive rights to what would become the most famous [perfume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/perfume) in the world, [Chanel No. 5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chanel_No._5), and became the worldwide distributor of the fragrance.

births.text: [Gil Hodges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gil_Hodges), American baseball player and 3-time Gold Glove Award winner, later the manager of the [New York Mets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Mets) during their 1969 World Series championship, inducted into the [Baseball Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Baseball_Hall_of_Fame_and_Museum), 2022; in [Princeton, Indiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princeton,_Indiana) (died of a heart attack, 1972)

[Noreen Nash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noreen_Nash) (stage name for Norabelle Roth), American film and TV actress; in [Wenatchee, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wenatchee,_Washington) (d. 2023)

[Joye Hummel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joye_Hummel), American comic book author known for ghost-writing the *[Wonder Woman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wonder_Woman_(comic_book))* series during the 1940s (d.2021)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Joseph Willard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Edward_Willard), 58, American diplomat, U.S. Ambassador to Spain 1913 to 1921, died suddenly from an attack of [angina pectoris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/angina_pectoris).

events.text: In the town of [Lilly, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lilly,_Pennsylvania), members of the [Ku Klux Klan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan) shot 22 people, two of them fatally, firing randomly into a crowd at the town's railroad station. The shooting happened after some residents of the town "played a stream of water from the town fire hose upon the visitors as they were marching back to the station." An estimated 500 Klansmen had arrived, uninvited, to Lilly and held a ceremony at a nearby field, then marched in a procession to the train, which was taking them to nearby [Johnstown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnstown,_Pennsylvania). After the train arrived at [Johnstown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnstown,_Pennsylvania), the Klansmen were met by more than 50 police officers, who arrested 25 of the Klan members and confiscated fifty guns. Four additional people, residents of Lilly, were arrested the next day and the 29 were charged with murder.

The [University of Cambridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Cambridge) rowing team won the 76th annual [Boat Race](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Boat_Race_1924) along the [River Thames](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/River_Thames).

sources: Four Are Slain, 13 Shot During Visit of Klan— Residents of Pennsylvania Town Attacked After Using Hose - April 6, 1924, p. 1
25 Arrested When Train Returns to Johnstown - April 6, 1924, p. 1
29 in Klan Riot to Be Charged With Murder - April 7, 1924, p. 1

events.text: [Voting was held in Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Italian_general_election) for all 535 seats of the [Camera dei deputati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Kingdom_of_Italy)). The [Lista Nazionale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_List_(Italy)), (a coalition headed by [National Fascist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Fascist_Party) leader [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini), received 65% of the votes and 374 of the seats in Parliament (74%) in accordance with the [Acerbo Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acerbo_Law), which provided that whatever party received more than 25% of the vote and the most votes overall would automatically be awarded two-thirds of the seats. The PPI party of [Alcide De Gasperi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcide_De_Gasperi), who would become Prime Minister of Italy after World War II, received the second most votes (9%) and dropped from 108 seats to only 39.

In the U.S. city of [Seattle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle), [Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_(state)), a team of aviators with four specially built [Douglas World Cruiser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_World_Cruiser) airplanes began their quest to be the first to [fly all the way around the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation). [Lowell Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lowell_Smith) was one of the pilots.

births.text: [Jimmy Roberts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Roberts_(singer)), American singer known for *[The Lawrence Welk Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lawrence_Welk_Show)*; in [Madisonville, Kentucky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madisonville,_Kentucky) (d. 1999)

events.text: [Ramsay MacDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald)'s [Labour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)) government suffered its first defeat in the British House of Commons when it failed to pass, by a margin of 212 to 221, a bill introduced by [John Wheatley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Wheatley) that would have protected unemployed people from being evicted over inability to pay rent.

births.text: [Stanislaw Trepczynski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanislaw_Trepczynski), Polish diplomat who served as [President of the United Nations General Assembly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly) from 1972 to 1973; in [Łódź](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Łódź) (d.2002)

events.text: On recommendation of Prime Minister [Mustafa Kemal Atatürk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atatürk), [Sharia courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharia) were abolished by vote of the [Grand National Assembly of Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey), and the Islamic law judges ([Qadis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qadi)) were dismissed.

British inventor [Harry Grindell Matthews](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Grindell_Matthews) made a laboratory demonstration to reporters of his "death ray" that could, he said, disable aircraft engines, explode ammunition dumps, render firearms useless and injure entire armies from a great distance..

France delivered 13 tons of gold ingots, worth US$6.5 million at the time, to English officers in the port city of [Calais](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calais) as part of France's efforts to stabilize the nation's currency, the [franc](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_franc).

events.text: The committee headed by [Charles G. Dawes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_G._Dawes) submitted its [plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan) to reorganize the German economy and for the Allies to restructure the method of [reparations payments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I_reparations). Among the changes were that while the Allies would retain military rights in occupied territory, Germany would retain control of its railways and industries, with some Allied supervision, and Germans would pay taxes similar to the rates of other nations. Payments would be adjusted upward or downward "according to an index of prosperity", with a neutral American observer being the judge of Germany's capacity to pay.

[Pope Pius XI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI) abruptly canceled plans to become the first Roman Catholic Pontiff since [1870](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1870) to travel outside of Vatican City. The Pope had been scheduled to one-half mile out of the walls of the Vatican and into [Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rome) in order to dedicate the new building for the [Knights of Columbus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knights_of_Columbus), but decided, after banner headlines in papers in [Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rome) and around the world to remain "a voluntary prisoner" inside the Vatican. His decision came 30 minutes before he was due to arrive. Appearing in his place was the Papal Secretary of State, Cardinal Gasparri.

The U.S. state of [Mississippi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mississippi) authorized the creation of Delta State Teachers College, now [Delta State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delta_State_University), to be built in Cleveland, [Mississippi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mississippi), with the signing of legislation by Governor [Henry L. Whitfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_L._Whitfield).

Apt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milburn_G._Apt), U.S. Air Force test pilot who was the first person to exceed [Mach 3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mach_number), but was killed in the attempt; in [Buffalo, Kansas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo,_Kansas) (d. 1956)

[Elizabeth Weisburger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth_Weisburger), American cancer researcher and chemist; in [Finland, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finland,_Pennsylvania) (d.2019)

events.text: The first large-scale train robbery in Greece took place shortly after 12 masked and armed bandits boarded a train at the [Doxaras railway station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doxaras_railway_station) en route to Thessaloniki. Among the passengers were the Minister of Social Welfare and a former governor of Macedonia, and the bandits escaped with 400,000 [drachmas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_drachma) of cash and valuables. The bandits apparently had been planning to board a train scheduled to carry Prime Minister Alexandros Papanastasiou, but Papanastasiou's train had not arrived at the time that the other train departed.

King [Ferdinand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_I_of_Romania) and Queen [Marie of Romania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marie_of_Romania) arrived in Paris on a royal visit. Though officially only a friendly visit, it was widely believed that Romania was seeking an alliance with France due to unfriendly relations with Russia, Spain and Italy.
The [Dawes Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan) committee urged all nations concerned to enact the plan quickly before conditions in Germany changed.

The [Des Moines, Iowa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Des_Moines,_Iowa) radio station [WHO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WHO_(AM)) began broadcasting as one of the "[clear-channel station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/clear-channel_station)" permitted to operate 24 hours a day.

births.text: [K Lal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K_Lal) (stage name for Kantilal Girdharilal Vora), Indian musician who performed for 62 years until two months before his death; in Mavjhinjhva, [Baroda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baroda_State) principality (now [Gujarat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarat)), [British India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_India) (d. 2012)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Hugo Stinnes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugo_Stinnes), 54, German industrialist and politician who was the wealthiest man in Germany after World War One until his death, died a month after [gall bladder surgery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/cholecystectomy).

Allies Advised to Act Quickly on Dawes Plan - April 11, 1924, p. 5, Author: Henry Wales
Hugo Stinnes, Richest Man in Germany, Dies - _Chicago Daily Tribune_, April 11, 1924, p. 1

events.text: [Voting was held in Denmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Danish_[Folketing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folketing)_election) for all 149 seats of the [Folketing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folketing), the European nation's unicameral parliament. [Thorvald Stauning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thorvald_Stauning)'s [Socialdemokratiet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democrats_(Denmark)) party won a plurality of the seats, gaining seven to change the balance of power from 51 to 48 for the liberal [Venstre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venstre_(Denmark)) party (led by Prime Minister [Niels Neergaard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niels_Neergaard), to a 55 to 44 lead by the Social Democrats. Stauning would form a coalition government on April 23.

Japan's Ambassador to the United States, [Masanao Hanihara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masanao_Hanihara), had a letter presented to U.S. Secretary of State [Charles Evans Hughes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Evans_Hughes), warning him of "the grave consequences" that would come if the U.S. Senate followed the House of Representatives in passing the [Immigration Act of 1924](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immigration_Act_of_1924), specifically targeted against Asian nations, refusing to increase the quota of Japanese citizens who would be allowed to immigrate to the United States. Hughes transmitted the note to the Chairman of the Senate Immigration Committee, [LeBaron B. Colt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LeBaron_B._Colt). On April 19, the U.S. Senate voted, 62 to 6, to pass the bill.

At 6:00 in the morning, the U.S. state of [Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona) closed its border with the state of [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California), barring all automobile traffic at the two entry points, Yuma, [Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona) and Needles, [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California). Before the enactment of the border closing, all vehicles entering from [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California) were disinfected, at the travelers' expense, as part of a [quarantine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/quarantine) to prevent an outbreak of [hoof-and-mouth disease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foot-and-mouth_disease).

A crowd of 4,000 Germans at a concert staged a pro-monarchist demonstration in [Breslau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wrocław) in favor of having the former heir to the German throne, [Crown Prince Wilhelm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm,_German_Crown_Prince), to return to Germany as Kaiser Wilhelm III.
The German Association of Industry released a statement expressing approval of the [Dawes Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan).

[Sigma Phi Delta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sigma_Phi_Delta), a professional fraternity of male engineering students, was founded at the University of Southern California. It has 25 chapters, and is limited to men in [ABET](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABET)-accredited colleges of engineering.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Karl Oenike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_Oenike), 62, German landscape painter and photographer known for his detailed information of locations in [South America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_America).

events.text: A scandal broke within the U.S. Navy after a radio operator discovered that members of the crew of the battleship USS *Arizona* (which would be sunk at Pearl Harbor in 1941) had helped an American [prostitute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/prostitution), [Madeline Blair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madeline_Blair), [stow away](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/stowaway) when the ship was anchored at New York City. Miss Blair, who had told sailors on [shore leave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/shore_leave) that she didn't have enough money to travel to California in hopes of becoming a [Hollywood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollywood,_Los_Angeles) actress, was found after the ship had passed through the [[Panama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama) Canal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Panama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama)_Canal) and was anchored off of the coast of [Panama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama) at [Balboa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balboa,_Panama). The ship's captain instigated the [courts-martial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/courts-martial) of 23 enlisted men. Blair would publish her story in *[The San Francisco Examiner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_San_Francisco_Examiner)* in 1928.

[Charles G. Dawes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_G._Dawes) visited Rome and met with [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini), who expressed his support for the reparations plan.
The U.S. House of Representatives Voted, 322 to 71, to pass the Japanese Exclusion Act.

France's Prime Minister Raymond Poincare announced the dissolution of the French National Assembly and President [Alexandre Millerand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandre_Millerand) signed the decree, [setting new elections for May 11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_French_legislative_election).

The first international soccer football game at [Wembley Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_(1923)) was played between [England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England_national_football_team) and [Scotland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team), ending in 1 to 1 draw, with [Billy Walker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billy_Walker_(footballer,_born_1897)) of [England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England_national_football_team) scoring the first goal.

Based in Chicago, [WLS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WLS_(AM)), one of the major AM radio stations in the U.S., went on the air for the first time after being purchased by the Sears, Roebuck and Company department store chain and catalog merchant. The station changed its name from WBBX to [WLS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WLS_(AM)) to reflect that it was broadcasting for the "World's Largest Store."

events.text: A [Voters in Greece overwhelmingly voted to abolish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Greek_republic_referendum) the [monarchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/monarchy) and to endorse the [Second Hellenic Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Hellenic_Republic) that had been proclaimed by parliament, subject to public approval, on March 25. Out of more than one million people who cast votes, over 758,000 opted in favor of a republic with [Pavlos Kountouriotis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pavlos_Kountouriotis) as president. Only 325,000 supporting the return of [King George II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_II_of_Greece) to the throne.

[Olympique de Marseille](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympique_de_Marseille) defeated [FC Sète 34](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FC_Sète_34), 3 to 2, in extra time to win the [Coupe de France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Coupe_de_France_final), the knockout tournament for the championship of French soccer football.

events.text: *[The Japan Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Japan_Times)* called for a boycott of [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California) if the United States passed the [Immigration Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immigration_Act_of_1924), putting the blame for the bill on that state.

France's Prime Minister Poincare, in his speech to open his campaign in the May elections for parliament, indicated "in his own peculiar way" that his government would accept the Dawes Plan for restructuring reparations. Poincare told his audience, "There can't be a question of retiring from the Ruhr until Germany pays us what is due us," and that he would reoccupy the Ruhr again if necessary.

Mayer Pictures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_B._Mayer_Pictures) were merged by [Marcus Loew](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcus_Loew) to create the [Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer) (MGM) film studio.
Japanese businesses began canceling orders from the United States in protest against the immigration bill.

The [All-India [Yadav](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yadav) Mahasabha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All-India_[Yadav](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yadav)_Mahasabha) was formed to promote equal treatment of and rights for [Yadav](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yadav) people, those from India's poorest [castes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caste_system_in_India).

An accidentally-started fire destroyed most of the town of [Franklin, West Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin,_West_Virginia), after breaking out at *[Pendleton Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pendleton_Times)* newspaper. The printing press had stopped when its engine ran out of fuel, and the operator failed to wait for the machine to cool down before pouring gasoline into its tank.

events.text: The Plaza Publishing Company, which would become [Simon & Schuster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_&_Schuster), the new publishing company that had been founded on January 2, released *The Cross Word Puzzle Book*, the first book of [crossword puzzles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/crossword_puzzle) ever published. Although the crossword had been invented in 1913 and the puzzles were a feature in daily newspapers, the book compiled "50 Brand New Puzzles". Retailing at $1.35 per copy and included an attached pencil, becoming a popular bestseller.

Argentine aviator [Raúl Pateras Pescara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raúl_Pateras_Pescara) set a new world record by flying a helicopter almost half a mile— 2415 ft— at an average height of 6 feet (1.8 meters).

A group of 700 frustrated drivers from California attempted to break through Arizona's quarantine closure of the border at [Yuma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuma,_Arizona), before being stopped by troops of the Arizona National Guard. After speeding past guards on the bridge over the [Colorado River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colorado_River), drivers who made it into Arizona were forced to retreat back to California after encountering a cordon of guards who used fire hoses to repulse vehicle that tried to drive further.

A fire at Curran's Hall on 1363 Blue Island Avenue in [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago) killed seven firemen and injured 18 others, when the building collapsed and buried the firefighters, all of whom were members of Hook and Ladder Truck Company No. 12.

events.text: *[National Barn Dance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Barn_Dance)*, one of the first popular weekly radio shows, was introduced on the Chicago radio station [WLS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WLS_(AM)), running from 8 to 12 in the evening central time as an "old time fiddlers program" played by the Hotel Sherman orchestra. As a "[clear-channel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clear-channel_station)" broadcaster whose signal could be heard at 870 kHz on AM radio, the [WLS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WLS_(AM)) program could in much of the North America and was soon licensed to other [clear-channel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clear-channel_station) stations. In 1933, *National Barn Chance* would be picked up by the [NBC Red Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_Radio_Network), before moving to the ABC Radio Network in 1946, and would remain a regular Saturday evening program until 1952.

events.text: In a luncheon address to the [[Associated Press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associated_Press)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associated_Press) in New York, U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) proposed an international disarmament conference along the lines of the one that produced the [Washington Naval Treaty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Naval_Treaty). After [[Associated Press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associated_Press)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associated_Press) president Frank B. Noyes introduced Coolidge with the story that a better a man who bet that he could "get more than two words" our of the president nicknamed "Silent Cal" and that Coolidge responded "You lose." Coolidge thanked Noyes and told the audience that the AP president "has given you a perfect example of one of those rumors now current in Washington which is without any foundation."

After having presented his plan for revision of German reparations in his trip to Europe, [Charles G. Dawes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_G._Dawes) departed for New York aboard the [SS Leviathan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Leviathan).

The Los Angeles suburb of [Signal Hill, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_Hill,_California) was incorporated three years after the discovery of the [Long Beach Oil Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_Beach_Oil_Field).

events.text: The [British Empire Exhibition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Empire_Exhibition) was opened at [Wembley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wembley) on [Saint George's Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint_George's_Day_in_England) as [King George V](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_V) made the first radio broadcast ever by a British monarch in the opening ceremonies. The King sent a telegram that was relayed by wireless through Canada, New Zealand, Australia, [South Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Africa), India, [Aden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aden), [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt), [Gibraltar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gibraltar) and back to London in 1 minute and 20 seconds.

The [Grand National Assembly of Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey) approved a list of "[150 personae non gratae of Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/150_personae_non_gratae_of_Turkey)", after narrowing a list of 600 Ottoman officials exiled from Turkey, to 150 *Yüzellilikler* ("150ers") who were forbidden from returning to the Turkish Republic, starting with former Sultan [Mehmed VI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mehmed_VI).

[Thorvald Stauning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thorvald_Stauning) formed a coalition government to become the new Prime Minister of Denmark, succeeding [Niels Neergaard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niels_Neergaard), whose party had lost control of the [Folketing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folketing) in the April 11 elections.

births.text: [Bobby Rosengarden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bobby_Rosengarden), American jazz drummer; in [Elgin, Illinois](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elgin,_Illinois) (d. 2007)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Karl Helfferich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_Helfferich), 51, German economist and former [Vice-Chancellor of the German Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice-Chancellor_of_Germany), was killed near [Bellinzona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellinzona) in [a train wreck in Switzerland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_rail_accidents_(1920–1929)) that claimed the lives of 14 other people.

sources: Imperial Fair Is Opened With Medieval Pomp— King George's Message Encircles Entire Globe In 80 Seconds - April 24, 1924, p. 1

events.text: [Thorvald Stauning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thorvald_Stauning) became the new [Prime Minister of Denmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Denmark), succeeding [Niels Neergaard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niels_Neergaard) after the [Socialdemokratiet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democrats_(Denmark)) party obtained a plurality of seats in the [April 11 elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Danish_Folketing_election) for the Folketing.

In [Leningrad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leningrad), hundreds of Russian Orthodox worshipers unsuccessfully attempted to stop police from confiscating religious icons from [Saint Andrew's Cathedral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint_Andrew's_Cathedral_(Saint_Petersburg)). As punishment, the Soviet government turned the cathedral over to the Soviet-sponsored [Renovationist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renovationism) Church that promoted a pro-Communist interpretation of Christianity.

Voters in the [Dallas County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas_County,_Texas) neighborhood of University Park, located adjacent to [Southern Methodist University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Methodist_University), voted overwhelmingly to incorporate as the city of [University Park, Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_Park,_Texas).

The Royal Dutch Airline, [KLM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KLM), had its first fatal accident when a [KLM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KLM) *[Fokker F.III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fokker_F.III)* airplane, carrying a pilot and two passengers, [vanished](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_KLM_Fokker_F.III_disappearance) shortly after takeoff from [Croydon Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croydon_Airport) in England on a flight to the [Waalhaven](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waalhaven), a suburb of [Rotterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotterdam) in the Netherlands. No trace of the plane was found the aircraft had apparently crashed in the [English Channel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_Channel).

events.text: Part 2 of the [Fritz Lang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fritz_Lang) fantasy film *[Die Nibelungen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Die_Nibelungen)* premiered at the [Ufa-Palast am Zoo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ufa-Palast_am_Zoo) in Berlin.

[Newcastle United](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newcastle_United_F.C.) beat [Aston Villa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aston_Villa_F.C.) 2–0 to win the [1924 FA Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_FA_Cup_Final).

The first performance of *Tzigane*, a rhapsody by French composer [Maurice Ravel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Ravel), took place at a premiere at the [Aeolian Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aeolian_Hall_([London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London))) in [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London).

[Warren T. McCray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warren_T._McCray), the incumbent Governor of the U.S. state of [Indiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana), was booked into the [Marion County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marion_County,_Indiana) Jail in [Indiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana)polis at 9:40 in the evening, after having been found guilty of attempted fraud by a U.S. federal court jury earlier in the day.

events.text: [Voting was held for white residents](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Southern_Rhodesian_general_election) of the British African colony of [Southern Rhodesia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Rhodesia) (now the [Republic of Zimbabwe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Zimbabwe)) for the first [elected colonial legislature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Rhodesia), the 30-member Legislative Assembly. The [Rhodesia Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Responsible_Government_Association), led by the Premier, [Sir Charles Coghlan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Coghlan_(politician)), won 26 of the seats, while independent candidates won the other four. The [Rhodesia Labour Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhodesia_Labour_Party) of Lawrence Keller lost in all 22 constituencies in which it had candidates.

[Philip Snowden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Snowden,_1st_Viscount_Snowden), the British [Chancellor of the Exchequer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chancellor_of_the_Exchequer), presented the [Labour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)) government's first budget.

births.text: [Svante Odén](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Svante_Odén), Swedish meteorologist who researched and publicized the causes of [acid rain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/acid_precipitation); in [Östermalm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Östermalm), [Stockholm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stockholm) (disappeared 1986)
[Shintaro Abe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shintaro_Abe), Japanese Foreign Minister 1982 to 1986; in [Tokyo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokyo) (d. 1991)
[Al Balding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Balding), Canadian golfer who was the first native of Canada to win a PGA event; in [Toronto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto) (d. 2006)
[Ann Flagg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ann_Flagg), African-American actress and playwright; in [Charleston, West Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charleston,_West_Virginia)

[Julian S. Carr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julian_S._Carr), 78, American businessman, philanthropist and white supremacist, former Commander-in-Chief of the United Confederate Veterans, died in Chicago after contracting influenza while traveling from his home in Durham, North Carolina.

[Dr. E. F. Nichols](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernest_Fox_Nichols), 54, American scientist and former president of Dartmouth College and of MIT, died in Washington D. C., while reading a research paper to an audience during dedication ceremonies for the new National Academy of Sciences headquarters.

events.text: An [outbreak of tornadoes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/April_1924_tornado_outbreak) killed 111 people across in five states in the southern U.S, with 76 deaths in [South Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Carolina), primarily in a storm that swept through [Richland County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richland_County,_South_Carolina) [Sumter County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sumter_County,_South_Carolina). Another 16 died in Georgia and 13 in Alabama.

[Warren T. McCray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warren_T._McCray) resigned as [Governor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_of_[Indiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana)) of the U.S. state of [Indiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana) after being convicted in a federal criminal trial for [mail fraud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/mail_fraud) and sentenced to 10 years in prison. McCray was succeeded by Lieutenant [Governor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_of_[Indiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indiana)) [Emmett Forest Branch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmett_Forest_Branch), to serve out the remaining 8½ months of McCray's term.

Over 10,000 people attended the funeral of slain Albanian nationalist figure [Avni Rustemi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avni_Rustemi) in [Vlorë](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vlorë). Bishop [Fan Noli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fan_S._Noli) gave a fiery speech which emboldened opposition against the government and led to the [June Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/June_Revolution).

An armed revolt broke out in [Cienfuegos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cienfuegos) in [Cuba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuba), under the leadership of General Laredo Bru in Santa Clara. Within two weeks, most of the rebels returned home after being offered amnesty by President Zayas.
Air mail service was inaugurated between [Liverpool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liverpool) in England and [Belfast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belfast) in Northern Ireland.

The lead plane in the [round-the-world flight attempt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation), *Seattle*, crashed in a dense fog near Port Moller, Alaska. The crew was rescued but declared they would never again fly in a plane made of lead.

events.text: The [Nixon Nitration Works disaster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Nixon_Nitration_Works_disaster), an explosion of [ammonium nitrate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ammonium_nitrate), killed at least 18 people, destroyed several miles of [New Jersey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Jersey) factories, and demolished the "tiny industrial town of Nixon, [New Jersey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Jersey)."

Public vehicles such as [taxicabs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/taxicab) were allowed into London's [Hyde Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London) for the first time since 1636, after the House of Commons had repealed the ban on motion by M.P. [Ben Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Smith_(Labour_politician)). The 1636 law had made [Hyde Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London) "reserved for people who kept their own carriages." Smith himself had been a taxicab driver prior to becoming an official in the Transport and General Workers' Union.

The [Communist Party of Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Germany) was legally reinstated. It had been banned in November 1923 after it tried to launch a [general strike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/general_strike).

*[Alice's Day at Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice's_Day_at_Sea)*, the first of 57 films in [Walt Disney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Disney)'s [Alice Comedies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_Comedies) series, was introduced to American cinemas as a short (11-minute) movie to be shown prior to a feature film. The silent film featured 5-year-old [Virginia Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_Davis) in a combination of live action and animation. An earlier Alice comedy, *[Alice's Wonderland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice's_Wonderland)*, had been shown to theater owners but never released to the public.

[Gopinath Saha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gopinath_Saha), 18, Bengali activist for independence in [British India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_India), was hanged at the [Alipore Central Jail](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alipore_Jail) in [Calcutta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calcutta) for the murder of a bystander during his attempt to assassinate [Calcutta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calcutta) Police Commissioner [Charles Tegart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Tegart).

events.text: [Shefqet Vërlaci](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shefqet_Vërlaci) became the new Prime Minister of Albania after [Ahmet Zogu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zog_I_of_Albania)'s serious injury in the assassination attempt of February 23.

The [Turkish National Assembly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey) formally ended the [Ottoman Caliphate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ottoman_Caliphate) that had operated for 407 years, voting "almost unanimously" to abolish the office, and ordered that [Abdulmejid II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abdulmejid_II) and his harem were to be deported by March 15. Abdulmejid, first cousin of the last Ottoman Sultan [Mehmed VI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mehmed_VI), who had become religious leader of Islam upon being elected Caliph on November 19, was formally deposed at 2:00 the next morning.

[Seán O'Casey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seán_O'Casey)'s drama *[Juno and the Paycock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juno_and_the_Paycock)* opened at the [Abbey Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abbey_Theatre), [Dublin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dublin).

events.text: A 7.1 magnitude earthquake, with an epicenter at [Orotina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orotina) in [Costa Rica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Costa_Rica), struck at 5:23 in the morning local time and killed 70 people. Damage was caused in the capital at [San Jose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Jose,_Costa_Rica), 40 mi away.

[Aidan de Brune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aidan_de_Brune) became the first person to walk all the way around [Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia), returning to [Melbourne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melbourne) from whence he had departed on September 20, 1921.

The [University of North Carolina Tar Heels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1923–24_North_Carolina_Tar_Heels_men's_basketball_team) men's basketball team completed a perfect season of 26 wins and no losses, as one of the major unbeaten team in the nation, by winning the 16-team [Southern Intercollegiate Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Southern_Conference_men's_basketball_tournament) postseason tournament, defeating the Alabama Crimson Tide, 26 to 18, in [Atlanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta). The University of Texas Longhorns also went unbeaten, finishing the Southwest Conference regular season with a 23-0 record and being 20-0 in SWC games, but did not play against North Carolina.

births.text: [Kenneth O'Donnell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_O'Donnell), aide to U.S. President [John F. Kennedy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy); in [Worcester, Massachusetts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worcester,_Massachusetts) (d. 1977)

events.text: Just two days after Turkey abolished the caliphate, [Hussein bin Ali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hussein_bin_Ali,_Sharif_of_Mecca), [King of the Hejaz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_of_the_Hejaz) (now Saudi Arabia) and Sharif of Mecca, was proclaimed the [Caliph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caliph) of all Muslims by Muslim leaders in Mesopotamia (now Iraq) and Transjordania (now Jordan). The response throughout the Muslim world was mostly negative.

Among the bird subspecies named in his honor are the [European goldfinch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_goldfinch) *Carduelis tschusii* [common reed bunting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/common_reed_bunting) *Emberiza schoeniclus tschusii* and the [Eurasian wryneck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurasian_wryneck) *Jynx torquilla tschusii*

events.text: In an elaborate nighttime ceremony at [Luxor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luxor) under [floodlights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/floodlight), [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt)'s Prime Minister [Saad Zaghloul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saad_Zaghloul) formally opened the site of Tutankamun's tomb to the [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt)ian public, which reportedly attracted the largest crowd seen in [Luxor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luxor). The reopening turned into an anti-British demonstration when the British High Commissioner, Field Marshal Allenby, arrived when the crowd was demanding immediate British withdrawal from [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt).

[Turkey's first government was reorganized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2nd_government_of_Turkey) as Prime Minister [Ismet Pasha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/İsmet_İnönü) formed a new council of ministers at the request of President Mustapha Kemal Ataturk. Ismet replaced four members of his Cabinet and eliminated the Ministry of Sharia and Foundations, and the Ministry of the General Staff while splitting the Ministry of the Economy into the new Ministry of Commerce and Ministry of Agriculture.

events.text: The *Delahueristas*, rebel supporters of former Mexican President [Adolfo de la Huerta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolfo_de_la_Huerta), surrendered across Mexico as President [Álvaro Obregón](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Álvaro_Obregón) offered an amnesty, bringing an end to the [De la Huerta rebellion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Álvaro_Obregón) after three months.

A representative of the [Irish Republican Army Organisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Republican_Army_Organisation) (IRAO) handed an ultimatum to Ireland's President [W. T. Cosgrave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W._T._Cosgrave), from Major-General [Liam Tobin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liam_Tobin) and Colonel Charles Dalton, demanding an end to Defence Minister [Richard Mulcahy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Mulcahy)'s demobilization of Irish Army troops. Mulcahy ordered the arrest of both officers [on charges of mutiny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Army_Mutiny).

events.text: All 171 miners were killed in two explosions at the [Castle Gate mine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castle_Gate_Mine_disaster) at [Castle Gate, Utah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castle_Gate,_Utah), near the town of [Helper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helper,_Utah).

The Governor-General of British India, [Lord Reading](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rufus_Isaacs,_1st_Marquess_of_Reading) transferred full power of administration of the [princely state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/princely_state) of [Bahawalpur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahawalpur_(princely_state)) (now part of the Punjab province of Pakistan) to the 19-year-old [Nawab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nawab) of [Bahawalpur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahawalpur_(princely_state)), [Sadeq Mohammad Khan V](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sadeq_Mohammad_Khan_V) who had been the nominal ruler since ascending the throne at the age of two on February 15, 1907. Sadeq would remain in power until 1955, when Pakistan abolished its [princely state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/princely_state)s.
Inventor [Nikola Tesla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikola_Tesla) spoke out for the first time in years, announcing he had perfected a system of transmitting power without wires.

[Georgios Kafantaris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgios_Kafantaris) was forced by the Greek Army to resign as [Prime Minister of Greece](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Greece), along with his cabinet, less than a month after succeeding [Eleftherios Venizelos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eleftherios_Venizelos), after refusing to endorse the Army's call for the abolition of the monarchy in favor of a republic. Kafantaris had proposed a referendum on the future of the monarchy while the Army requested an immediate change.
The Kingdom of Greece established diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, a policy that continued even after the kingdom was abolished less than one month later.

He said that by quitting before he could be asked to resign, he was "dying with my face toward the enemy."
France obtained a $50 million credit from American banks and a £5 million credit from London to stabilize the franc.

In the case of *Radice v. [New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_(state))*, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld a [New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_(state)) state statute banning late-night working for women on grounds of health.

events.text: The worst Atlantic gale in twenty years hit the [east coast of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States), downing telephone and telegraph lines and killing nine people.

[Belva Gaertner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belva_Gaertner), a cabaret singer, was arrested for the murder of her abusive lover, Walter Law, who was found dead from a bullet wound in her car in **[[Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_(musical))](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_(musical))_(play))**. She would be acquitted based on reasonable doubt over whether Law's death was a murder or a suicide. The story would be the inspiration of the [Maurine Dallas Watkins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurine_Dallas_Watkins) Broadway play, **[[Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_(musical))](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_(musical))_(play))** in 1926, and for the successful [John Kander](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Kander) and [Fred Ebb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Ebb) [musical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/musical_theatre) **[[Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_(musical))](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_(musical))_(play))** in 1975.

events.text: [Adolfo de la Huerta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolfo_de_la_Huerta), leader of the failed Mexican rebellion against President [Álvaro Obregón](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Álvaro_Obregón), went into exile to Florida.

[Commonwealth Oil Refineries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Oil_Refineries), a joint venture of the [Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia)n government and the [Anglo-Persian Oil Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Persian_Oil_Company) and the first oil refinery in [Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia), began its refining operations as it received its first shipment of crude oil at [Laverton, Victoria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laverton,_Victoria), north of [Melbourne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melbourne).

The World Court of the [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations) issued its decision to end the [border dispute between Poland and Czechoslovakia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish–Czechoslovak_border_conflicts) within the [Orava Territory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Árva_County) in a reworking of the original Spa Conference of 1920 decision. Czechoslovakia was allowed to retain [Javorina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Javorina) (formerly Javorzyna) and [Ždiar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ždiar) in return for ceding Nižná Lipnica (now [Lipnica Wielka, Nowy Targ County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lipnica_Wielka,_Nowy_Targ_County)) to Poland, while Polish territory around Sucha Góra and Glodōvka became [Suchá Hora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suchá_Hora) and [Hladovka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hladovka) in what is now [Slovakia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slovakia).

events.text: A [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations) committee spearheaded by American diplomat [Norman Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_Davis_(diplomat)) reached a settlement on the question of the administration of the [Klaipėda Region](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klaipėda_Region) (*Memelland* in German), leading to the signing of the [Klaipėda Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klaipėda_Convention) two months later.

Fighting broke out in [Honduras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honduras) in the wake of the death of President [Rafael López Gutiérrez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_López_Gutiérrez), initiated by rebels who opposed the new President, [Francisco Bueso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_Bueso).

deaths.text: Died:

[Nellie Kershaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nellie_Kershaw), 33, English textile worker who was the first known person to die of [asbestosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/asbestosis). Miss Kershaw at worked for [Turner Brothers Asbestos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turner_&_Newall) for 18 years, starting at age 13 and continuing until 1922.

[Cyril Harcourt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyril_Harcourt) (pen name for Cyril Worsley Perkins), 51, British playwright and novelist whose 1914 Broadway play *A Pair of Silk Stockings* was later adapted to the 1932 film comedy *[They Just Had to Get Married](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/They_Just_Had_to_Get_Married)*

events.text: [Voting was held in the Dominican Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Dominican_Republic_general_election) for the next president and for the bicameral [Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congress_of_the_Dominican_Republic).[Horacio Vásquez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horacio_Vásquez) defeated [Jacinto Peynado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacinto_Peynado) by more than 2 to 1 margin, and his Progressive National Alliance party won 24 of the 31 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 10 of the 12 seats in the Dominican Senate.

[Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt)'s [King Fuad I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuad_I_of_Egypt) opened the initial session of the first-ever [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt)ian constitutional parliament.

King [Victor Emmanuel III of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III_of_Italy) gave the warrior-poet [Gabriele D'Annunzio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gabriele_D'Annunzio) the title of Prince of [Montenevoso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snežnik_(mountain)).

[England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England_national_rugby_union_team) beat [Scotland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotland_national_rugby_union_team), 19 to 0, to clinch a perfect 4–0 record in the [Five Nations Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Five_Nations_Championship) rugby tournament and complete a [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(rugby_union)).
[Kenya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenya) held a [legislative election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Kenyan_legislative_election), the first under its new Constitution.

births.text: [Walter Gotell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Gotell), German actor; in [Bonn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonn) (d. 1997)
[Concordia Scott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concordia_Scott), Scottish nun and sculptor; in [Glasgow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glasgow) (d. 2014)

deaths.text: [Louis Atilla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludwig_Durlacher) (stage name for Ludwig Durlacher), 79, German [strongman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/strongman) and personal trainer to members of royalty and high society.

Brigadier General [Richard Henry Pratt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Henry_Pratt), 83, controversial U.S. educator and superintendent of the [Carlisle Indian School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlisle_Indian_School) known for his policy of cultural assimilation of Native Americans into Anglo-Saxon culture. General Pratt is credited with coining, in 1902, the word [racism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/racism) but also his summary of erasing the native culture with the phrase "Kill the Indian...save the man."

Major General [DeRosey Cabell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeRosey_Caroll_Cabell), 62, chief of staff for General John J. Pershing of the [U.S. Expedition into Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pancho_Villa_Expedition) in 1916 to 1917 after Villa's attack on [Columbus, New Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbus,_New_Mexico).
[Daniel Ridgway Knight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Ridgway_Knight), 84, American artist

events.text: Italy formally annexed [Fiume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiume) in a colorful ceremony. Crowds cheered as King [Victor Emmanuel III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III) read the annexation decree.

[Annie Matheson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annie_Matheson), 70, British writer known for *Florence Nightingale: A biography* and for her "Rose and Dragon" children's book series.

events.text: The [first attempt to fly around the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation) began as four [Douglas World Cruiser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_World_Cruiser) airplanes, piloted by members of the [United States Army Air Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Army_Air_Service), departed from [Santa Monica, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Monica,_California), for *[Seattle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)*, the starting point of the global circumnavigation. Of the four aircraft— *[Seattle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)*, **Chicago**, *Boston* and **New Orleans**— the airplanes **Chicago** and **New Orleans** would return to *[Seattle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)* 175 days later on September 28.

[Athlone Town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athlone_Town_A.F.C.) defeated [Fordsons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fordsons_F.C.) 1-0 to win the [Football Association of Ireland Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1923–24_FAI_Cup).

[France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France_men's_national_ice_hockey_team) defeated [Sweden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweden_men's_national_ice_hockey_team) 2-1 to win the [Ice Hockey European Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_Hockey_European_Championship_1924).

The [Irish Army Mutiny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Army_Mutiny) came to a crisis as 40 armed soldiers assembled at a hotel in Dublin to plan the next move, including [a possible coup d'etat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Army_Mutiny) against the Irish government. Two truckloads of Irish Army troops surrounded the building and a standoff ensued. The Irish government responded by getting the resignation of the Irish Army Council members, along with that of Defence Minister [Richard Mulcahy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Mulcahy).

The swashbuckling film *[The Thief of Bagdad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Thief_of_Bagdad_(1924_film))*, starring [Douglas Fairbanks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_Fairbanks), was released.

births.text: [Johnny Papalia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnny_Papalia), crime boss in the Canadian mob; in [Hamilton, Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton,_Ontario) (d.1997)

events.text: [Winston Churchill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winston_Churchill) of the [Constitutionalists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitutionalist_(UK)) lost the [Westminster Abbey by-election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Westminster_Abbey_by-election) by 43 votes to [Unionist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)) candidate [Otho Nicholson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otho_Nicholson), who had 8,187 votes to Churchill's 8,144. Churchill had originally lost by 33 votes and requested a recount, which showed a larger winning majority.

[Bertolt Brecht](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bertolt_Brecht)'s play *[The Life of Edward II of England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Life_of_Edward_II_of_England)* (*Leben Eduards des Zweiten von England*) was given its first performance, premiering at the [Munich Kammerspiele](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Munich_Kammerspiele).

Kohli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F._C._Kohli) (Faqir Chand Kohli), Indian software producer, information technology entrepreneur, and founder of [Tata Consultancy Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tata_Consultancy_Services), in [Peshawar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peshawar), [Punjab Province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab_Province_(British_India)), [British India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_India) (now [Punjab province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab,_[Pakistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan)) in [Pakistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan) (d. 2020)

events.text: What is now the national airline of Finland, [Finnair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finnair), began operations as Aero O/Y, with a flight from [Helsinki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helsinki) to [Tallinn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tallinn) in [Estonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estonia) in a [Junkers F.13](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Junkers_F.13) seaplane.

The "Eugenical Sterilization Act" went into effect in the U.S. state of [Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia) upon being signed into law by Governor [E. Lee Trinkle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._Lee_Trinkle), providing for the sterilization of persons in mental institutions.

[Nadir of American race relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadir_of_American_race_relations): In the U.S., the [Virginia General Assembly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_General_Assembly) passed the [Racial Integrity Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_Integrity_Act_of_1924), amending the state's racial classification law which had provided that a person was considered to be "colored" if they had a great-grandparent who was African-American. The amendment enacted the "[one-drop rule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/one-drop_rule)", which provided that a person was considered non-white if it was shown that they had *any* ancestor who was African-American. The 1924 Act had what was called the "Pocahontas Clause" providing that a person with an American Indian ancestor would be considered white if they were 15/16ths European.

events.text: The first modern [mutual fund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/mutual_fund), the [Massachusetts Investors Trust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MFS_Investment_Management), was introduced by [Edward G. Leffler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_G._Leffler) with an [open-ended policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-end_fund) that allowed investors to withdraw their account money at any time from the collective investment.

A British soldier was killed, and 21 others wounded, in a drive-by shooting at [Queenstown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cobh) in Ireland's [County Cork](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/County_Cork). Four IRA members dressed as [Irish Free State Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Army_(Ireland)) officers drove into town in a converted 1919 Rolls-Royce, dubbed the "[Moon Car](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_Car)". As the [Moon Car](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_Car) drove past the destroyer [HMS Scythe (1918)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Scythe_(1918)) at the port of [Spike Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spike_Island,_County_Cork), the men opened fire with a machine gun.
London drivers of [trams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/tram) and public buses went on strike.

Boxer [Abe Goldstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abe_Goldstein) won the world bantamweight championship in a 15-round bout against [Joe Lynch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Lynch_(boxer)) before 14,900 people at [Madison Square Garden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden_(1890)) in New York City.

Dunville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T._E._Dunville) (stage name for Thomas Edward Wallen), 56, English comedian, committed suicide one day after his final stage performance. He left a suicide note for his wife, and his body was found in the [River Thames](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/River_Thames) the next day.

events.text: The ocean liner RMS *Olympic* collided with the smaller liner *[Fort St George](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMAT_Wandilla)* in New York City. The damage required repairs to the extent of which had never been attempted on a ship the size of *Olympic* before.

General [Robert Nivelle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Nivelle), 67, French Chief of the Army Staff, known for the [Nivelle offensive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nivelle_offensive) on the [Western Front](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)) during World War One.

events.text: [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) presided over a Fascist parade in Rome commemorating the fifth anniversary of the founding of the *[Fasci Italiani da Combattimento](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fasci_Italiani_di_Combattimento)*. Mussolini's commemorative speech doubled as a campaign speech for the upcoming [general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Italian_general_election) as he listed his government's accomplishments.

[Olga Kennard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olga_Kennard), Hungarian-born British scientist and researcher of [crystallography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/crystallography) for the structure of organic molecules; in [Budapest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budapest) (d. 2023)

[Vasubahen Ramprasad Bhatt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasubahen), Indian radio director, social activist and [Gujarati language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarati_language) novelist; in [Baroda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baroda), [Baroda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baroda) State (now Vadodara, Gujarat state) (d. 2020)

events.text: The [U.S. House of Representatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives) voted to appropriate $10 million for the purchase of food supplies for impoverished women and children in Germany.

[Symphony No. 7 in C major](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symphony_No._7_(Sibelius)), written by composer [Jean Sibelius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Sibelius), was performed for the first time, as part of a concert in [Stockholm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stockholm).

The films *[Secrets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secrets_(1924_film))*, starring [Norma Talmadge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norma_Talmadge), and *[The Enchanted Cottage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Enchanted_Cottage_(1924_film))*, starring [Richard Barthelmess](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Barthelmess) and [May McAvoy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/May_McAvoy), were released.
The Portuguese football club [Sport Benfica e Castelo Branco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_Benfica_e_Castelo_Branco) was founded.

births.text: [Norman Fell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_Fell) (stage name for Norman Noah Feld), American film and TV actor known for the series *Three's Company*; in [Philadelphia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia) (d. 1998)

[Abbas Abbasi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abbas_Abbasi), Pakistani politician, army officer and former member of royalty who served as Governor of [Punjab province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab,_Pakistan) 1975-1977, Pakistani [Minister for Religious Affairs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Religious_Affairs_and_Inter-faith_Harmony) 1981-1984, and former heir to the throne of the [[Bahawalpur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahawalpur)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Bahawalpur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahawalpur)_(princely_state)) [princely state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/princely_states_of_Pakistan); in [[Bahawalpur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahawalpur)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Bahawalpur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahawalpur)_(princely_state)) (d. 1988)

events.text: The Greek Parliament voted to depose King [George II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_II_of_Greece) and declare the [Second Hellenic Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Hellenic_Republic). A public referendum on the issue was set for April 13.

The [Montreal Canadiens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1923–24_Montreal_Canadiens_season) of the [National Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hockey_League) (NHL) defeated the [Calgary Tigers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calgary_Tigers) of the [Western Canada Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Canada_Hockey_League) (WCHL), 3 to 0, to win the [Stanley Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Stanley_Cup_Finals), two games to none in a best-of-three series. The game was played in Ottawa because the natural ice at the March 22 first game at Montreal's [Mount Royal Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Royal_Arena) had turned to slush in warmer than normal temperatures, on a day with a high of 42 F.

A three-man team of British fliers, led by navigator [Archibald Stuart-MacLaren](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archibald_Stuart-MacLaren), accompanied by pilot William Noble Plenderleith and flight engineer Sergeant W. H. Andrews, became the first of six different groups to attempt the [first trip around the world by airplane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation). The British team departed from [Calshot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calshot) Aerodrome, near [Southampton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southampton), in a [Vickers Vulture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vickers_Viking) II Mark VI amphibious biplane. Other teams from the U.S., Portugal, France, Italy and Argentina, would depart between April and June on different routes to cover a global trip of at least 23000 mi with plans to return the site of their takeoff. The British attempt would eventually end on August 4 when Plenderleith was forced to make a forced sea landing in which the aircraft was badly damaged.

events.text: French [Prime Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_France) [Raymond Poincaré](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Poincaré) resigned after his government was defeated in the [Chamber of Deputies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(France)) by a vote of 271 to 264. The confidence vote was a complete surprise and Poincaré was not even present, as he was in a committee meeting when it was announced and voted on.

[Friedrich Akel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Akel) became the new *Rigivanem* (literally the "State Elder"), the head of state and head of government for [Estonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estonia), after [Konstantin Päts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konstantin_Päts) had announced his resignation on March 11.
Over 100 people died in landslides around [Amalfi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amalfi) in Italy.

sources: Landslides Kill 73 in Italy; Rush to Rescue Yanks - March 27, 1924, p. 1
Landslide at Beauty Spot of Italy Kills Hundred - March 28, 1924, p. 3
Poincaré to Take Reins of France Again - March 27, 1924, p. 1, Author: Henry Wales

events.text: The opening of the first elected parliament in the [Kingdom of Iraq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Iraq), the 100-member Constituent Assembly, was opened in Baghdad by [King Faisal I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faisal_I_of_Iraq) and directed to draw up the Middle Eastern nation's [first constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_Iraq), which would be ratified in 1925.
[Raymond Poincaré](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Poincaré) accepted President [Alexandre Millerand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandre_Millerand)'s request to form a new government.

[Erich Ludendorff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erich_Ludendorff) and [Adolf Hitler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolf_Hitler) made their final addresses as their trial for treason wound down in [Munich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Munich).

The [New York Philharmonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Philharmonic) orchestra began its tradition of the [Young People's Concerts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Young_People's_Concerts), with guest conductor [Ernest Schelling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernest_Schelling) providing a description of aspects to be listened for in the music that would be heard, or about the parts of the orchestra itself. From 1926 onward, a concert would be performed every month.

**[Irrelohe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irrelohe)**, a three-act [opera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/opera) by [German](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language) composer [Franz Schreker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franz_Schreker) premiered at the [Stadttheater [Köln](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cologne)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cologne_Opera) in [Köln](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cologne), with [Otto Klemperer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Klemperer) as conductor. **[Irrelohe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irrelohe)**, [German](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language) for a crazy fire, was named by Schreker for the [Irrenlohe station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irrenlohe_station), a railway stop in Bavaria.

events.text: The first known [Motocross](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motocross) in the United Kingdom took place at [Camberley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camberley), [Surrey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrey), with a "[scramble race](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/hare_scramble)" of 89 riders, rather than the individual time trials that had been staged by clubs. Rather than everyone starting at once, however, riders started once per minute, riding two laps on a challenging course 25 mi long.

The popular [musical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/musical_theatre) *[Wildflower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildflower_(musical))*, with music by [Herbert Stothart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Stothart) and [Vincent Youmans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vincent_Youmans), and lyrics by [Oscar Hammerstein II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oscar_Hammerstein_II) and [Otto Harbach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Harbach), closed at the [Casino Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Casino_Theatre_(New_York_City)) on [Broadway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadway_theatre) after 477 performances, following its premiere on February 7, 1923.

events.text: The air transport company [Imperial Airways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_Airways) was founded in the United Kingdom by the merger of the UK's four existing airlines, [Handley Page Transport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handley_Page_Transport), [Instone Air Line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instone_Air_Line), [Daimler Airway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daimler_Airway) and [British Marine Air Navigation Co Ltd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Marine_Air_Navigation_Co_Ltd). The four combined their aircraft for a fleet of 13 planes operating out of [Croydon Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croydon_Airport) to serve international flights to and from [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London). In 1939, Imperial would merge with [[British Airways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Airways) Ltd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Airways_Ltd) to form [British Overseas Airways Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Overseas_Airways_Corporation) (BOAC), which would merge in 1974, fifty years from the day of Imperial's founding, with [British European Airways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_European_Airways) to create [British Airways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Airways).
The London tram and bus drivers' strike ended after a vote on a new wage package from the transport companies.
