The classic jazz tune "[Sweet Georgia Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweet_Georgia_Brown)" was first recorded by bandleader [Ben Bernie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Bernie).
The British government announced that it was proceeding with the development of a major naval base at [Singapore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singapore).

sources: Philadelphia's 1926 Sesqui-Centennial International Exposition - 2009, p. 7, Publisher: Arcadia Publishing, ISBN: 978-0-7385-6544-6, Author: James D. Ristine

events.text: [Arturo Alessandri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arturo_Alessandri) returned from exile to retake office as [president of Chile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/president_of_Chile), thus ending the [January Junta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_Junta_of_Chile_(1925)).

The documentary film *[Grass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grass_(1925_film))*, following the [Bakhtiari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bakhtiari_people) tribe of [Persia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persia), was released.

deaths.text: **Died:** [George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Curzon,_1st_Marquess_Curzon_of_Kedleston), 66, Viceroy of India

events.text: The state of [Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennessee) enacted the [Butler Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butler_Act), prohibiting school teachers from denying the [Biblical account](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creationism) of man's origin.

The first performance of the [Maurice Ravel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Ravel) opera ballet *[L'enfant et les sortilèges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L'enfant_et_les_sortilèges)* was conducted in Monte Carlo.

births.text: [Peter Brook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Brook), British theatre director, in [Chiswick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiswick) (d. 2022)

sources: [Peter Brook | Biography, Plays, & Facts | Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Peter-Brook)

events.text: The first Japanese radio program was transmitted in Tokyo.
Women's [tuxedos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/tuxedo) were reported as the newest fashion rage in Paris.

40-year-old Lewis S. Thompson of [Denver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denver), [Colorado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colorado), fell 700 ft to his death from the [South Rim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Rim) of the [Grand Canyon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Canyon) while posing for a photo.

births.text: [Gerard Hoffnung](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerard_Hoffnung), artist and musician, in Berlin (d. 1959)

It's the Tuxedo Now the Wimmin Grab from Us - March 23, 1925, p. 1

events.text: In Rome, [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) made his first public appearance in over a month when he briefly spoke at a celebration commemorating the sixth anniversary of the *[Fasci Italiani da Combattimento](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fasci_Italiani_di_Combattimento)*. There had been much speculation as to the state of his health during his long absence.

[Parliamentary elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Egyptian_parliamentary_election) were held in Egypt. The [Wafd Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wafd_Party) lost its majority to a collection of other parties and independents.

births.text: [David Watkin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Watkin_(cinematographer)), cinematographer, in [Margate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margate), England (d. 2008)

sources: 150,000 Roar Continued Faith to Mussolini. - March 23, 1925, p. 6

events.text: The two-act operetta and [radio opera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/radio_opera) *[The Red Pen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Red_Pen)* was first broadcast.

births.text: [Quazi Nuruzzaman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quazi_Nuruzzaman), Bangladeshi guerrilla commander (d. 2011)

events.text: Scottish inventor [John Logie Baird](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Logie_Baird) publicly demonstrated the transmission of moving silhouette pictures at the London department store [Selfridges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selfridges).

births.text: [Flannery O'Connor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flannery_O'Connor), writer, in [Savannah, Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Savannah,_Georgia) (d. 1964)

deaths.text: **Died:** [Hugo Bettauer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugo_Bettauer), 52, Austrian writer and journalist (shot on March 10)

events.text: A fistfight broke out in the Italian [Chamber of Deputies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Italy)). Upon [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini)'s return to the Chamber after an absence of 40 days, Fascists cheered and sang "[Giovinezza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovinezza)", while the [Communists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Italy) countered with "[The Internationale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Internationale)". Fascists rushed the Communist benches and punches were exchanged until the [Communists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Italy) left the Chamber and order was restored.

Germany announced that holders of German [war bonds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/war_bond) would receive a refund of 5 percent of their original investment. Winners of a lottery would receive a refund of up to 25 percent.
The British armed merchant cruiser [HMS Rawalpindi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Rawalpindi) was launched.

births.text: [Pierre Boulez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Boulez), composer, in [Montbrison, Loire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montbrison,_Loire), France (d. 2016)

sources: Deputies Fight as Mussolini enters Session - March 27, 1925, p. 1, Author: [George Seldes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George Seldes)
Germany Will Pay 5 Per Cent for War Bonds - March 27, 1925, p. 15, Author: [Sigrid Schultz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sigrid Schultz)

events.text: Double Chase won the 84th [Grand National](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Grand_National) horse race at [Aintree Racecourse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aintree_Racecourse) near [Liverpool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liverpool), England.

[James "Red" Herring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Red_Herring) won boxing's World Junior Welterweight Title in a controversial decision over [Pinky Mitchell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinky_Mitchell).

The remains of U.S. Admiral [George Dewey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Dewey) were disinterred from [Arlington National Cemetery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arlington_National_Cemetery) and moved to the [Washington National Cathedral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_National_Cathedral), next to the tomb of [Woodrow Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson).
The [University of Cambridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Cambridge) won the 77th annual [Boat Race](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Boat_Race_1925).

deaths.text: **Died:** [Henry Rawlinson, 1st Baron Rawlinson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Rawlinson,_1st_Baron_Rawlinson), 61, British general

sources: Dewey Sleeps Beside Wilson in Cathedral - March 29, 1925, p. 1, Author: James O'Donnell Bennett

events.text: The [German presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_German_presidential_election) was held to choose a successor to [Friedrich Ebert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert), who died in office February 28. [Karl Jarres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_Jarres) came in first with 38.8% of the vote, but because no candidate won a majority a [run-off election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-round_system) was set for April 26.
Japan passed a suffrage bill expanding voting rights to 4 million citizens who were previously barred from voting on account of their dependence on public or private assistance for their livelihood.

births.text: [Bobby Hutchins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bobby_Hutchins), child film actor (*[Our Gang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Our_Gang)*), in [Tacoma, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tacoma,_Washington) (d. 1945)

sources: Japan Grants Vote Right to 4,000,000 More - March 30, 1925, p. 3

events.text: The [Victoria Cougars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_Cougars) defeated the [Montreal Canadiens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montreal_Canadiens), 6 to 1, to win the [Stanley Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Stanley_Cup_Finals) of ice hockey, three games to one. The Cougars were the last non-[NHL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hockey_League) team to win the Cup.

Explorer [Donald Baxter MacMillan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Baxter_MacMillan) urged U.S. President [Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) to send ships into the [Arctic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arctic) in search of undiscovered lands to claim for the United States.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Rudolf Steiner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolf_Steiner), 64, Austrian philosopher

sources: MacMillan Urges U.S. to Claim Lands Near North Pole - March 31, 1925, p. 9

events.text: 67 soldiers of the [Reichswehr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichswehr) were reported drowned when a pontoon bridge over the [Weser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weser) river near [Minden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minden) collapsed. Later reporting alleged that the casualties were over 200 and the German military was conducting experiments with a new river-crossing system.
The *[Philadelphia Daily News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Daily_News)* began publication.

sources: 67 Soldiers in Germany Die as Bridge Breaks - April 1, 1925, p. 14, Author: [Sigrid Schultz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sigrid Schultz)
Reveal How 200 Germans Died for Army Test - April 18, 1925, p. 5, Author: John Steele

events.text: The British government formally recognized the Soviet Union and began diplomatic relations with [Robert M. Hodgson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Hodgson_(diplomat)) as the first [chargé d'affaires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/chargé_d'affaires).

Honduran President [Rafael López Gutiérrez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_López_Gutiérrez), who had been [elected in 1919](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1919_Honduran_general_election) for a 4-year term that started on February 1, 1920, refused to leave office after his term expired, citing the failure of the Honduran Congress to elect a president following the lack of any candidate to receive a majority in the [1923 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1923_Honduran_general_election).

births.text: [Richard Hooker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Hooker_(author)) (pen name for Dr. Hiester Richard Hornberger Jr.), American surgeon and author who wrote a novel based on his experiences at a [mobile army surgical hospital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Army_Surgical_Hospital) during the Korean War, *MASH: A Novel About Three Army Doctors* (published 1968), later adapted into [a successful film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[M*A*S*H](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M*A*S*H_(TV_series))_(film)) in 1970 and an even more successful TV series in 1972, [M*A*S*H](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M*A*S*H_(TV_series))''; in [Trenton, New Jersey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trenton,_New_Jersey) (d. 1997)

[Ruth Teitelbaum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruth_Teitelbaum), American computer programmer who was one of six women assigned to enter data into the U.S. Army's Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer ([ENIAC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ENIAC)); as Ruth Lichterman in [the Bronx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/the_Bronx) (d.1986)

events.text: [Alexei Rykov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexei_Rykov) became Chairman of the [Council of People's Commissars of the Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Council_of_People's_Commissars_of_the_Soviet_Union), equivalent to Prime Minister of the Soviet Union, filling the vacancy left by the death of [Lenin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin).

[Felix Dzerzhinsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Felix_Dzerzhinsky) became Chairman of the [Supreme Soviet of the National Economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Soviet_of_the_National_Economy).

The [International Ski Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Ski_and_Snowboard_Federation) (FIS) was founded in [Chamonix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamonix) in France, site of France's International Ski Week, later recognized as the [1924 Winter Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Winter_Olympics), during a meeting of leaders of the skiing organizations of various nations.
[Woodrow Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson) fell into a coma shortly before 10:30 p.m.

births.text: [Elfi von Dassanowsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elfi_von_Dassanowsky), Austrian singer, pianist and film producer; in [Vienna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vienna) (d. 2007)

images.caption: Alexei Rikov emerges as the new Premier of the Soviet Union

events.text: [Woodrow Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson), who had served as President of the United States from 1913 to 1921, died at the age of 67 in his home at 2340 S Street NW in Washington, D.C., at 11:15 in the morning.

The Soviet Union welcomed Britain's diplomatic recognition of the USSR as an "historic step" and pledged to "make every effort to settle all misunderstandings and develop and consolidate economic relations."
Germany and Turkey signed a Treaty of Friendship.

[Astra Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astra_Club), based in [Tokyo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokyo), defeated Shukyu-Dan of [Nagoya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagoya), 2 to 1, to [win](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1923_Emperor's_Cup_final) the [Emperor's Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emperor's_Cup) in football.

images.caption: Former U.S. President Woodrow Wilson dies at age 67

sources: Russia Accepts Britain's Offer of Recognition - February 4, 1924, p. 16, Author: Paul Williams

events.text: Indian freedom fighter [Mohandas K. Gandhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohandas_K._Gandhi), known for his campaign of [passive resistance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/passive_resistance) in pursuing the independence of India from the British Empire, was released from incarceration in [Ahmedabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmedabad) after serving less than two years of his six-year prison sentence for [sedition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/sedition). The release came on the recommendation of British physicians that Gandhi should be allowed six months convalescence to recover from a serious illness.

sources: British Release Gandhi, Indian Non Co-Op Chief - February 5, 1924, p. 5

events.text: A flash flood inside an underground iron mine [drowned 41 of the 46 miners inside](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milford_Mine), after the crew conducted blasting too close to the bottom of Foley Lake near [Crosby, Minnesota](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crosby,_Minnesota).

At 17:30:00 UTC, the [Greenwich Observatory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich) in England, near [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London), began its service of broadcasting regular of broadcasting a [time signal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/time_signal) for the standard of the exact time of day by hour, minute and second as measured at Greenwich. According to a press release from Greenwich, "the last four seconds of the preceding minute will be heard as 'clicks' when the signal is about to be given, representing the 55th, 56th, 57th, 58th and 59th second, and the final click, which will be a little louder than the others" every minute on [shortwave radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/shortwave_radio) to be heard worldwide, with an announcement of the exact time.

The [Winter Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Winter_Olympics) closed in [Chamonix, France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamonix,_France). Norway and Finland tied for the [most gold medals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Winter_Olympics_medal_table) with four each, but Norway won 17 total medals to Finland's 11.

Mexican rebels retreated from their former stronghold of [Veracruz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veracruz) when federal troops won a crucial victory at [Córdoba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Córdoba,_Veracruz).

*The Show-Off*, a play by American playwright [George Kelly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Kelly_(playwright)), opened on [Broadway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadway_theatre) at the [Playhouse Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Playhouse_Theatre_(New_York_City)) for the first of 571 performances.

events.text: The funeral of former U.S. President [Woodrow Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson) was conducted. He was buried in a vault beneath the center aisle of the chapel of the [Washington National Cathedral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_National_Cathedral), becoming the first, and only, U.S. president to be buried in the District of Columbia.

Demonstrators raised disturbances outside the German embassy in Washington. About 200 taxi drivers walked onto the embassy lawn, and after planting the American flag, saluted it amid cheers and pistol shots. The controversy arose after the German Embassy had refused to offer condolences or to lower flags in honor of the late President Wilson, who had led the U.S. against the German Empire during World War One from 1917 to 1918.

births.text: [Sir John Richardson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Richardson_(art_historian)), British art historian, in [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London) (d. 2019)

deaths.text: [Sir John Stewart, 1st Baronet, of Fingask](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_John_Stewart,_1st_Baronet,_of_Fingask), 46, Scottish whisky distiller, committed suicide at his home at [Fingask Castle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fingask_Castle) in [Perthshire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perthshire).

[Queenie Scott-Hopper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queenie_Scott-Hopper), 42, English children's author, committed suicide at her home in Whitley Bay, by slitting her own throat. Her suicide noted stated that she took her life because she was unable "to think up any new ideas for stories."

sources: Wilson Sleeps in Cathedral Tomb; Notables of Nation Pay Last Homage - _Chicago Daily Tribune_, February 7, 1924, p. 1, Author: [James O'Donnell Bennett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James O'Donnell Bennett)

events.text: Mexican rebel leader [Adolfo de la Huerta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolfo_de_la_Huerta) and his staff withdrew by boat to [Mérida, Yucatán](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mérida,_Yucatán) after federal troops recaptured the key city of [Veracruz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veracruz_(city)).
The Fascist government of Italy gave formal recognition of the Communist Soviet Union.

sources: Mexican Rebel Chief and Staff Reach Yucatán - February 8, 1924, p. 2

events.text: The first [execution by lethal gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/gas_chamber) in American history was carried out in [Carson City, Nevada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_City,_Nevada) at the [Nevada State Prison](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nevada_State_Prison). Chinese national [Gee Jon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gee_Jon), convicted of a gangland slaying, was put to death with a chemical reaction that put [prussic acid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/hydrogen_cyanide) into an airtight chamber.

On the same day, the U.S. state of Texas executed five prisoners— all African-American inmates who had been convicted of murder— at the [state penitentiary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huntsville_Unit) in [Huntsville, Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huntsville,_Texas), in the state's first use of the [electric chair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/electric_chair). Starting at 12:09 a.m., Charles Reynolds was the first to die "as Warden Walter Monroe Miller threw the switch which sent 2,500 volts and 11 amperes of electricity into Reynolds's body. Over the next hour, E. L. Morris, George Washington and Mack Matthews were put to death. The fifth inmate, Melvin Johnson, was electrocuted after a one-hour stay of execution.

The [Nakhchivan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nakhchivan_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic) was created by the Soviet Union within the Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic. On January 20, 1990, it would become the first part of the Soviet Union to secede.

U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) signed a resolution ordering the [Doheny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_L._Doheny) and [Sinclair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Ford_Sinclair) petroleum leases to be nullified due to the [Teapot Dome scandal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teapot_Dome_scandal).

births.text: [Ada Sipuel Fisher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ada_Lois_Sipuel_Fisher), U.S. civil rights figure and lawyer known for her successful 1948 challenge to racial segregation in the case of *[Sipuel v. Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sipuel_v._Board_of_Regents_of_the_University_of_Oklahoma)*; in [Chickasha, Oklahoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chickasha,_Oklahoma) (d. 1995)

[Lady Wonder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lady_Wonder), American horse exhibited for her abilities to perform arithmetic and spelling while being accompanied by her owner and trainer, Claudia E. Fonda (d. 1957)

[Major General John W. Hepfer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Hepfer), U.S. Air Force officer and missile development engineer who oversaw the creation of the [Minuteman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGM-30_Minuteman) and [Peacekeeper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGM-118_Peacekeeper) intercontinental ballistic missiles; in [Waynesboro, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waynesboro,_Pennsylvania) (d. 1997)

deaths.text: Died:

[Annie Arniel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annie_Arniel), 50, American suffragist and women's rights activist died by suicide from natural gas in a rooming house where she was living in [Wilmington, Delaware](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilmington,_Delaware).

[David Dunnels White](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Dunnels_White), 79, Union Army veteran of the American Civil War who would be nominated (and declined) for the [Medal of Honor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medal_of_Honor) in 2016.

[Madame Sorgue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madame_Sorgue) (Antoinette Cauvin), 59, French anarchist, feminist and labor activist referred to as "the most dangerous woman in Europe", died of a heart attack.

events.text: The [Nakhchivan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nakhchivan_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic) was established.

As the [Drenica-Dukagjin Uprisings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drenica-Dukagjin_Uprisings) drew to a close in [Kosovo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosovo), Yugoslavian troops carried out the massacre of 25 Albanian-minority civilians (including eight young children and ten women) in the Kosovan town of [Dubnica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dumnicë_e_Poshtme,_Podujevo), then set fire to the town.
Mexican federal troops won a decisive battle over the rebels at [Ocotlán](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ocotlán,_Jalisco).

events.text: The [United States Senate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate) voted, 47 to 34, to demand that President [Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) remove [Edwin Denby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edwin_Denby_(politician)), who was under investigation for the [Teapot Dome scandal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teapot_Dome_scandal), as [Secretary of the Navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Navy). [Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) said in a statement that evening that, "As soon as special counsel can advise me as to the legality of these leases and assemble for me the pertinent facts in the various transactions, I shall take such action as seems essential for the full protection of the public interests".

The five-day [Negro Sanhedrin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negro_Sanhedrin) opened in Chicago with 250 delegates from trade unions, civic groups and fraternal organizations in an attempt to create a program to protect the legal rights of African-American tenant farmers.

The Greek government deposited the instrument of ratification of the [treaty of Lausanne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/treaty_of_Lausanne), the peace treaty between Turkey and the Allied Powers, that was concluded on July 24, 1923.

events.text: [Howard Carter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howard_Carter) and his archaeological team had the lid of Pharaoh [Tutankhamun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tutankhamun)'s stone sarcophagus raised, revealing his solid gold mummy case. The case itself would not be opened until October 28, 1925.

The [George Gershwin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Gershwin) musical composition *[Rhapsody in Blue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhapsody_in_Blue)* premiered at the [Aeolian Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aeolian_Hall_(Manhattan)) in New York City.

The play *[Beggar on Horseback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beggar_on_Horseback)*, by [George S. Kaufman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_S._Kaufman) and [Marc Connelly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Connelly), opened on Broadway.

*[L'Unita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L'Unita)* began a 67-year run as the official newspaper of the Italian Communist Party, before becoming an independent leftist periodical after the dissolution of the PCI. The paper would cease publication entirely in 2017.

events.text: German nationalists attacked the headquarters of Rhineland separatists in [Pirmasens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pirmasens), smashing their way into the building and setting it ablaze, while snipers outside shot at the separatists. The fighting and the blaze killed 36 people, most of them separatists, an elderly woman bystander was killed by a stray bullet.

The first [fascist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/fascism) event ever held in public in the United Kingdom took place at the [Hotel Cecil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotel_Cecil_(London)) in London, as about 500 members of the [British Fascisti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Fascists) and Italian expatriates attended.

The day after testifying in the trial of Shoeless Joe Jackson, former Chicago White Sox outfielder [Oscar "Happy" Felsch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Happy_Felsch) was arrested for [perjury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/perjury) in testimony given as a rebuttal witness for Jackson. The arrest came after lawyers for the Chicago White Sox produced letters that contradicted Felsch's statements. Felsch posted his own $2,000 bail and was released.

[Howard Carter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howard_Carter) abruptly suspended work on Tutankhamun's tomb and had it resealed, "owing to the impossible restrictions and discourtesies on the part of the public works department and its antiquity section." The dispute was reportedly about media access rights.

events.text: The [Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computing-Tabulating-Recording_Company) (CTR) renamed itself the International Business Machines Corporation, or [IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM).
Mexican federal troops inflicted another defeat on rebels near Paloverde southwest of [Pénjamo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pénjamo).

The planned city of [Longview, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longview,_Washington), was incorporated after being designed by city planner [George Kessler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Kessler) for the [Long-Bell Lumber Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long-Bell_Lumber_Company) to house 11,000 residents who were employees and their families.

Part 1 of the [Fritz Lang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fritz_Lang) fantasy film *[Die Nibelungen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Die_Nibelungen)* premiered at the [Ufa-Palast am Zoo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ufa-Palast_am_Zoo) in Berlin.

events.text: U.S. troops began their intervention in the [civil war in Honduras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Honduran_Civil_War), with 167 U.S. Marines and nine officers landing at [Ampala](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ampala) after being brought by the battle cruiser USS *Milwaukee*.

U.S. Senator [Frank L. Greene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_L._Greene) of Vermont was seriously wounded when he was shot in the head by a stray bullet during a shootout between [Prohibition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prohibition) enforcement agents and [bootleggers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/rum-running). Senator Greene had been walking along Washington's [Pennsylvania Avenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania_Avenue) with his wife and was left partially paralyzed.

The jury in the [Joe Jackson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoeless_Joe_Jackson)-White Sox case awarded Jackson over $16,000 in unpaid salary. However, Judge Gregory declared that the plaintiff's case was based on perjury and declared a mistrial. Jackson was triumphant at the verdict despite it being set aside.

In Germany, the enabling act of December 8 expired under its own terms, after having allowed Chancellor [Wilhelm Marx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_Marx) and [his cabinet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Marx_cabinet) to issue emergency decrees. In the first session of the Reichstag afterward, legislators began the process of attempting to repeal the Marx cabinet decrees.

Gilbert [trench warfare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/trench_warfare) [filling factory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filling_factories_in_the_United_Kingdom) killed 12 young women and a male foreman who were employees in south east London at the borough of [Slade Green](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slade_Green), near [Dartford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dartford).

The popular U.S. comic strip *[Boots and Her Buddies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boots_and_Her_Buddies)*, by [Edgar Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edgar_Martin), was published for the first time and would run for 44 years until ending on October 6, 1968.

American jazz cornet player and composer [Bix Beiderbecke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bix_Beiderbecke) (Leon Bismark Beiderbecke) made his recording debut as he and his band [The Wolverines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wolverines_(jazz_band)) created the 78 rpm record "[Fidgety Feet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fidgety_Feet)" for Gennett Studios, with "Jazz Me Blues" on the opposite side.

British Prime Minister [Ramsay MacDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald) warned against [profiteers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profiteering_(business)) extracting "unjust prices" during the dock worker's strike.

The cost of a four-pound loaf of bread went up a [halfpenny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/halfpenny_(British_pre-decimal_coin)) to eightpence-[halfpenny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/halfpenny_(British_pre-decimal_coin)) as a result of the dock strike.

events.text: The [Volga German Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volga_German_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic) was set up for the [ethnic German](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia_Germans) minority in the Soviet Union, with a capital city of Kosakenstadt, now [Engels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Engels,_Saratov_Oblast) in the [Saratov Oblast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saratov_Oblast). It would exist until its abolition by the USSR on September 7, 1941 in response to the invasion by Nazi Germany.

French military leaders objected to a clause in the Dawes proposal that would return the railroads in the [occupied Ruhr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Ruhr) region to German control.

The genus *[Peringueyella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peringueyella)* of [katydids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tettigoniidae) is named in his honor, as are the reptile species [Peringuey's leaf-toed gecko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peringuey's_leaf-toed_gecko) (*Cryptactites peringueyi*) and [Peringuey's adder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peringuey's_adder) (*Bitis peringueyi*) and the black cocktail ant (*[Crematogaster peringueyi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crematogaster_peringueyi)*).

events.text: [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) became the first President to make a radio broadcast from the [White House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House) when he gave a national address on the occasion of [George Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Washington)'s birthday.

The [Treaty of Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome_(1924)) signed on January 27 between the [Kingdom of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy) and the [Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbs,_Croats_and_Slovenes) took effect after being ratified by representatives of both parties, dissolving the [Free State of Fiume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_State_of_Fiume) and dividing it between the two kingdoms.

A bill to provide for automatic U.S. citizenship for Native American peoples was introduced by U.S. Representative [Homer P. Snyder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homer_P._Snyder), a Republican for the state of New York. The text of the [Indian Citizenship Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Citizenship_Act) stated "*Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled,*, That all non citizen Indians born within the territorial limits of the United States be, and they are hereby, declared to be citizens of the United States: *Provided* That the granting of such citizenship shall not in any manner impair or otherwise affect the right of any Indian to tribal or other property."

events.text: Designed by [Henry Berliner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Berliner) and his father [Emile Berliner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emile_Berliner), the [Berliner gyrocopter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_Helicopter) Model No. 5, capable of flying at a speed of 40 mph, to hover at an altitude of 15 ft, and to turn within a radius of 15 ft, was given its first successful demonstration. U.S. Army Lieutenant Harold R. Harris flew the machine for 1 minute and 20 seconds at [College Park Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_Park_Airport) near the [University of Maryland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Maryland), in front of U.S. Navy officials and members of the press.

The [Beverly Hills Speedway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beverly_Hills_Speedway) hosted its final race, attended by 85,000. The track was torn down afterward because the rapidly increasing real estate values had rendered the track an uneconomical use of property. [Harlan Fengler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harlan_Fengler) broke the world record for a 250-mile race, averaging 116.6 mph.
British dock workers voted to accept the offer of their employers to receive a rise of 1 shilling-per-day plus an additional shilling on June 1.

events.text: Fresh violence broke out around Italy as [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini)'s crackdown on opposition newspapers continued. Fascists seized or attacked newspaper presses while at least three were killed in rioting. Mussolini met with King [Victor Emmanuel III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III_of_Italy) and requested dictatorial powers to quell the chaos. The king refused, but gave Mussolini tacit permission to act however he considered necessary within at least the appearance of constitutional legality.

[Leo Chiozza Money](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_Chiozza_Money) testified before Britain's [Royal Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Commission) that an increase in the world's population had led to the country's food situation becoming as desperate as it was during the [war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I). "The 10 pence price of bread has doubled in recent years and looking into the future there are good prospects of its doubling again", he stated. Money recommended a "department of supply" be created to remedy the problem.

events.text: [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) made a pivotal speech in the Italian [Chamber of Deputies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Italy)). He took personal responsibility for the actions of his [Blackshirts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milizia_Volontaria_per_la_Sicurezza_Nazionale), challenged his political opponents to remove him from office and then promised to take charge of restoring order to Italy within forty-eight hours. Historians now trace this speech to the beginning of Mussolini's dictatorship.

[Cyril Brownlie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyril_Brownlie) was sent off the field for foul play during a rough Test match against England during New Zealand's [1924–25 rugby union tour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924–25_New_Zealand_rugby_union_tour_of_Britain,_Ireland_and_France) of Britain, Ireland and France. It was the first time such a severe sanction had ever been applied in an international rugby match. New Zealand won 17-11.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Camille Decoppet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camille_Decoppet), 62, Swiss Federal Councilor;  [Harry Furniss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Furniss), 80, English cartoonist, illustrator and animation pioneer

events.text: [Hans Luther](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Luther) became [Chancellor of Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chancellor_of_Germany).

Soviet leader [Joseph Stalin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Stalin) fired [Leon Trotsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leon_Trotsky) as [Commisar for Military and Naval Affairs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minister_of_Defence_(Soviet_Union)). He was replaced by [Mikhail Frunze](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mikhail_Frunze).

Blues artist Huddie Ledbetter, more popularly known as [Lead Belly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lead_Belly), was granted a full pardon by Texas governor [Pat Morris Neff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Morris_Neff), having served the minimum seven years of his prison sentence after killing one of his own relatives in a fight over a woman. Neff had been impressed by a religiously-themed song about forgiveness that [Lead Belly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lead_Belly) had written and performed for him during a visit he made to the prison the previous year.

Italy passed a new electoral bill containing a controversial provision for "plural voting". Double votes were to be given to academians, professors, those with diplomas, knights, military officers, those with any military decorations, officeholders, certain business personnel, all those paying a direct tax of 100 lira or more, and fathers of at least five children. Triple votes were to be given to members of the royal family, members of high nobility, cardinals, highly decorated war veterans, high officeholders, or anyone who met three conditions for double votes. The opposition blasted the provision as disproportionately favouring the wealthy, but [Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) contended that it would help to encourage educated and productive Italians.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Aleksey Kuropatkin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksey_Kuropatkin), 76, Russian general and Imperial Russian Minister of War

sources: [Ramblin' Man: The Life and Times of Woody Guthrie](https://archive.org/details/ramblinman00edcr) - 2004, p. 192, Publisher: W.W. Norton & Company, ISBN: 0-393-32736-1, Author: Ed Cray
Mussolini Law to Cut Italian Workers' Vote - January 10, 1925, p. 4, Author: John Clayton
Mussolini Lets Chamber Change Election Bill - January 18, 1925, p. 19, Author: Don Skene

events.text: [Miriam A. Ferguson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miriam_A._Ferguson) became the first female governor of [Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas) and the second in United States history.

Italy's [Chamber of Deputies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Italy)) repealed the "plural voting" provision in the electoral bill passed the previous day. Mussolini consented to the change upon the advice of labour leaders within his party who feared it would draw too much resentment from the working class.

births.text: [Duane Hanson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duane_Hanson), sculptor, in Alexandria, [Minnesota](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minnesota) (d. 1996)

events.text: "The Gentleman Bandit" [Gerald Chapman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerald_Chapman) was apprehended on a street in [Muncie, Indiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muncie,_Indiana). On his person he had $5,000 cash, $3,000 in bonds, $500 worth of jewelry, a pint of [nitroglycerin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/nitroglycerin), burglary tools and part of a sawed-through padlock.

births.text: [Gilles Deleuze](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilles_Deleuze), philosopher, in Paris (d. 1995)

sources: Muncie Police Snare Chapman, King of Crooks - January 19, 1925, p. 16

events.text: The [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations) opened the second session of the Second Opium Conference with the goal of reducing the worldwide trafficking and use of opium.

German Chancellor [Hans Luther](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Luther) and President [Paul Löbe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Löbe) were mercilessly heckled to an unprecedented degree in the [Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_building) as the new Cabinet was introduced and Luther outlined the new government's policies, including support for the [Dawes Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan). Cries such as "traitor", "crook" and "monarchist" rang out from republican benches.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Marie Sophie of Bavaria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marie_Sophie_of_Bavaria), 83, last [Queen consort](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen_consort) of the [Kingdom of the Two Sicilies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Two_Sicilies)

sources: Luther to Back Dawes Plan, He Tells Reichstag - January 20, 1925, p. 2, Author: [George Seldes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George Seldes)

events.text: The [Soviet–Japanese Basic Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet–Japanese_Basic_Convention) was signed, in which Japan and the Soviet Union restored diplomatic relations and reached a number of agreements on matters that had previously been disputed between them, including that of the northern part of [Sakhalin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sakhalin) Island, which Japan agreed to withdraw from in exchange for oil and coal concessions.

Chancellor [Hans Luther](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Luther) casually admitted in a speech to the [Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_building) that his Cabinet had discussed changing the form of government, but had decided to remain a constitutional republic. The statement fueled charges from republicans that Luther was preparing to restore the [German monarchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monarchy_of_Germany), as his Cabinet included several known monarchists.
The Soviet Union held mass demonstrations culminating in five minutes of silence in observation of the first anniversary of [Vladimir Lenin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin)'s death.

births.text: [Charles Aidman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Aidman), actor, in [Frankfort, Indiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frankfort,_Indiana) (d. 1993); [Arnold Skaaland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnold_Skaaland), professional wrestler and manager, in [White Plains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_Plains,_New_York), New York (d. 2007)

sources: Admits German Cabinet Talked Monarchy Plan - January 22, 1925, p. 7, Author: [George Seldes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George Seldes)

events.text: A radio [telegram](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/telegram) was sent out through the [U.S. Army Signal Corps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_Corps_(United_States_Army)) by Curtis Welch, the only doctor in [Nome, Alaska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nome,_Alaska), alerting all major towns in Alaska of an impending outbreak of [diphtheria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/diphtheria). Another was sent to the [U.S. Public Health Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Public_Health_Service) in Washington, D.C. explaining the desperate need for [antitoxin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/antitoxin).
The [Richard Eichberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Eichberg)-directed German romance film *[The Motorist Bride](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Motorist_Bride)* was released.

events.text: A [coup d'état](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Chilean_coup_d'état) in Chile overthrew the [September Junta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_Junta_of_Chile_(1924)).

births.text: [Danny Arnold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danny_Arnold), actor and television writer-producer, in New York City (d. 1995)

events.text: [Chicago Outfit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Outfit) gangster [Johnny Torrio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnny_Torrio) survived an assassination attempt when [Hymie Weiss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hymie_Weiss) and [Bugs Moran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bugs_Moran) jumped him as he and his wife were returning to their apartment from a shopping trip. Torrio was shot multiple times, but Moran's gun clicked empty when he tried to deliver a [coup de grâce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/coup_de_grâce) to Torrio's head.
A [total solar eclipse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_January_24,_1925) occurred.

events.text: The [tomb of Tutankhamun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KV62) was reopened in Egypt so [Howard Carter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howard_Carter) could resume his archaeological work. Carter was disappointed to find that the [pall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/pall_(funeral)) which had covered the [sarcophagus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/sarcophagus) was now ruined because someone in Egypt's antiquities department had carelessly stored it in a wooden shed that did not provide adequate protection from sunlight.

events.text: 300,000 units of [antitoxin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/antitoxin) were located in [Anchorage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchorage,_Alaska), enough to contain the Alaskan [diphtheria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/diphtheria) epidemic temporarily.

events.text: The [January Junta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_Junta_of_Chile_(1925)) was established to restore [Arturo Alessandri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arturo_Alessandri) to power in Chile.

A number of injuries were reported in Berlin as rioting broke out among monarchists, communists and republicans during demonstrations held on the birthday of former ex-kaiser [Wilhelm II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor).

Alaskan Territorial Governor [Scott Cordelle Bone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Cordelle_Bone) gave the final authorization for a succession of [dog sled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/dog_sled) teams to deliver the [antitoxin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/antitoxin) to [Nome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nome,_Alaska) to relieve the [diphtheria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/diphtheria) epidemic, beginning the relay that would become known as the 1925 serum run to [Nome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nome,_Alaska).

Efforts to rescue him over the next eighteen days would become a subject of national media attention.

He went 0-for-2 with a walk as the visiting [Washington Senators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Washington_Senators_(1901–60)) won 5–3. [Lou Gehrig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lou_Gehrig)'s [consecutive games-played record streak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_consecutive_games_played_streaks) began in the same game.
An intense and deadly [heat wave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/heat_wave) began in parts of the United States.

Canada claimed all land between [Alaska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska) and [Greenland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenland) up to the [North Pole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Pole).

Dr. [Charles Horace Mayo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Horace_Mayo) said that "the pace of modern life is serious, causing many of our present day ills. A return to the simple life would do away with the necessity for many doctors, but, alas, how can this be done?"

events.text: A *[Reichsgericht](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichsgericht)* judgment struck down a law for the purpose of confiscation of all the demesne lands of the Dukes of [Saxe-Coburg and Gotha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Saxe-Coburg_and_Gotha), ruling it was unconstitutional. The decision caused much public resentment in Germany and the question of [expropriation of the dynastic properties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expropriation_of_the_Princes_in_the_Weimar_Republic) of the former ruling houses of the German Empire became a contentious political subject.

[Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) proclaimed the "Battle for Wheat", aimed at increasing Italy's wheat production to the point of becoming completely self-sufficient and no longer needing to import grain.
The Australian comedy film *[The Adventures of Algy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Algy)* was released.

The [Ku Klux Klan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan) would lose a baseball game to an all black team known as the [Wichita Monrovians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wichita_Monrovians) (Monrovians 10-8 KKK)

events.text: The [National Fascist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Fascist_Party) of Italy ended its fourth and final [party congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/party_conference) in Rome. Such conferences had become increasingly unnecessary as the Fascist Party expanded its power and became essentially the state. In [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini)'s closing speech he first used the word "[totalitarian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/totalitarianism)" when he referred to "our ferocious [totalitarian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/totalitarianism) will."

deaths.text: **Died:** [Felix Klein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Felix_Klein), 76, German mathematician

As Chinese protests against imperialism spread to a strike and boycott known as the [Canton–Hong Kong strike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canton–Hong_Kong_strike), The [Shaji Massacre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaji_Massacre) occurred when British troops fired from [Shamian Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shamian_Island) across the river to [Guangzhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou), killing 52 and wounding 117.
The massive [Gros Ventre landslide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gros_Ventre_landslide) occurred in [Wyoming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wyoming).

The [Five Sisters window](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Sisters_window) at [York Minster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/York_Minster) was dedicated to the women who lost their lives in the line of service during [World War I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I)

The [Kraków University of Economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kraków_University_of_Economics) opened in Poland.

In [Richmond, Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richmond,_Virginia), several workers were buried alive when the [Church Hill Tunnel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Church_Hill_Tunnel) collapsed. One man was able to escape, giving rise to an [urban legend](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/urban_legend) known as the [Richmond Vampire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richmond_Vampire).

After eleven years of limited [Prohibition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_Russian_Empire_and_the_Soviet_Union), the Soviet Union removed all restrictions on the alcohol content of beverages.

events.text: The [Locarno Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locarno_Treaties) debated the matter of France wanting assurance of the right to cross through Germany to help Poland and [Czechoslovakia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czechoslovakia) in the event of war.

sources: French Demand Right to March Army to Poland - October 7, 1925, p. 1

events.text: Germany and France reached a deadlock in [Locarno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locarno) over the Poland and Czechoslovakia matter.

events.text: Cuban airline [Cubana de Aviación](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubana_de_Aviación) was founded.

The city of [Belgrade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgrade) in [Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia) was awarded the [Czechoslovak War Cross 1918](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Czechoslovak_War_Cross_1918).

The Italian state prosecutor absolved twenty-four officials of any responsibility for the June 1924 [Giacomo Matteotti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti) murder, ruling that they might have ordered the "sequestration" of Matteotti but not his murder, nor would they have had any knowledge of it.

[Lithuania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithuania) held the first day of a three-day mourning period for the loss of [Vilnius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilnius) to Poland in 1920. Many demonstrations were staged in which speakers declared that [Lithuania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithuania) would not have any relations with Poland until [Vilnius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilnius) was returned.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Hugo Preuß](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugo_Preuß), 64, German lawyer and politician

events.text: About 15 people were killed in [Catanzaro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catanzaro) in Italy when a train plunged over a bridge after high floodwaters weakened the bridge's supports.
Police in [Panama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama) killed two people when they opened fire on an open-air labor union meeting discussing what to do about national rent increases.

The [American Federation of Labor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Federation_of_Labor) called for a nationwide boycott of non-union products to eliminate [child labour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/child_labour) and obtain better working conditions.

events.text: Powers at [Locarno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locarno) agreed on an arrangement in which, with regard to military obligations in the [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations), due consideration would be given to Germany's special military status until such time as a general arms reduction plan could be implemented across Europe. This was thought to remove the main obstacle to Germany's entry into the [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations).
[Panama City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama_City) was effectively shut down by protestors angered by the shooting of the previous day.

births.text: [Elmore Leonard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elmore_Leonard), novelist and screenwriter, in [New Orleans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Orleans), [Louisiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louisiana) (d. 2013)

sources: German Path to League Opened by Allied Plan - October 12, 1925, p. 1

events.text: A contingent of 600 U.S. troops entered [Panama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama) at the request of [President](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_of_Panama) [Rodolfo Chiari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rodolfo_Chiari) to put down a massive renter's strike.

Two people were killed and 70 arrested in Paris during clashes between police and communists who were calling for a [general strike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/general_strike) in protest of the [Rif War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rif_War). Communist Deputy [Jacques Doriot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Doriot) was among those arrested.
Germany and the Soviet Union signed a commercial treaty designed to increase mutual trade.

sources: U.S. Soldiers Rule Panama - October 13, 1925, p. 1, Author: Gerald Martin
Paris Reds Riot Against War in Riff; Two Slain - October 13, 1925, p. 3

events.text: The British seaman's outlaw strike ended. It continued in Australia, however.
[John W. Weeks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Weeks) resigned as [United States Secretary of War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_War) due to failing health.

The jewels stolen from Mrs. Jessie Woolworth Donahue on September 30 were returned by a [private detective](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_investigator) agency. No public statement was given regarding the circumstances of their recovery.

[Dwight F. Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwight_F._Davis) became [United States Secretary of War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_War).
French forces withdrew from [Damascus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damascus) amid rioting after the French displayed corpses of [Druze](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Druze) rebels.
Landlords in [Panama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama) agreed to roll back rent increases to placate angry demonstrators.

[Dongdaemun Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dongdaemun_Stadium) opened in [Seoul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seoul), Korea.
The [P.G. Wodehouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P.G._Wodehouse) novel *[Sam the Sudden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_the_Sudden)* was published.

The [Locarno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locarno) conference ended with several agreements in place. German Foreign Minister [Gustav Stresemann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gustav_Stresemann) gave a closing speech in which he said the conference spelled a new era in European relationships, while French Foreign Minister [Aristide Briand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristide_Briand) said it marked the beginning of a new epoch of cooperation and friendship.

births.text: [Angela Lansbury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angela_Lansbury), actress and singer, in [Regent's Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regent's_Park), London, England (d. 2022)

The film *[Little Annie Rooney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Annie_Rooney_(1925_film))* starring [Mary Pickford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Pickford) was released.
[Wankdorf Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wankdorf_Stadium) opened in [Bern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bern), Switzerland.

The [Incident at [Petrich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petrich)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incident_at_[Petrich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petrich)) occurred near the Bulgarian town of [Petrich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petrich) on the border with Greece, when at least one Greek soldier was shot by someone on the Bulgarian side. Conflicting accounts exist as to what led up to the incident, but one holds that a Greek soldier was running across the border after his dog, which is why the incident is sometimes called "The War of the Stray Dog".

The [Goodman Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goodman_Theatre) opened in [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago).

events.text: Greece delivered a 48-hour ultimatum to the Bulgarian government demanding they pay an indemnity and apologize for the [Incident at Petrich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incident_at_Petrich).
