events.text: U.S. Vice Consul to Iran Robert Imbrie was beaten to death by an angry mob in [Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran) after he photographed a gathering at a sacred watering place where a miracle was said to have taken place. Police were slow to help because they were intimidated by the soldiers of the Cossack Brigade, the real authority in Iran, who were participating in the attack. Imbrie's companion [Allen Dulles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen_Dulles) survived the beating.

sources: U.S. Consul Slain in Persia - July 19, 1924, p. 1, Author: H. Basil

[Blood, Power and Hypocrisy: The Murder of Robert Imbrie and American Relations with Pahlavi Iran, 1924](http://scholarworks.boisestate.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1000&context=history_facpubs) - 1986, Publisher: Boise State University, Author: Michael Zirinsky

events.text: The [Napalpí massacre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Napalpí_massacre) occurred in [Argentina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentina) when 400 indigenous [Toba people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toba_people) were killed by Argentine police and ranchers.

[Montana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montana) Senator [Burton K. Wheeler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burton_K._Wheeler) was announced as the vice presidential nominee of the [Progressive Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_Party_(United_States,_1924–34)) and running mate of presidential nominee [Robert M. La Follette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_M._La_Follette,_Sr.).

Pitcher [Herman "Hi" Bell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hi_Bell) of the [St. Louis Cardinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_St._Louis_Cardinals_season) started and finished a doubleheader baseball game, pitching all 9 innings of a 6 to 1 win over the [Boston Braves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Boston_Braves_season) and all 9 innings of the second game of the day, a 2 to 1 win. Bell was the last Major League Baseball pitcher to pitch all 18 innings of two games on the same day.

events.text: [Paris Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics) organizer [Pierre de Coubertin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_de_Coubertin) lashed back at criticism of the games, calling the Paris press guilty of "magnifying the unpleasant incidents instead of fulfilling its duty and educating the people to a big sport ideal." He also said it was "idiotic" of the French government to build [Colombes Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stade_Olympique_Yves-du-Manoir) so far outside of Paris without the proper transportation facilities. Some of the unfortunate incidents referred to included the French booing of the American flag at a rugby match and complaints over accommodations in the tennis tournament.

Japan passed an amendment to its Nationality Law so that Japanese children born in the United States and other *jus soli* countries would automatically lose their Japanese nationality unless it was expressly retained within 14 days of birth. The amendment also allowed [dual citizens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/multiple_citizenship) in those countries to easily renounce their Japanese citizenship.

events.text: After [Norway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norway)'s parliament, the [Storting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storting), rejected a government plan for banning alcohol sale, [Prime Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_[Norway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norway)) [Abraham Berge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Berge) of [Norway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norway) and [his entire cabinet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berge's_Cabinet) announced their resignations. They would be replaced two days later.

Twenty children were trampled to death and 17 injured as patrons fled a movie house in [Veracruz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veracruz_(city)), [Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico) when the film caught fire.
The collapse of seats in a storm injured 20 people at a minor league baseball game in [Newton, Kansas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton,_Kansas).

The first [official flag of the U.S. state of Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Washington) was unveiled at the office of the Washington Secretary of State at [Olympia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympia,_Washington).

The judge in the [Leopold and Loeb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leopold_and_Loeb) case fully explained to the defendants the consequences of pleading guilty and asked them to confirm their plea, which they did. The trial now became a question of whether or not the killers would receive the [death penalty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_punishment).

World light heavyweight boxing champion [Gene Tunney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_Tunney) defeated [Georges Carpentier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georges_Carpentier) by technical knockout at the beginning of the fifteenth round at the [Polo Grounds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polo_Grounds) in [New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City).

events.text: The new issue of *[Workers' Weekly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workers'_Weekly_(UK))*, the newspaper of the [Communist Party of Great Britain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain), included a provocative article entitled "An Open Letter to the Fighting Forces" which included passages such as, "Neither in a class war nor in a military war, will you turn your guns on your fellow workers", and, "Turn your weapons on your oppressors." The question of whether to charge editor [John Ross Campbell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Ross_Campbell) with incitement to [mutiny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/mutiny) became a controversial issue known as the [Campbell Case](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Campbell_Case).
Greece announced it was expelling 50,000 [Armenians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armenians) from the country.

[American League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_League) president [Ban Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ban_Johnson) ordered umpires to speed up baseball games by cutting short trivial arguments about balls and strikes as well as preventing players from taking too much time inspecting balls on suspicion they had been tampered with.

events.text: Argentine pilot [Pedro Zanni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Zanni) and mechanic Felipe Beltrame began their attempt to fly around the world, departing [Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam) in a Fokker C-IV biplane named *Ciudad de Buenos Aires*. With stops in [Baghdad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baghdad) and [Hanoi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanoi), [Hong Kong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong), [Fuzhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzhou) and [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai), and a change of planes after the first one was destroyed the two would get as far as [Tokyo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokyo) before abandoning the trip on October 11, upon discovering that a British and American team had completed the [first aerial circumnavigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/first_aerial_circumnavigation) on September 28.

Boxer [Larry Estridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Estridge) of the British West Indies became the last person to win the [World Colored Middleweight Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Colored_Middleweight_Championship), after defeating title holder [Panama Joe Gans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama_Joe_Gans) in a 10-round bout at [Yankee Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yankee_Stadium). Afterward, separate titles for African-American and white boxers would be abandoned.
The [Ku Klux Klan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan) staged a huge rally in [Issaquah, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Issaquah,_Washington), drawing at least 13,000 people.

Although their access to materials was blocked, the two were never charged or prosecuted out of concern that the Soviets would learn that U.S. cryptanalysts were decoding Soviet cables.

events.text: The closing ceremonies of the [Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics) were conducted at [Colombes Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stade_Olympique_Yves-du-Manoir) in Paris. The United States led the [final medal count](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics_medal_table) with 45 gold medals.

Lieutnant Doxakis, a Greek Army officer in charge of enforcing martial law in the [Kato Nevrokopi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kato_Nevrokopi) region on the border of Bulgaria, [carried out the massacre of 17 Bulgarian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Tarlis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/:el:Βαθύτοπος_ΔράμαςTarlis)_incident) peasants arrested in the village of [Tarlis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/:el:Βαθύτοπος_ΔράμαςTarlis) (now Vathytopos), near the Greco-Bulgarian border. Lieutenant Doxakis told his commander that their 10-soldier unit had come under attack from Bulgarian guerrillas and that they were forced to kill the prisoners who were attempting to escape.

The first Stånga Games, were held on the Swedish island of [Gotland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gotland) as an annual competition of traditional Swedish Gothic sports, including [paerk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pärk), a team game similar to a cross between baseball and football; [varpa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/varpa), similar to horseshoe pitching; *Herre på stång* (a fight between two men on a pole) and three variations of [tug of war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/tug_of_war).

events.text: The secret "[May Manifesto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/May_Manifesto)" of the [Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_Macedonian_Revolutionary_Organisation) (IMRO) was published after IMRO leader [Todor Aleksandrov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Todor_Aleksandrov) refused to cooperate with the Soviet Union's wishes for IMRO to join [Comintern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comintern). Despite Alexandrov's claims that the publication was a forgery, he would be assassinated the following month.

The [revolt by Brazilian Army officers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/São_Paulo_Revolt_of_1924) in [São Paulo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/São_Paulo) ended after the rebels quietly withdrew to [Campinas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Campinas). By the time that the government realized that the rebels had quit, the last rebels had been gone from the city for five hours. The city was recaptured by the government, at a cost of more than 500 deaths and almost 5,000 injuries. Sao Paulo state governor [Carlos de Campos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_de_Campos), who had fled the city on July 8, returned to his office later in the day.

[Ljubomir Davidović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ljubomir_Davidović) became [Prime Minister of Yugoslavia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Yugoslavia) after [Nikola Pašić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikola_Pašić) resigned.

events.text: The practicality of [airmail](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/airmail) was demonstrated for the public when the U.S. Army air service carried a cargo of mail from [Nashville, Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nashville,_Tennessee) to [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago) in 2 hours and 29 minutes.
Germany and the Soviet Union signed a trade agreement which ended the two-month standoff over the Berlin police raid.

events.text: The [Commonwealth Electoral Act 1924](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electoral_system_of_Australia), requiring [compulsory voting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/compulsory_voting) in Australian national elections, was given [royal assent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/royal_assent) by [George V](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_V) in his capacity as [King of Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_of_Australia). The law, in effect 100 years later, provides for a requirement that [enrolled voters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/electoral_register) explain their absence if they fail to vote, and a fine of up to A$170 if no adequate excuse is given. The Act was sponsored after fewer than 60% of voters cast ballots in the 1922 federal election; participation increased to 91% in 1925 election.

The Allied Reparations Commission released a report estimating that Germany had only paid about half the amounts that the French, Belgians and English demanded for occupying the [Rhineland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Rhineland) and [Ruhr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Ruhr).

events.text: Austrian Chancellor [Ignaz Seipel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ignaz_Seipel) was shot by a disgruntled worker. A bullet was extracted from his lung and he survived.

The [June Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/June_Revolution) began in [Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania) as an army of 6,000 nationalists marched on [Tirana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tirana).
[Raymond Poincaré](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Poincaré) resigned as [Prime Minister of France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_France) along with his entire cabinet.

The Bengal Provincial Congress Committee passed a resolution acknowledging the sacrifice of [Gopinath Saha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gopinath_Saha). It stated that 'this conference, while denouncing and dissociating itself from violence and adhering to the principle of non-violence, appreciates [Gopinath Saha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gopinath_Saha)'s idea of self-sacrifice, misguided though it is, in respect of the country's best interest and expresses respect for such self-sacrifice.' [Mahatma Gandhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi) opposed the resolution.

What would become one of the most widely-heard radio stations in the U.S. as well as a widely-seen television station was created as the *Chicago *Tribune** newspaper purchased Chicago's WDAP radio station and renamed it [WGN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WGN_(AM)), an abbreviation of the *Tribune* slogan, "World's Greatest Newspaper".

events.text: In the United States, the [Indian Citizenship Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Citizenship_Act) was signed into law, recognizing U.S. citizenship for all indigenous Native Americans (referred to at the time as "[American Indians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States)") who had been born within the United States and its territories, regardless of whether they had been granted citizenship by other means, such as service in the U.S. military or formal renunciation of tribal affiliation. At the time, there were 300,000 Native Americans in the U.S. out of a population that had been measured in 1920 as 106,021,537 people. Of the 300,000 there were 175,000 who had already been granted U.S. citizenship and the Act, signed by U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge), extended full rights to the remaining 125,000 not already qualified.

In the Soviet Union, the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee selected the seven members of the *de facto* rulers of the nation, the Party's [Politburo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politburo_of_the_13th_Congress_of_the_All-Union_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)). To replace the vacancy left by the death of [Vladimir Lenin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin), candidate member [Nikolai Bukharin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolai_Bukharin) was elevated to full status, while full members [Joseph Stalin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Stalin), [Leon Trotsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leon_Trotsky), [Alexei Rykov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexei_Rykov), [Lev Kamenev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lev_Kamenev), [Mikhail Tomsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mikhail_Tomsky) and [Grigory Zinoviev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grigory_Zinoviev) were re-elected.
U.S. President Coolidge also signed the [Revenue Act of 1924](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revenue_Act_of_1924) into law, despite his many criticisms of the bill.

The [Frank Lloyd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Lloyd)-directed film *[The Sea Hawk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sea_Hawk_(1924_film))* premiered at the [Astor Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astor_Theatre,_New_York_City) in New York City.
In Germany, miners in the [Ruhr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruhr) ended their strike after accepting a 6 percent wage increase.

events.text: The [Gila Wilderness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gila_Wilderness), which would become the first government-protected [wilderness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/wilderness) area (defined as an area not significantly affected by human activity) in the world, was founded in the U.S. state of [New Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Mexico) as the first [wilderness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/wilderness) area in the National Forest System. The designation followed the lobbying efforts of [Aldo Leopold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aldo_Leopold), the [United States Forest Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Forest_Service) supervisor of the [Carson National Forest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_National_Forest), who proposed that the headwaters area of the [Gila River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gila_River) should be preserved by an administrative process of excluding roads and denying use permits.

In [[Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania)), fighting was reported in [Shkodër](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shkodër) and [Vlorë](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vlorë), while an Italian destroyer arrived at the port of [Durrës](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durrës). It was thought that Italy might intervene in the [June Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/June_Revolution) if any Italian interests in [[Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania)) were threatened. Anti-government forces in [[Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania)) took [Shkodër](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shkodër) the next day.

events.text: [Indian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India) physicist [Satyendra Nath Bose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyendra_Nath_Bose) contacted [Albert Einstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Einstein) to report his development of what would become known as the [Bose–Einstein statistics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bose–Einstein_statistics). Bose mailed his short manuscript, *Planck's Law and the Light Quantum Hypothesis* to Einstein to get it published after the prestigious journal *[Philosophical Magazine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophical_Magazine)* rejected it. Einstein, recognizing the importance of the paper, translated it from [English](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language) into [German](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language) himself and submitted it on Bose's behalf to the prestigious *[Zeitschrift für Physik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeitschrift_für_Physik)*. Einstein would later apply Bose's principles on particles with mass and quickly predict the [Bose-Einstein condensate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bose-Einstein_condensate).

The [E.M. Forster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E.M._Forster) novel *[A Passage to India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Passage_to_India)* was first published, originally by the British imprint [Edward Arnold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Arnold_(publisher)). It would be published in the U.S. August 14, 1924, by [Harcourt, Brace and Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harcourt_Brace).

events.text: [Giacomo Matteotti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti), a socialist member of the Italian Chamber of Deputies and one of [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini)'s most outspoken critics, was kidnapped in broad daylight. On May 30, he had spoken out against Prime Minister Mussolini and the Fascist movement in general. His fate would be a mystery until his body was found in August, with signs that he had been beaten to death. Six men were arrested for the crime, including [Amerigo Dumini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amerigo_Dumini), who would confess a week later. Mussolini said he would order summary justice if any of the kidnappers were identified.

The [Anglo-Iraqi Treaty of 1922](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Iraqi_Treaty_of_1922), making Iraq a self-governing British [protectorate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/protectorate), was ratified by the Iraqi Constituent Assembly by a vote of 36 to 25, with the United Kingdom having control of Iraq's foreign affairs and Iraq handling its own domestic affairs.

The [June Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/June_Revolution) was completed in [Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania) when anti-government forces took the [Albania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania)n capital, [Tirana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tirana).

The [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Republican_National_Convention) opened in [Cleveland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland), [Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio).

events.text: The [International Football Association Board](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Football_Association_Board) legalized the scoring of a goal by [corner kick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/corner_kick) in advance of the 1924 Summer Olympics competition. The first score by [corner kick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/corner_kick) in international play would be made on October 2, 1924, by [Cesáreo Onzari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesáreo_Onzari) of the [Argentina national football team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team) in 2 to 1 win over the Olympic champion [Uruguay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team), and the goal was called "an Olympico" as a result.

[Aldo Finzi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aldo_Finzi_(politician)) resigned as Italy's Under Secretary of State over the [Matteotti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti) disappearance, explaining he was doing so in order to defend himself from "libelous accusations" spread against him by the opposition. Rome's Chief of Police, [Emilio De Bono](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emilio_De_Bono), resigned three days later.

events.text: The [Lone Scouts of America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lone_Scouts_of_America), founded in 1915 by newspaper publisher [W. D Boyce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_D._Boyce) as a rural version of the Boy Scouts, merged with the [Boy Scouts of America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boy_Scouts_of_America) and discontinued operations.

[Fan Noli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fan_Noli) (Theofan Stilian Noli), one of the leaders of Albania's [June Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/June_Revolution), formed a government of ministers with himself as Prime Minister of Albania.

King [Victor Emmanuel III of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III_of_Italy) held an extraordinary council with former Prime Ministers and members of the royal family to discuss the Matteotti crisis as [Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini)'s hold on power appeared increasingly tenuous. Italian Fascist politician [Cesare Rossi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesare_Rossi_(politician)) surrendered to police the same day after having been in hiding. Another Fascist, [Giovanni Marinelli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Marinelli), was arrested three days later.

The much-delayed trial of [Mabel Normand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mabel_Normand)'s chauffeur, over the New Year's Day shooting of millionaire Courtland S. Dines, opened in Los Angeles. [Edna Purviance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edna_Purviance) once again testified that she was out of the room when the shooting happened.

The ruling [South African Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_African_Party), led by Prime Minister [Jan Smuts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Smuts), lost 24 of its 77 seats, while the [National Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._B._M._Hertzog) of [J. B. M. Hertzog](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._B._M._Hertzog) gained 19 seats for 63 overall, five short of a majority.

[Mabel Normand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mabel_Normand)'s chauffeur was acquitted on the assault charge from the New Year's Day shooting, though he was immediately re-arrested on a separate liquor charge. events.text: U.S. Army First Lieutenant [Russell Maughan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russell_Maughan) successfully made the first [dawn-to-dusk transcontinental flight across the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/dawn-to-dusk_transcontinental_flight_across_the_United_States), landing at [Crissy Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crissy_Field) in [San Francisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco) at 9:46 in the evening local time, one minute before sundown, after having departed earlier on the same day from [Mitchel Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitchel_Field) on Long Island near [Garden City, New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garden_City,_New_York) at 3:58 in the morning local time. During his flight of 20 hours and 48 minutes, in a [Curtiss P-1 Hawk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curtiss_P-1_Hawk), he made refueling stops at [Dayton, Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio); [St. Joseph, Missouri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Joseph,_Missouri); [North Platte, Nebraska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Platte,_Nebraska); [Cheyenne, Wyoming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheyenne,_Wyoming) and the [Bonneville Salt Flats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonneville_Salt_Flats) at [Salduro, Utah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salduro,_Utah) before completing a journey of 2670 mi.

German serial killer [Fritz Haarmann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fritz_Haarmann), called the Butcher of Hanover, was arrested eight days after murdering and dismembering his final victim, Erich de Vries. Haarmann was implicated by another teenager who had been arrested at Hanover station the night before. Tried and convicted on 24 of 27 charges of murder, Haarmann would be beheaded on April 15, 1925.

events.text: [Attorney General](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attorney_General_of_Ireland) [Hugh Kennedy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugh_Kennedy_(judge)) took office as the first [Chief Justice of Ireland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_Ireland), presiding over the [Supreme Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Ireland) of the [Irish Free State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Free_State).

The [Democratic National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Democratic_National_Convention) opened at [Madison Square Garden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden_(1890)) in New York City. Former Treasury Secretary [William Gibbs McAdoo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Gibbs_McAdoo) was considered the [front-runner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/front-runner) going into the convention, but required two-thirds of the 1,092 delegate votes for a majority. The convention would last 16 days before a nominee would be picked on July 9.

The brand name for [Kleenex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kleenex), which would become synonymous with [facial tissue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/facial_tissue), was used for the first time in commerce, according to an application for registered trademark filed with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) by the original manufacturer, the Cellucotton Products Company of [Neenah, Wisconsin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neenah,_Wisconsin).

The Italian Senate held a ceremony commemorating [Giacomo Matteotti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti), now presumed dead. [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) promised to reform his government and then put it to a vote of confidence the last week of July, but said that the Fascists did not need to be removed from power over the crisis.

The *New York *Daily Mirror** was launched by publisher [William Randolph Hearst](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Randolph_Hearst) as a morning paper in New York City, to compete against the popular *[New York Daily News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Daily_News)*. Hearst, who already owned the morning *New York American* and the *New York Evening Journal*, would sell the *Daily Mirror* in 1928 and then buy it back in 1932; the paper would continue publication until October 16, 1963.

events.text: The "[Aventine Secession](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aventine_Secession_(20th_century))" took place as 123 members of the opposition in the [Italian Chamber of Deputies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(Kingdom_of_Italy)) walked out of the Chamber, retreated to [Aventine Hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aventine_Hill) and gave Premier [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) an ultimatum. The Deputies demanded an acknowledgment of government responsibility for Fascist crimes, a complete and thorough investigation of the Matteotti affair and the abolition of the [Blackshirts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milizia_Volontaria_per_la_Sicurezza_Nazionale). If the government did not accede, the ultimatum read, the opposition would stage a boycott of parliament. On the same day, 10 minutes of silence were observed all over Italy in respect for [Giacomo Matteotti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti). Ultimately, the strategy of the 123 legislators would backfire and they would be declared on November 9, 1926, to have forfeited their seats, clearing the way legally for Italy to become a one-party state under Fascist control.

A plank denouncing the [Ku Klux Klan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan) by name was also narrowly rejected.

events.text: [Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico)'s President [Álvaro Obregón](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Álvaro_Obregón) announced that he was suspending further payments from the Mexican Treasury to the International Committee of Bankers on [Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico) (ICBM), abrogating the [De la Huerta–Lamont Treaty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_la_Huerta–Lamont_Treaty) that had been signed on June 16, 1922. [Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico) had paid $16,250,000 to the ICBM Bankers in 1922 and 1923.

After the first day of balloting and 15 rounds of voting, and no candidate receiving the necessary 729 votes for a two-thirds majority, the [Democratic National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Democratic_National_Convention) adjourned at midnight. [William Gibbs McAdoo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Gibbs_McAdoo) (with 479 votes) and [Al Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Smith) (with 305.5) were deadlocked in balloting. On the first ballot, McAdoo had 431.5 and Smith 241, with the eventual nominee in seventh place with 31.
[J. B. M. Hertzog](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._B._M._Hertzog) took office as the new [Prime Minister of South Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_South_Africa).

Sixteen-year-old Calvin Coolidge Jr. played a tennis match on the [White House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House) tennis court wearing tennis shoes but no socks. During the course of the match he developed a toe blister that would lead to fatal [blood poisoning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/blood_poisoning).

Dutch-born Jewish poet [Jacob Israël de Haan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_Israël_de_Haan) was assassinated in Jerusalem by the [Avraham Tehomi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avraham_Tehomi) on the orders of [Haganah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haganah) leader [Yitzhak Ben-Zvi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yitzhak_Ben-Zvi) for his anti-Zionist activity and contacts with Arab leaders. Tehomi waited outside of the Shaare Zedek Hospital for De Haan, then shot him three times.

events.text: The [Geneva Protocol for the Pacific Settlement of International Disputes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geneva_Protocol_(1924)) received preliminary approval at the [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations). The agreement required formal approval to be given by all governments concerned, and was understood to have little meaning until the conclusion of the world disarmament conference was concluded the next year. The Protocol included a very controversial piece of wording added at the insistence of Japan, which allowed for the restriction of immigration to become a matter of international jurisdiction if it endangered the peace.

[Cesáreo Onzari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cesáreo_Onzari) of the [Argentina national football team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team) scored the first goal from a [corner kick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/corner_kick) in international play after the rules of soccer football had been amended on June 14 by the [International Football Association Board](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Football_Association_Board). The first goal in a professional league game had come on August 23. Onzri's goal came against [Uruguay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team), which had recently won the [1924 Olympic title](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_at_the_1924_Summer_Olympics). For this reason the direct goal from a [corner kick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/corner_kick) is called an *Olympic goal* or *gol olímpico* in Latin America.

Baseball commissioner [Kenesaw Mountain Landis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenesaw_Mountain_Landis) said the [World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_World_Series) would go forward despite the bribery scandal. "Inside of four days after the attempted bribery of [Sand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinie_Sand) of the [Phillies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies) had occurred, the guilty persons had been placed on baseball's ineligible list. Surely our speedy action in the matter must indicate that the game is being kept clean", he said.

deaths.text: **Died:** [William B. Ross](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_B._Ross), 50, [Governor of Wyoming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_governors_of_Wyoming) since 1923, died of complications from an appendectomy he had undergone one week earlier. He was temporarily succeeded by Secretary of State [Frank Lucas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Lucas_(Wyoming_politician)) pending a special election Governor Ross's widow, [Nellie Tayloe Ross](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nellie_Tayloe_Ross), run in the election and win the governorship.

events.text: Britain's *[Evening Standard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_Evening_Standard)* blasted the [Geneva Protocol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geneva_Protocol_(1924)) and called on Australia, Canada and New Zealand to quit the [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations) over it, pointing out that if Australia refused to submit to Japan's demand that it alter its immigration policy, the British fleet might be called upon to impose a naval [blockade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/blockade) in the name of the League.
A conference in London between the United Kingdom and [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt) on the issue of [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt)ian independence ended without success.

A feud erupted between major league baseball commissioner [Kenesaw Mountain Landis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenesaw_Mountain_Landis) and [American League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_League) president [Ban Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ban_Johnson). Johnson told the media that he would pursue an independent investigation of the circumstances under which the [New York Giants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_New_York_Giants_(NL)) won the pennant, and that they should be forbidden from playing in the World Series. Johnson called Landis a "wild-eyed, crazy nut" who was "protecting the crooks" by failing to investigate the scandal more thoroughly.

The [First Division Monument](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Division_Monument) was dedicated in Washington, D.C. During his dedication speech, U.S. President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) briefly commenting on the [Geneva Protocol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geneva_Protocol_(1924)), saying, "We do not propose to entrust to any other power or combination of powers any authority to make up our minds for us."

Skeel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burt_E._Skeel), 30, American racing pilot, was killed while competing in the [Pulitzer Trophy Race](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Air_Races) at [Wilbur Wright Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base) in [Dayton, Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio). Skeel's Curtiss Aircraft flyer lost both wings as he was traveling at high speed at an atltitude of 2000 ft.

events.text: A harsh ordinance was issued in [British India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Raj) aimed at suppressing "terrorists". Pro-independence nationalists such as [Subhas Chandra Bose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subhas_Chandra_Bose) would be arrested under the new law.

[Carlos José Solórzano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_José_Solórzano) was [elected](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Nicaraguan_general_election) to be [President of Nicaragua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Nicaragua), to take office on January 1. He would be overthrown on March 14, 1926.

Seven people died and 48 were injured during rioting in [Camagüey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camagüey), [Cuba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuba), during a political rally for presidential candidate Mario Menocal ahead of the country's [general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Cuban_general_election).

events.text: [Radio Marconi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rai_Radio_1), the first radio station in [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italy) for the general public, began broadcasting from [Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rome) as a service of [Unione radiofonica italiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unione_radiofonica_italiana) (URI). The station, with call sign 1-RO, transmitted at the 425 metre wavelength, equivalent to the 710 AM radio frequency. At 9:00 in the evening, Maria Luisa Boncompagni read an announcement that the first program would be an "inaugural symphony concert", followed by an introduction by Ines Viviani Donarelli that she and three other members of a string quartet would perform [Joseph Haydn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Haydn)'s [Opus 7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_compositions_by_Joseph_Haydn).

[Ali of Hejaz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ali_of_Hejaz) was proclaimed the new [King of Hejaz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hejaz) after his father, [King Hussein bin Ali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hussein_bin_Ali,_King_of_Hejaz) fled from [Mecca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mecca) to [Jeddah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeddah) to avoid the [conquest of Nejd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unification_of_Saudi_Arabia) by the neighboring [Sultanate of Nejd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sultanate_of_Nejd), led by [Ibn Saud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibn_Saud).

The classic German silent film *[Das Wachsfigurenkabinett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waxworks_(film))* (*Waxworks*), directed by [Paul Leni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Leni), premiered in Austria.

events.text: The British [Labour Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)) ruled out affiliation with the [Communist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain) by a card vote of 3,185,000 to 193,000 at Labour's national congress in London. "Communism is nothing practical. It is a product of [czarism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia) and war betrayal, and as such we will have nothing to do with it", Prime Minister [Ramsay MacDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald) said.

The Soviet Union's Council of People's Commissars, the [Sovnarkom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sovnarkom), declared an amnesty to all participants of the recent [August Uprising](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_Uprising) against the [Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic) on the condition that they surrender their weapons voluntarily.

The United States [accepted diplomatic relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ireland–United_States_relations) with the [Irish Free State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Free_State), separately from the United Kingdom, as [Timothy Smiddy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timothy_Smiddy) was accepted by the U.S. as Minister Plenipotentiary from Ireland, with an office in [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C.). The U.S. would not send a diplomat to Ireland until 1927.

events.text: In the UK, King [George V](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_V) dissolved parliament at the request of Prime Minister [Ramsay MacDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald), and scheduled new elections for the House of Commons for October 29.

events.text: [Walter Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Johnson) pitched four shutout innings of relief as the [Washington Senators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Washington_Senators_(1901–60)) beat the [New York Giants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_New_York_Giants_(NL)), 4 to 3, in 12 innings to win the [World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_World_Series) in a winner-take-all Game 7. This game is considered by some sports historians to be one of the greatest baseball games ever played and the conclusion of one of the most exciting [World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_World_Series) of all time.
The Commonwealth Electoral Act made [compulsory voting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/compulsory_voting) the law in Australia.

The [Office of the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign,_Commonwealth_and_Development_Office) in the United Kingdom received the fabricated [Zinoviev letter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zinoviev_letter), purporting to be a directive from the Soviet Union's director of [Comintern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_International) to order the [Communist Party of Great Britain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain) to undermine the British government. The letter came two days after the vote of no confidence against Prime Minister MacDonald and was leaked by Conservative Party members within the Foreign Office to the local news media, including the *[Daily Mail](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daily_Mail)* newspaper, in advance of the elections set for October 29.

events.text: The [H. J. Heinz Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._J._Heinz_Company) celebrated its fifty-fifth birthday with banquets in different American cities. President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) used the occasion to make a radio address from the [White House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House) about business that was carried in 70 cities.

Baseball commissioner [Kenesaw Mountain Landis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenesaw_Mountain_Landis) made his first public response to [Ban Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ban_Johnson)'s criticisms of his handling of the recent bribery scandal, saying, "Answer Johnson? I don't have to... it has been done by the President of the United States." [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge), who attended three of the games played in Washington, said that "The contests which I witnessed maintained throughout a high degree of skill and every evidence of a high class of sportsmanship that will bring to every observer an increased respect for and confidence in our national game."

events.text: The [Tajik Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tajik_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic), which would later become the independent nation of [Tajikistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tajikistan), was created as a partially self-governing entity with the new [Uzbek SSR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzbek_SSR) in the Soviet Union. It would become the Tadzhik Soviet Socialist Republic and one of the constituent republics of the Soviet Union on December 5, 1929, and become independent upon the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991.

[Hjalmar Branting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hjalmar_Branting) formed a government as the new [Prime Minister of Sweden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Sweden) after the resignation of [Ernst Trygger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Trygger), whose coalition government had lost power in the [September elections for the Riksdag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Swedish_general_election). Terminally ill, Branting would serve for less than three months before resigning in favor of Commerce and Industry Minister [Rickard Sandler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rickard_Sandler).

events.text: In [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany), [Adolf Hitler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolf_Hitler), incarcerated for organizing the 1923 attempt to overthrow the [Weimar Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weimar_Republic) government, had a statement printed admitting that he was born in the Austro-Hungarian Empire rather than in [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany). Hitler, who was facing deportation back to Austria, argued that he had lost his Austrian citizenship after volunteering to serve in the German Army during World War I and said that "I never felt as an Austrian citizen but always as a German only... It was this mentality that made me draw the ultimate conclusion and do military service in the German Army. Hitler would not renounce his Austrian citizenship until April 7, 1925, and would not become a citizen of [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany) until 1932 upon his appointment as a state government official.

events.text: The first [media event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/media_event) in a U.S. presidential campaign took place 18 days before the November 4 election day as President [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) hosted a breakfast at the [White House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House) for an all-star cast of [Broadway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadway_theatre) actors and actresses, including [Al Jolson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Jolson), [Ed Wynn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Wynn), [John Drew Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Drew_Jr.), [Raymond Hitchcock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Hitchcock_(actor)), [Charlotte Greenwood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte_Greenwood) and [Francine Larrimore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francine_Larrimore). The breakfast, the brainchild of public relations specialist [Edward Bernays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Bernays), marked a groundbreaking example of a staged attempt to improve a politician's image by having him associate with popular celebrities. Bernays would recall decades later that "In 1924 this was a startling idea," and that the "non-event" of celebrity entertainers counteracted Coolidge's sour personality.

A group of politicians, dissatisfied with the Republic of **T**urkey being [a one-party state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey), organized a competitor to the Republican **P**eople's **P**arty (****C****umhuriyet **H**alk **P**artisi or ****C******H****P**) of **P**resident [Mustafa Kemal Atatürk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atatürk). ****C****reated by [Kâzım Karabekir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kâzım_Karabekir), the rival **P**rogressive Republican **P**arty (**T**eraḳḳîperver ****C****umhûriyet **F**ırḳası or **T******C******F**) would last for less than seven months before being banned on June 5, 1925.

events.text: The first "round-the-world" wireless radio communication took place between locations in [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand) and the [United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom) as favorable atmospheric conditions permitted amateur [ham radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ham_radio) operators to hear each other over a distance of more than 19000 km. Amateurs in both countries heard signals the night before. Transmitting on the 80-metre short wave band from [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand), at Waiheua near [Dunedin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunedin), [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand), telegraphed the message, in [Morse code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morse_code), "Z4AA calling. Pass the following to Radio Society of Great Britain. Greetings from [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand). Z4AA calling. Pass following to G2OD. Your signals strong last night." Mr. E. J. Simmonds of [Gerrards Cross](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerrards_Cross), [Buckinghamshire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buckinghamshire) in [England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England), operator of G2OD, acknowledged the call from Z4AA and asked for confirmation by [cable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/radiogram_(message)). A little more than five hours later, he was handed a message from Dell that said, "Congratulations on first trans-world message. Dell. Waiheua, [Dunedin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunedin), [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand)." Later in the day, Cecil W. Goyder of [Hendon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hendon), near [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London) exchanged messages with Mr. Bell "for over an hour."

In one of the most anticipated games of the [1924 college football season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_college_football_season), played before 60,000 at the [Polo Grounds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polo_Grounds) stadium in New York City, [Notre Dame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Notre_Dame_Fighting_Irish_football_team) defeated [Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Army_Cadets_football_team), 13 to 7. That evening, nationally syndicated sportswriter [Grantland Rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grantland_Rice) wrote his famous "Four Horsemen" column that was published in the next day's newspapers.

Police in Berlin put on a media display of all the evidence they had uncovered of a "false passport factory" that communist agents used to operate in the United States and other countries under false identities.

events.text: The [1924 [Cuba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuba) hurricane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_[Cuba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuba)_hurricane), the earliest officially classified [Category 5 Atlantic hurricane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Category_5_Atlantic_hurricanes), struck western [Cuba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuba) in [Pinar del Río Province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinar_del_Río_Province) and killed 90 people.

The day after [Notre Dame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Notre_Dame_Fighting_Irish_football_team)'s defeat of Army in football, sportswriter [Grantland Rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grantland_Rice)'s famous newspaper account was published nationwide. "Outlined against a blue-gray October sky," Rice wrote, "the [Four Horsemen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_Horsemen_of_the_Apocalypse) rode again. In dramatic lore they are known as [famine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/famine), [pestilence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/infectious_disease), [destruction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/global_catastrophic_risk) and [death](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/death). These are only aliases. Their real names are: [Stuhldreher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Stuhldreher), [Miller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don_Miller_(American_football,_born_1902)), [Crowley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Crowley) and [Layden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elmer_Layden)."

The film *[The Border Legion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Border_Legion_(1924_film))*, based on the 1916 novel by [Zane Grey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zane_Grey) and starring [Antonio Moreno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_Moreno) and [Helene Chadwick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helene_Chadwick) premiered in New York City, before being released nationwide by [Paramount Pictures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Pictures).
[Antonio Ascari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_Ascari) of [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italy) won the [Italian Grand Prix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Grand_Prix).

events.text: The [Hilldale Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilldale_Club) (near [Philadelphia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia)) of the [Eastern Colored League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Colored_League) (ECL) defeated the [Kansas City Monarchs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Monarchs) of the [Negro National League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negro_National_League_(1920–1931)), 5 to 0, to win the championship baseball game of the best-5-of-9 [Colored World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Colored_World_Series), five games to four.

German President [Friedrich Ebert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert) dissolved the [Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic)) and called for new elections on December 7. The cabinet of Chancellor [Wilhelm Marx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_Marx) fell apart after he granted three seats to nationalist parties in exchange for their voting to ratify the [Dawes Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan), and the various factions were unable to cooperate afterward.

An explosion of gunpowder killed 14 servicemen on the U.S. Navy light cruiser USS *Trenton* (CL-11) as it was conducting gunnery drills off the [Virginia Capes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_Capes).

In central Africa, the former German colony of [Ruanda-Urundi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruanda-Urundi) became [League of Nations mandate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations_mandate) territory under the administration of [Belgium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgium), which controlled the neighboring colony of the [Belgian Congo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgian_Congo). With a capital at [Usumbura](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bujumbura) (now Bujumbura in [Burundi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burundi)), the mandate would later be divided into the nations of [Rwanda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rwanda) (speakers of the [Kinyarwanda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinyarwanda) Bantu dialect) and [Burundi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burundi) (speakers of the [Kirundi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirundi) Bantu dialect).

The [National Association of Schools of Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_of_Schools_of_Music) (NASM) was founded by leaders from six American music schools at a convention in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh).

events.text: [Elections were held](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Norwegian_parliamentary_election) for the 150 seats of Norway's parliament, the *[Storting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storting)*. The coalition government of the conservative [Conservative Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservative_Party_(Norway)) (Høyre) and the liberal [Venstre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_Party_(Norway)), led by Prime Minister [Johan Ludwig Mowinckel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johan_Ludwig_Mowinckel)), maintained its slim majority, with 77 seats.

The first elections in Canada under the "[Indian Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Act)" were held for the [Six Nations Band of Indians Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Nations_of_the_Grand_River_Elected_Council), a partially self-governing territory that served as a Canadian government forced replacement of the traditional [Six Nations Iroquois Confederacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Nations_Iroquois_Confederacy) (the *Haudenosaunee*). The council had representatives for the [Mohawk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohawk_people), [Oneida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oneida_people), [Onondaga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Onondaga_people), [Cayuga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cayuga_people), [Seneca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seneca_people) and [Tuscarora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuscarora_people) people. The Council's first meeting was subsequently held the next day at the Iroquois capital in [Ohsweken, Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohsweken,_Ontario).

The [German National People's Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_National_People's_Party) issued an official proclamation announcing itself in favour of restoring the monarchy and terminating the [Treaty of Versailles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles) and the [Dawes Plan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawes_Plan).

Smedley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_C._Smedley) with the opening in [Santa Ana, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Ana,_California), of the first Toastmasters Club.

[William Joyce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Joyce), a member of the [British Fascists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Fascists), was slashed with a razor by a communist hooligan while stewarding a meeting of Conservatives in North Lambeth, London. [William Joyce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Joyce) would later gain notoriety as Nazi propagandist "[Lord Haw-Haw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Haw-Haw)" and would be hanged for treason in 1946.

events.text: General [Feng Yuxiang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feng_Yuxiang), leading the 11th Division of the Chinese Army, carried out the [Beijing Coup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing_Coup), arriving in China's capital and taking the city unopposed and overthrowing [President](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_Republic_of_China) [Cao Kun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cao_Kun). Feng's troops halted all railway traffic and cut telephone and telegraph communications, then set up a temporary dictatorship. After issuing emergency decrees, Feng installed [Huang Fu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huang_Fu) as the new Chinese president.

Voters in the Canadian province of [Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontario) [rejected a proposal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Ontario_[prohibition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/prohibition)_referendum) to end the [prohibition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/prohibition) of sales of liquor. By a margin of 51.5% to 48.5%, chose to continue the [Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontario) Temperance Act.

events.text: Irish independence activist [Éamon de Valera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Éamon_de_Valera) was arrested in [Newry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newry) as he arrived at a meeting of the [Sinn Féin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinn_Féin) party. He was charged with entering a prohibited area under the Civil Powers Act.

[Corneliu Codreanu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corneliu_Zelea_Codreanu), leader of Romania's fascist *[Iron Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iron_Guard)* organization, assassinated Constantin Manciu, the police chief of the city of [Iași](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iași), and shot several other policemen. Codreanu would be acquitted on the grounds that he had acted in self-defense, despite invading the meeting and shooting Manciu from behind.

The British [Foreign Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_and_Commonwealth_Office) released the [Zinoviev letter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zinoviev_letter), allegedly a directive from Moscow addressed to the [Communist Party of Great Britain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain) to increase labor unrest in the UK, and lodged a protest with the Soviet embassy.
Belgium signed the [Geneva Protocol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geneva_Protocol_(1924)).

Crown Princes [Wilhem of Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm,_German_Crown_Prince) and [Rupprecht of Bavaria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rupprecht,_Crown_Prince_of_Bavaria) reconciled after a six-year feud.
The [Prince of Wales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_VIII) ended his visit to the United States and Canada.

events.text: Poor ventilation in a chemical processing plant caused a mass accident in [Elizabeth, New Jersey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth,_New_Jersey) that injured 40 employees of the [Bayway Refinery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayway_Refinery) of the [Standard Oil Company of New Jersey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Oil_Company_of_New_Jersey), where leaded gasoline (called "ethyl" by the Standard Oil dealers) was produced using the additive [tetraethyllead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/tetraethyllead) (TEL). Ernest Oelgart became the first fatality after becoming paranoid following inhalation of fumes, and died later in the day. By the end of the week, 10 more workers were dead at Standard Oil plants.

The Soviet Union denied the authenticity of the [Zinoviev letter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zinoviev_letter) (which purported to be a directive to British Communists to overthrow the government) and demanded an apology from Britain.

events.text: In a reorganization of the Soviet Union's central Asian republics, the [Turkestan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkestan_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic), the [Bukharan People's Soviet Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bukharan_People's_Soviet_Republic), and the [Khorezm People's Soviet Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khorezm_People's_Soviet_Republic), were broken up along ethnic lines to create the [Uzbek SSR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzbek_Soviet_Socialist_Republic) and four other autonomous republics that would eventually become the independent nations of [Uzbekistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzbekistan), [Turkmenistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkmenistan), [Tajikistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tajikistan), [Kyrgyzstan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyrgyzstan) and [Kazakhstan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kazakhstan).

Two days before [elections for the House of Commons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_United_Kingdom_general_election), Prime Minister [Ramsay MacDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramsay_MacDonald) said he believed the [Zinoviev letter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zinoviev_letter) was authentic and denied that the British government had delayed its publication.

deaths.text: [Percy Haughton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percy_Haughton), 48, American college football coach for [Columbia University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_Columbia_Lions_football_team) since 1923, and previously for [Harvard University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_University) (1908-1916), died of acute indigestion after becoming ill while on the Columbia football field. His death came two days after Columbia's 27 to 3 win over [Williams College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Williams_Ephs_football). Coach Haughton, who had guided Harvard to four unbeaten football seasons, would later be inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame.

[Abraham Ángel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Ángel) ([Abraham Ángel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Ángel) Card), 19, Mexican painter, was found dead of a [cocaine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/cocaine) overdose.

events.text: France and the Soviet Union established diplomatic relations for the first time since the Communist government had replaced the Russian Empire in 1917. [Leonid Krasin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonid_Krasin) would become the [Soviet Ambassador to France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ambassadors_of_Russia_to_France) on November 14, and Jean Herbette became France's envoy to Moscow.

Many prominent Spaniards opposed to the dictatorship of [Miguel Primo de Rivera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miguel_Primo_de_Rivera) were arrested at a meeting in [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid). The writer [Pedro Sainz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_Sainz_Rodríguez) was among those imprisoned. General [Dámaso Berenguer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dámaso_Berenguer) was present but not arrested at the time.

The British African protectorate of [Sierra Leone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Leone_Colony_and_Protectorate) held its first elections for the native population. Voters were allowed to select three of the 22 members of the new Legislative Council of [Sierra Leone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Leone_Colony_and_Protectorate). The right to vote was limited to literate Africans who were at least 21 years old and had at least 10 pounds sterling of property. Out of 25,000 people, only 1,866 registered. [Ernest Beoku-Betts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernest_Beoku-Betts), [Herbert Bankole-Bright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Bankole-Bright) and Albert Tuboku-Metzger were elected. The other 19 Assembly members were made up of five appointed Africans and 14 British government officials.

events.text: [Voting took place in the UK](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_United_Kingdom_general_election) for all 615 seats of the [House of Commons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom) and was marked by a gain of 154 seats by the [Conservative Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)) of former Prime Minister [Stanley Baldwin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanley_Baldwin), as well as a loss of 158 seats for the coalition of Prime Minister [Ramsey MacDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramsey_MacDonald)'s [Labour Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)) and former Prime Minister [H. H. Asquith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._H._Asquith)'s [Liberal Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_Party_(UK)). With 308 seats needed for a majority, the Labour-Liberal coalition had a 349 to 258 control of Commons over the Conservatives. Baldwin's Tories had a 412 to 198 seat control after the voting.

[John Marden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Marden), 69, Australian headmaster and pioneer of women's education

events.text: Eight deputies of the [Irish Free State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Free_State)'s parliament, the [Dáil Éireann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dáil_Éireann)— [Francis Cahill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Cahill), [Thomas Carter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Carter_(TD)), [Henry Finlay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Finlay), [Seán Gibbons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seán_Gibbons), [Alexander McCabe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_McCabe), [Daniel McCarthy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_McCarthy_(politician)), [Seán McGarry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seán_McGarry) and [Seán Milroy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seán_Milroy)— resigned after the government response in the [Irish Army Mutiny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Army_Mutiny).

Seven days after overthrowing China's President [Cao Kun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cao_Kun) in the [Beijing Coup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing_Coup), Chinese warlord [Feng Yuxiang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feng_Yuxiang) broke with the [Zhili clique](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhili_clique) and allied his forces with the [Fengtian clique](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fengtian_clique) led by [Zhang Zuolin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhang_Zuolin), inviting Zhang to form a new, pro-Japanese, government.

Chemical engineer [Thomas Midgley Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Midgley_Jr.) of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey (later [Exxon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exxon)) participated in a [press conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/press_conference) to demonstrate the apparent safety of the gasoline additive [tetraethyllead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/tetraethyllead) (TEL). Midgley poured the TEL over his hands, placed a bottle of it under his nose, and inhaled its [vapor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/vapor) for 60 seconds, declaring that he could do this every day without succumbing to [any problems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lead_poisoning).  Despite the demonstration, the U.S. state of New Jersey closed the [Bayway Refinery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayway_Refinery), where five workers had died and 35 others were seriously injured from lead poisoning by TEL fumes.
[Henry Ford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Ford) endorsed [Calvin Coolidge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge) for re-election, calling him "short on promises and long on action."

deaths.text: **Died:** [Stina Quint](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stina_Quint), 65, Swedish publisher and founder of the children's magazine *[Kamratposten](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamratposten)*

events.text: The government of [Miguel Primo de Rivera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miguel_Primo_de_Rivera) had Spain's highest general, [Dámaso Berenguer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dámaso_Berenguer), sentenced to six months' imprisonment for insubordination. All others present at the meeting of October 28 were condemned to [solitary confinement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/solitary_confinement) for an indefinite period without trial.
The [Japan Swimming Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan_Swimming_Federation) was founded.
The Ukraine sports club [Dynamo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamo_(Ukraine)) was founded.

sources: Spain's Highest General Sent to Prison as a Rebel - November 1, 1924, p. 1

events.text: Flooding of the [Rhine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhine) river struck [Cologne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cologne); 50,000 were forced to evacuate their homes.
Ireland's first regular radio service, [2RN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2RN) (later *Radio Éireann*), began broadcasting.

In "the game that changed the South", the [Alabama Crimson Tide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Alabama_Crimson_Tide_football_team) won the [1926 Rose Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1926_Rose_Bowl) with a 20–19 win over the [Washington Huskies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Washington_Huskies_football_team).

sources: Floods Dtive 50,000 out of Homes on Rhine - January 2, 1926, p. 5
[1925 College Football National Championship](http://tiptop25.com/champ1925.html)

events.text: Flooding continued to ravage Europe, from England to Romania, due to heavy rains and unseasonably high temperatures.

[Howard Caine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howard_Caine), actor; in [North Hollywood, Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Hollywood,_Los_Angeles) (d. 1993)

births.text: [George Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Martin), producer of [The Beatles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Beatles), in London (d. 2016)

events.text: The [Parliament of Romania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_Romania) ratified the acceptance of [Crown Prince Carol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carol_II_of_Romania)'s renunciation of his right to the throne in the wake of his scandalous affair with [Magda Lupescu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magda_Lupescu), the Roman Catholic daughter of a Jewish pharmacist. His four-year-old son [Michael](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_I_of_Romania) became the new Crown Prince. Carol later reneged on the renunciation and reigned as [King of Romania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_of_Romania) from 1930 to 1940.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Margherita of Savoy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margherita_of_Savoy), 74, queen consort of Italy

events.text: In the United Kingdom, the first [Widow's Pensions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Widow's_pension) were paid out at post offices.

births.text: [W.D. Snodgrass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W.D._Snodgrass), poet, in [Beaver Falls, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaver_Falls,_Pennsylvania) (d. 2009)

sources: Chronicle of the 20th Century - 1989, p. 338, Publisher: Chronicle Communications Ltd., ISBN: 978-0-582-03919-3, Author: Derrik Mercer

events.text: The airline [Deutsche Luft Hansa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Luft_Hansa) was founded in Berlin.

births.text: [Mickey Hargitay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mickey_Hargitay), bodybuilder and actor, in [Budapest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budapest) (d. 2006)

events.text: Ongoing downpours in Europe submerged [Great War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I) cemeteries in France and flooded the [London subway system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_Underground).

The [15th Canadian Parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/15th_Canadian_Parliament) was seated. [William Lyon Mackenzie King](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Lyon_Mackenzie_King) continued as [Prime Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Canada) despite the [Conservatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservative_Party_of_Canada_(1867–1942)) winning more seats in the last [federal election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Canadian_federal_election), by forming a coalition with the [Progressives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_Party_of_Canada). King did not even have his own seat as he'd lost his [York North](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/York_North), Ontario, riding.
The [Royal Academy of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Italy) was created.

sources: Yank Graves Under Floods - January 8, 1926, Author: Henry Wales

[Bảo Đại](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bảo_Đại) became [Emperor of Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Vietnamese_monarchs).

births.text: [Chester Feldman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chester_Feldman), American game show producer, in [The Bronx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bronx), New York (d. 1997); [Evelyn Lear](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Lear), operatic soprano, in [Brooklyn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn), New York (d. 2012); [Hanae Mori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanae_Mori), fashion designer, in [Yoshika, Shimane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshika,_Shimane), Japan (d. 2022); and [Soupy Sales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soupy_Sales), comedian, in [Franklinton, North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklinton,_North_Carolina) (d. 2009)

events.text: The [Navy League of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navy_League_of_the_United_States) released a report finding the [United States Navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Navy) to be unprepared for war and well short of the tonnage limitation set by the [Washington Naval Treaty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Naval_Treaty).

A band of twenty Mexican rebels opened fire aboard the Guadalajara-Mexico City train, then looted and burned the train. An estimated twenty to fifty people were killed and about 300,000 pesos (about $150,000 US) worth of cash and bar silver were stolen.

sources: Fleet Unfit and Getting Worse, Country Told - January 10, 1926, p. 1, Author: Arthur Sears Henning
Mexican Rebel Band Kills U.S. Man and Troops - January 11, 1926, p. 1, Author: John Cornyn
Mexican Troops Kill Bandits and Recover Loot - January 12, 1926

events.text: Mexican federal troops tracked down bandits responsible for the previous evening's train massacre to a ranch in [Jalisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jalisco) and engaged them in a shootout. Most of the rebels were killed in the fighting, and eight who were captured were immediately executed. All the stolen loot was recovered.

sources: [The Guadalajara-Mexico City Train Massacre](http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~wynkoop/webdocs/guadalajara.htm) - 2006

events.text: The [Whittemore Gang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whittemore_Gang) robbed Belgian diamond merchants Albert Goudris and Emanuel Veerman on West 48th Street in Manhattan, making off with $175,000 in gems.

events.text: [Freeman Gosden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeman_Gosden) and [Charles Correll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Correll) premiered their radio program *[Sam 'n' Henry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_'n'_Henry)*, in which the two white performers portray two black characters from [Harlem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harlem) looking to strike it rich in the big city. It was a precursor to Gosden and Correll's more popular later program, *[Amos 'n' Andy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amos_'n'_Andy)*.
The [Pasteur Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pasteur_Institute) in Paris announced the discovery of an anti-tetanus serum.

As known well [synthetic fiber brand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_fiber), [Toray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toray) was founded in [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan), as predecessor name was Toyo Rayon.

Britain and Iraq signed a new treaty extending their relations for 25 years or until Iraq joined the [League of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_Nations).

A [total solar eclipse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/solar_eclipse_of_January_14,_1926) occurred.

The film *[The Sea Beast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sea_Beast_(1926_film))*, starring [John Barrymore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Barrymore), was released.

events.text: Twenty-year-old [Ayn Rand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ayn_Rand) left Russia, departing from Leningrad by train. Her early life experiences in Communist Russia were a major influence on her philosophy.

births.text: [Moira Shearer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moira_Shearer), ballet dancer and actress, in [Dunfermline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunfermline), Scotland (d. 2006)
