events.text: The [Italianization of [South Tyrol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Tyrol)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italianization_of_South_Tyrol) escalated as the government issued a decree requiring citizens of [South Tyrol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Tyrol) to Italianize any names and titles of nobility "which have been translated into other languages or deformed by foreign orthography or foreign endings." Failure to comply carried a fine of up to 1,000 lira.

sources: Tyrol Citizens Told to Make Names Italian - January 19, 1926, p. 3

events.text: [Lev Karakhan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lev_Karakhan), the Soviet ambassador to China, sent a protest to the Chinese Foreign Ministry warning of "serious consequences" if a dispute over the two countries' joint management of the [Chinese Eastern Railway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Eastern_Railway) was not resolved. Manchurian warlord [Zhang Zuolin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhang_Zuolin) had been seizing parts of the railway line and arresting Soviet officials in retaliation for a decision that made Chinese troops pay half-fare instead of being allowed to ride for free. The dispute was a precursor to the [Sino Soviet Conflict](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sino-Soviet_conflict_(1929)) of 1929.

births.text: [Fritz Weaver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fritz_Weaver), actor, in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh), Pennsylvania (d. 2016)

sources: Moscow and the Emergence of Communist Power in China 1925–30 - 2009, p. 20, Publisher: Routledge, ISBN: 978-0-203-88160-6, Author: Bruce Elleman

events.text: German Chancellor Dr. [Hans Luther](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Luther) formed his second cabinet, a minority coalition involving the [Centre Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_Party_(Germany)), [German People's Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_People's_Party) and [National People's Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_National_People's_Party).

births.text: [Patricia Neal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patricia_Neal), actress, in [Packard, Kentucky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packard,_Kentucky) (d. 2010); and [David Tudor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Tudor), American pianist and composer, in [Philadelphia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia) (d. 1996)

Manchuria responded by agreeing to comply, ending the crisis.
The [Shrine Auditorium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shrine_Auditorium) opened in Los Angeles.

events.text: The Third International Radio Week began, featuring transatlantic tests of distance reception. Listeners in New York and Chicago reported successful reception of English and South American radio broadcasts.

sources: Chicago Fans Hear Britain, South America - January 25, 1926, p. 1

events.text: British surgeon [Sir Berkeley Moynihan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berkeley_Moynihan,_1st_Baron_Moynihan) said cancer of the tongue was partly caused by smoking.

births.text: [Bob Clarke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Clarke_(illustrator)), illustrator, in [Mamaroneck, New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamaroneck,_New_York) (d. 2013)

events.text: Scottish inventor [John Logie Baird](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Logie_Baird) demonstrated a mechanical television system for members of the [Royal Institution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Institution) and a reporter from *[The Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Times)* at his London laboratory.

Galician aviator [Ramón Franco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramón_Franco) completed a Trans-Atlantic flight from [Huelva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huelva), Spain to [Buenos Aires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buenos_Aires), Argentina. There were stopovers at [Gran Canaria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gran_Canaria), [Cape Verde](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cape_Verde), [Pernambuco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pernambuco), [Rio de Janeiro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro) and [Montevideo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montevideo) along the way. The 10,270 km journey was completed in 59 hours and 39 minutes.

sources: [Palos de la Frontera](http://www.discoverhuelva.com/town/palos-de-la-frontera)

events.text: The U.S. Senate voted in favor of joining the [World Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permanent_Court_of_International_Justice), but with several specific reservations.

30 communists and 12 monarchists were wounded in street fighting in the [Charlottenburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlottenburg) district of Berlin during demonstrations on the birthday of the former Kaiser, [Wilhelm II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor). The fighting broke out as communists paraded an effigy of the ex-Kaiser hanged from a gallows. Riot police opened fire after attempts to separate the combatants were met with attacks from both sides.

births.text: [Fritz Spiegl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fritz_Spiegl), musician, journalist and broadcaster, in [Zurndorf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zurndorf), Austria (d. 2003); and [Ingrid Thulin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ingrid_Thulin), actress, in [Sollefteå](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sollefteå), Sweden (d. 2004)

Thousands lined the streets of Brussels to watch the funeral procession.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Katō Takaaki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katō_Takaaki), 66, 24th [Prime Minister of Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Japan); and [Ernest Troubridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernest_Troubridge), 63, Royal Navy officer

events.text: [Eugene O'Neill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eugene_O'Neill)'s play *[The Great God Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Great_God_Brown)* opened at the [Greenwich Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenwich_Theatre).

births.text: [Abdus Salam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abdus_Salam), Pakistani theoretical physicist and [Nobel Prize](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics) laureate, in [Jhang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jhang) (d. 1996)

events.text: 27 miners were killed in a gas explosion in Mossboro, Alabama; 26 escaped unhurt.

The Allied occupation of the first zone of the Rhineland ended. At 15:00 hours the British, French and Belgians in the zone all hauled down their flags and withdrew their remaining troops in advance of much of the Rhineland's sovereignty being formally returned to Germany at the stroke of midnight.

The [unidentified body](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/unidentified_decedent) of a young soldier was interred in the [Tomb of the Unknown Soldier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomb_of_the_Unknown_Soldier,_Warsaw) in Warsaw, Poland.
The operetta *[Princess Flavia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Flavia)* opened on Broadway.

Twenty-one-year-old film actress [Constance Bennett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constance_Bennett) married millionaire socialite Philip Morgan Plant in a hotel lobby in [Greenwich, Connecticut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenwich,_Connecticut); she did not make another film until they divorced in 1929.

events.text: Italian Socialist deputy and expert marksman [Tito Zaniboni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tito_Zaniboni) took a hotel room opposite the [Palazzo Chigi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palazzo_Chigi) with [the intent of shooting Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_attempts_on_Benito_Mussolini) with a telescopic rifle when he came out to the balcony to make a speech. The police had been tipped off by an intercepted phone call and stopped the would-be assassin.

The [Reform Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_Reform_Party) led by incumbent Prime Minister [Gordon Coates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Coates) won the [New Zealand general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_New_Zealand_general_election).

The [Dow Jones Industrial Average](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_record_closes_of_the_Dow_Jones_Industrial_Average) closed at 159.39. This was the 65th record close of the calendar year 1925, a record in itself almost doubling the old mark of 34 set in 1899. The record stood until 1995.

events.text: [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh) was granted a franchise by the [National Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hockey_League). The club was named the [Pirates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates_(NHL)), after the baseball team also [based in the city](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates).
Several Italian opposition leaders were arrested in connection with the assassination attempt on [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini).
It was announced that the remains of [Manfred von Richthofen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manfred_von_Richthofen), "The Red Baron", would be disinterred from France and repatriated to Germany.

events.text: The film *[The Eagle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Eagle_(1925_film))*, starring [Rudolph Valentino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_Valentino), was released.

[Parliamentary elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Portuguese_legislative_election) were held in Portugal. The [Democratic Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Portugal)) won a majority with 83 of the 163 seats.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Domício da Gama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domício_da_Gama), 62, Brazilian journalist and diplomat

events.text: Forces allied with [Wu Peifu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wu_Peifu) inflicted a defeat on [Zhang Zuolin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhang_Zuolin) after several days of fighting south of [Xuzhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xuzhou).

The [Leonard "Kip" Rhinelander](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kip_Rhinelander) divorce trial opened in [White Plains, New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_Plains,_New_York). Rhinelander was seeking an annulment of the marriage because his wife Alice had failed to inform him of her "[colored](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mulatto)" blood before the wedding. The trial was a significant [media circus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/media_circus) event at the time.

The [race film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/race_film) *[Body and Soul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_and_Soul_(1925_film))* was released, directed by [Oscar Micheaux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oscar_Micheaux) and starring [Paul Robeson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Robeson) in his film debut.

The process was exceedingly difficult due to the extreme fragility of the bandages and the resinous coating that held the mummy fast inside the sarcophagus.
*[Le Faisceau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faisceau)*, a French [Fascist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/fascism) party, was founded, consisting of about 10,000 members.

events.text: [Louis Armstrong and His Hot Five](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Armstrong_and_His_Hot_Five) recorded their first songs together for [Okeh Records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Okeh_Records). These recordings were among the most important and influential in the development of [jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/jazz) music.

The British submarine [HMS M1 (1917)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_M1_(1917)) sank with all 69 hands in the [English Channel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_Channel) when it was hit by the Swedish ship SS *Vidar*.
The Italian government agreed to repay its war debt to the United States with a fixed interest rate of 0.4 percent.

events.text: The Polish Cabinet of [Władysław Grabski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Władysław_Grabski) resigned over the difference of opinion with the banks over how to stabilize the [zloty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish_zloty).

sources: Polish Cabinet Resigns After Row with Bank - November 14, 1925, p. 6

events.text: The [Nationalist Party of Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nationalist_Party_of_Australia) won the [Australian federal election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Australian_federal_election) winning 37 of 75 seats, despite losing the popular vote. This was the first [Australian federal election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Australian_federal_election) to have compulsory voting.
The first [Surrealist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrealism) art exhibition opened in Paris.

sources: Chronicle of the 20th Century - 1989, p. 335, Publisher: Chronicle Communications Ltd., ISBN: 978-0-582-03919-3, Author: Derrik Mercer

About 2,000 German Fascist followers of [Erich Ludendorff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erich_Ludendorff) gathered in front of the [Berlin City Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_Palace,_Berlin) to protest the [Locarno Treaties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locarno_Treaties).

A [general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Burmese_general_election) was held in [Burma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burma). The People's Party received the most votes, but was unable to form a government.

The autopsy of [Tutankhamun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tutankhamun) concluded. The bad condition of the body and limited [forensic science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/forensic_science) of the 1920s meant that little could be determined other than the age of the body being estimated to be about eighteen.

[Paul Painlevé](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Painlevé) resigned as [Prime Minister of France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_France) when a credit moratorium article in his financial plan was defeated in the [Chamber of Deputies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(France)) by three votes.

deaths.text: **Died:** [Vajiravudh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vajiravudh), 45, monarch of [Siam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thailand), at the [Grand Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Palace) in [Phra Nakhon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangkok)

events.text: Italy promulgated a bill bringing secret societies such as [Freemasonry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freemasonry) under the control of the state and forbidding government employees from belonging to them.

It was reported that the British government had advised [Benito Mussolini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini) not to attend the formal signing of the [Locarno Treaties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locarno_Treaties) in London, as it could not protect him from being insulted in public. The British public was generally displeased by Mussolini's increasingly [authoritarian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/authoritarianism) rule, and labor factions were particularly angered over his suppression of Italian [trade unions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/trade_union). Diplomat Vittorio Scialoja would be sent as the Italian representative instead.

events.text: A state funeral was held at [Westminster Abbey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westminster_Abbey) in London for [Queen mother](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen_mother) [Alexandra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandra_of_[Denmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_X_of_Denmark)). The kings of [England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_V), [Denmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_X_of_Denmark), [Norway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haakon_VII_of_Norway) and [Belgium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_I_of_Belgium) marched behind the casket in the procession.
[Feng Yuxiang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feng_Yuxiang) sent a public message to [Zhang Zuolin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhang_Zuolin) telling him to retire or else he would be attacked.

The jury in the [Ossian Sweet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ossian_Sweet) trial said it was unable to reach a verdict after 46 hours of deliberation. The judge declared a mistrial and dismissed the jury.

Miriam Noel Wright, the wife of architect [Frank Lloyd Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Lloyd_Wright), filed for divorce, alleging desertion and cruelty. It had not previously been known to the public that they were married.
The [Reichstag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic)) approved the [Locarno Treaties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locarno_Treaties).

The [Grand Ole Opry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Ole_Opry) was first broadcast, as a one-hour radio "barn dance" on [WSM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WSM_(AM)) in [Nashville, Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nashville,_Tennessee).

[Queen mother](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen_mother) [Alexandra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandra_of_Denmark) was buried in [St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._George's_Chapel,_Windsor_Castle) alongside her [late husband](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_VII) in a simple ceremony.

In American football, the [[Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Military_Academy)–Navy Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Military_Academy)–Navy_Game) was won by the [Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Military_Academy), 10 to 3, at the [Polo Grounds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polo_Grounds) in New York.

events.text: [Parliamentary elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_[Uruguay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uruguay)an_parliamentary_election) were held in [Uruguay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uruguay). The [National Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Party_(Uruguay)) won the most seats of any one party, but various factions of the [Colorado Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colorado_Party_(Uruguay)) formed a majority.

The comedy film *[Clothes Make the Pirate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clothes_Make_the_Pirate)* starring [Leon Errol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leon_Errol) and [Dorothy Gish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dorothy_Gish) was released.
The Australian seamen's strike ended after fifteen weeks when [Melbourne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melbourne), the last port to hold out, capitulated.
Religious convents and [dervish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/dervish) lodges were closed in Turkey.

A [tropical storm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Florida_tropical_storm) struck near [Tampa, Florida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tampa,_Florida), becoming the latest hurricane to ever make landfall in the United States.

The film *[Cobra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cobra_(1925_film))*, starring [Rudolph Valentino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_Valentino) and [Nita Naldi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nita_Naldi), opened.

The Netherlands held a [general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_general_election,_1925), in which the [General League of Roman Catholic Caucuses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_League_of_Roman_Catholic_Caucuses) maintained its plurality.
The first [International Congress of Radiology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Congress_of_Radiology) opened in London.

events.text: The German government sent a strong protest note to the Soviet Union over the sentencing of three German students to death for "high treason and spying". Numerous German newspapers called for a break in diplomatic relations between the two countries as many were convinced that the charges were trumped up in order to arrange for an exchange of prisoners.

[Suzanne Lenglen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suzanne_Lenglen) of France defeated [Joan Fry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joan_Fry) of the United Kingdom in the [Women's Singles Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Wimbledon_Championships_–_Women's_Singles) at Wimbledon.

sources: Berlin Papers Demand Break with Russians - July 4, 1925, p. 3
[3 July 1925, Friday](http://takemeback.to/03-July-1925#.VKDhuF4ALw)

events.text: The [collapse of the Pickwick Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pickwick_Club_collapse) in [Boston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston) killed 44 people, most of them party-goers at an event that had started the night before to celebrate the Fourth of July.

Police in Rome reported that the treasury of [St. Peter's Basilica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Peter's_Basilica) was robbed of 5–7 million lira worth of valuables, including gold crosses and other religious objects.

[René Lacoste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/René_Lacoste) defeated fellow French tennis player [Jean Borotra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Borotra) in the [Men's Singles Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Wimbledon_Championships_–_Men's_Singles) at Wimbledon.
Amusement park [Belmont Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belmont_Park_(San_Diego)) opened in [San Diego](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Diego), California.

events.text: Numerous arrests were made and stolen items were recovered in the [St. Peter's Basilica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Peter's_Basilica) robbery case. Six workmen who were doing repairs in the vicinity of the treasury room were among those arrested.

events.text: [William Jennings Bryan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Jennings_Bryan) arrived by train in [Dayton, Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Tennessee) to a hero's welcome as national anticipation of the [Scopes Trial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scopes_Trial) accelerated. Bryan gave a fiery speech saying the trial would be a "duel to the death".

Defense lawyer [Clarence Darrow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clarence_Darrow) arrived in [Dayton, Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Tennessee) to much less fanfare than that afforded [Bryan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Jennings_Bryan) the previous day.

Norway passed the [Svalbard Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Svalbard_Act).

Flooding in [Seoul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seoul), Korea killed hundreds as dikes broke on the third straight day of heavy rain.

events.text: Italian cyclist [Ottavio Bottecchia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ottavio_Bottecchia) won the [Tour de France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_Tour_de_France) for the second straight year.

Italy and Yugoslavia signed the [Treaty of Nettuno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Nettuno), permitting Italians to freely immigrate to [Dalmatia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dalmatia). Its ratification was held up in the Yugoslav parliament for three years as the [Croatian Peasant Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croatian_Peasant_Party) staunchly opposed it.

Near [Montecatini Terme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montecatini_Terme) in Italy, a gang of Fascists attacked opposition figure [Giovanni Amendola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Amendola), ambushing his car in the dead of night and beating him savagely. Details of the attack were censored in government-controlled media to avoid another outcry along the lines of the [Matteotti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giacomo_Matteotti) scandal. Amandola died of his wounds nine months later.
A [solar eclipse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_eclipse_of_July_20,_1925) occurred.

events.text: The [Scopes Trial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scopes_Trial) ended with [John Scopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Scopes) being found guilty of violating the [Butler Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butler_Act) and fined $100, which both [William Jennings Bryan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Jennings_Bryan) and the [American Civil Liberties Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Civil_Liberties_Union) offered to pay for him. After the verdict was read Scopes made his only statement during the trial, vowing to "oppose this law in any way I can. Any other action would be in violation of my ideal of academic freedom — that is, to teach the truth as guaranteed in our constitution, of personal and religious freedom."
The Battle of al-Kafr was fought in the [Great Syrian Revolt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Syrian_Revolt).

The [Council of People's Commissars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Council_of_People's_Commissars) passes a resolution mandating use of the [metric system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/metric_system) throughout the [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union).

The [Ethel Smyth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethel_Smyth) comic opera *[Entente Cordiale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entente_Cordiale_(opera))* was first performed at the [Royal College of Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music) in London. The performance was broadcast on the [BBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC).

sources: The BBC and Ultra-Modern Music, 1922–1936 - 1999, p. 79, Publisher: Cambridge University Press, ISBN: 0-521-66117-X, Author: Jennifer Doctor

events.text: Ex-Kaiser of Germany [Wilhelm II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor) made it known in a statement to the [United Press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Press_International) through his spokesperson [Hubert von Rebeur-Paschwitz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubert_von_Rebeur-Paschwitz) that he believed the [Treaty of Versailles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles) should be scrapped, explaining, "The criminal and impossible treaty of Versailles has disarmed Germany and left Europe and the world bereft of the greatest factor of peace. You will agree that the greatest danger to Europe and the United States of America lies in the fact that the thus disarmed central Europe is surrounded by a number of nations all armed to the teeth and continually increasing their armaments."

events.text: Negotiations between the British government and representatives of the country's nearly one million coal miners entered their final hours before a nationwide miner's strike over wages was set to begin at midnight. Leaders of the railway and transport workers issued notices to their workers telling them not to handle coal when the strike began as a gesture of solidarity with the miners.

"All the workers in this country have got to take reductions in wages to help put industry on its feet", British Prime Minister [Stanley Baldwin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanley_Baldwin) stated.
